We must get on with dealing with trade, the environment, science, digital, security, fishing, agriculture, and all the rest. But there were three issues to solve before the next phase – not two and a half, but three. For too many people, the future is still unclear. This Parliament must continue to demand action on our citizens’ rights.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in its guidelines the Council has promised mutual, effective, enforceable, non-discriminatory and comprehensive guarantees on citizens' rights. Despite the progress made, the preliminary agreement between negotiators does not yet reflect these characteristics: its entirety is still compromised by the absence of crucial rights such as the protection of future family members and free movement within the Union. The current characteristics of settled status are in contrast with the principles of non-discrimination and reciprocity to the detriment of European citizens in the United Kingdom. The Commission's openness to possible similar instruments in the Member States risks undermining European law itself. Reciprocity and the effectiveness of rights are also at risk if the role of the Court of Justice no longer becomes precise. Important steps forward have been made, however the second phase of negotiations will have to serve to fill the many gaps still existing on Northern Ireland and on the protection of the full set of rights deriving from European law. It is not just about legal certainty, but about keeping the promise that nothing will change in the lives of millions of citizens.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, Brexit is the zombie that staggers on, dragging distress and disappointment in its wake. The resolution we are debating today makes it clear that Brexit means losses on both sides, but there is a stark contrast in the way the two sides are approaching the negotiations. The EU side have a clear and consistent position, and they have sheltered the EU citizens who are their responsibility, protecting their rights to travel and work and ensuring that the UK pays for the projects they depend on that we have already committed to in this budget period. By contrast, the UK negotiators have not been able to agree a position, a state of unpreparedness reinforced by the Chancellor’s admission this week that the cabinet has not even debated what they hope to achieve and by David Davis’s shenanigans. To constituents who feel let down by the negotiations, it is important to recall that we can still step back. This is why the Green Party is demanding a final say and a democratic choice between the deal as negotiated – with all the trade-offs and disappointments – and continued membership of the European Union.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, on 23 June 2016, the British people voted by a clear majority to leave the European Union. That decision was not conditional on any withdrawal agreement or any other factor. Eighteen months later, we still have not left and the leaving process is in a shambles. Mrs May is a Remainer; she leads a party and a parliament that, sadly, is made up of a majority of Remainers. They simply do not want to leave. What Mrs May and the European Union intend is one of two outcomes: either to achieve a deal whereby we leave in name, but not in reality; or to delay the whole leaving process until the next general election, when the referendum result can be set aside. Either way, the result of the referendum is being betrayed. Her Majesty’s Government should not be asking the European Union how it can leave; it should be telling the European Union how it is going to leave. It will never be too late for a patriotic government and parliament to take control and make Brexit happen.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - I would like to address our British colleagues, because apart from the outcome of Brexit, there is an important and interesting psychological phenomenon.That is because here in this House, on the side of those left behind in the European Union, there is a kind of acceleration tendency among the proponents of the European Union, among the EU federalists.They are all in a spasm as if they are being chased by the devil.Nobody illustrates this better than our colleague Belet from the EPP group, who said in a well-watched television broadcast last week: "I am glad they left because they were a pain in the ass anyway".In doing so, he explains why people like Schultz, Macron and others are now fully pressing the accelerator.We have to realize, friends who are left here, EU critics: we are going to miss those Brits.I wish them all the best but will miss them.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, 537 days ago the majority of British people voted to leave the EU, but for 537 days we have listened to a rump of Remainers moan, whinge and cry about losing their beloved EU. For 537 days we have watched a cabal of political elitists wage an anti-democratic campaign in the UK to delay, damage and deny Brexit.  But at Christmas time we are reminded that three wise men brought gifts to Jesus for a brighter future and, in that spirit, I offer three gifts to those Remainers in this Chamber and beyond: the gifts of hearing, hope and a heart. Hearing, so that the voice of those people who believe leaving the EU will make their lives better, brighter and freer is at long last heard by you. Hope, so that someday you accept the result and start to move on. Finally, a heart, because those who you have abused by calling old, stupid and ignorant for voting to leave believe you do not have one. Happy Christmas and a joyous Brexit New Year.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, last week the British Prime Minister managed to avoid a ‘no deal’ scenario but the risk remains and there is still a long way. We are at the beginning of an arduous, complex, intensive process of drafting the withdrawal agreement with a number of issues of relevance remaining outstanding. We also have ahead transition negotiations and the future relationship is still to be identified. The most difficult is yet to come.  The transition period raises many legal issues which will have to be considered with the highest caution. It will have to provide for connection with the future framework, foreseeable at that time, and the talks on transition will precede the negotiations on the future relationship, so there is no reason to call transition an implementation phase. But transition is not only about bridging with the future framework; it has its own challenges. It is true that there is no time to negotiate a bespoke transition agreement, so its major part will be the prolongation of the acquis, but it only looks simple.  We have to bear in mind that the EU acquis is strongly interdependent in a legally and politically complex way and this is a challenge in itself, but there will also be parts of the transition deal going beyond prolongation of the acquis, and this will require in my view a strong credible joint oversight mechanism with a strong role for the European Commission on our side.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: –Madam President, this is certainly the time for ambitious European solutions, but this is not the case for the joint declaration to be signed tomorrow by the three institutions. It lacks this kind of ambition – to start with, on the way to deliver the European Social Pillar, because we want to update social standards for all citizens, starting with young people, in all Member States.  For this, we need to have more powerful instruments to support convergence: real convergence, economic and social convergence. Take the reform package for Economic and Monetary Union: we welcome the fact that important movements will take place to introduce more democracy when it comes to the accountability of the European Stability Mechanism.  But let me be clear: if you want to have upward convergence, reforms are needed, but these are not enough; we need to have a stronger priority for investment, and this investment priority remains too weak in the integrated Fiscal Compact, too weak in the instrument to support convergence, too weak even in the so-called instrument to protect investment. The only way to have stronger priority for investment is to have an upcoming Community budget with new own resources supporting stronger future—oriented investment. We need to get these, and we count on the Estonian Presidency to deliver on this.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - I still hope Brexit does not go ahead. Brexit is harmful, politically and economically, for both parties. The political center of gravity in the European Union then shifts to the south and we are already seeing what wild wishes for even more Europe Mr Macron is expressing. Brexit is economically damaging because the gross domestic product of the United Kingdom will be hit hard, but also that of the European Union and, unfortunately, that of my country. For now: quickly through to the second negotiation phase. Definitely not a fight divorce, but good and reasonable agreements. We must continue to live and work with each other after 2019. We must keep the political and economic gap created by this departure as small as possible. That is in the interest of the United Kingdom and the interest of the European Union. Finally, millions of Britons voted for Brexit in 2016. That result is not only due to the tabloids or to UKIP. There is a sentiment underneath that we also encounter in my country. This week, a report by the Social Cultural Planning Office showed that support for the European Union in the Netherlands has dropped from 75 to 58%. This cries out for reflection, not for fleeing for even more EU.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, today’s debate is helping to provide some clarity. Mr Barnier, you were clear. You said there would be no going back and that last week’s agreement will be translated into a legal text. Mr Verhofstadt strengthened this by suggesting it should be done in the coming weeks, not months. With regard to the second strand, Mr Barnier, regarding Northern Ireland, again you were clear. You said we need a specific solution for a unique situation, and I agree. While the issue of no hardening of the Irish border and the upholding of the Good Friday Agreement are crucial, the agreement on citizens’ rights is of fundamental importance to all EU citizens, and to Irish citizens living and/or working in the UK, those who have lived there, and to all cross—border workers. But we need trust to continue these negotiations in good faith. Yes, we all recognise what political grandstanding is, but this process is way too important to be derailed by those who simply like the sound of their own voices.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, the United Kingdom's withdrawal agreement with the European Union must in no way jeopardize workers' rights or other social rights enjoyed by citizens of the Member States of the European Union in the United Kingdom, including the right of residence, the right to non-discriminatory treatment, the right of access to public services, health and education, the portability of benefits and rights in terms of social security, the right to family reunification, the mutual recognition of qualifications academic and professional, among other examples, something that is not acquired at the current stage of negotiations nor is it explicit in the joint resolution proposal. Any possible future agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom must take into account the interests and specificities of the different Member States. Furthermore, this agreement must not, cannot, remove the right of each Member State to establish relations with the United Kingdom in the most diverse areas based on the interests and mutual benefit of the respective peoples.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Madam President, I will be supporting the resolution this afternoon in the votes, and I do so with a sense of real sadness and more than a little anger, both personally and on behalf of the people that I represent. Scotland did not want this; Scotland voted against this; this is not in Scotland’s name. But we do need – and I say it through gritted teeth – to move onto phase two of the negotiations, because for too many people in the UK Brexit remains white noise: a false equivalence aided by an industrial—scale spin machine telling us that somehow we will have our cake and eat it; that it’ll be alright on the night, because we’re special, we’re British. People need to see the detail, the line—by—line, the policy—by—policy, the nitty—gritty. People need to see what they’re going to lose for a Brexit to become real. And in phase two, the promises of the shysters and charlatans who have so disgraced themselves even in their conduct today in this debate will be shown for what they are: a cruel deception of the people they claim to serve. This is the end of the beginning of this Brexit negotiation. I look forward to phase two, where we will hold them to account. (Applause)

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, Mr Smith is not being factual. 40% of Scots voted against the European Union. That’s a substantial minority of which I am a representative. He is misleading the House by suggesting that Scots do not want to be in Britain or do not want to leave the European Union. That is an absolute travesty.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, in my country Manchester United fans still talk about the Holy Trinity of Best, Law and Charlton. In the EU we have the rather less holy trinity of Juncker, Schulz and Verhofstadt, each supporting the creation of a federal superstate. Mr Verhofstadt believes the nations of Europe are dwarves that cannot prosper independently. In his State of the Union speech Mr Juncker unveiled a raft of new integrationist plans, and Mr Schulz left this place to go around Germany stirring up apathy about a United States of Europe.  If that’s what you want, then fair enough, but do not affect to be surprised that the British people won’t go there. Even a moment’s reflection on our history and indeed our geography should tell you that. So you should let us leave the EU with good will. Instead, many of you seek to punish us and it is that spirit of pettiness that will in the end destroy all your grand plans.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council and of the Commission, two visions of security / defense are at odds. That of General De Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer, a Europe independent of NATO but a partner, as conceived by the Elysee Treaty of January 22, 1963, before its passage through the Bundestag on May 16, before its addendum resituating this treaty of independence in transatlantic dependence; and then, that of the American Jean Monnet, wanting to make defense Europe an annex of the United States. Chancellors Erhard and Kiesinger had so much to be forgiven for their past that they supported her against Adenauer. Merkel too. Since Adenauer, we can no longer speak of a Franco-German couple, because we, French patriots in defense Europe, see a dynamic of independence and the others, including Germany, a case of dependence in the pooling. In security / defense, we must build this Gaullean vision of European independence with the United States within the United Nations, in a now multipolar world, otherwise the Europe of defense will be a failure.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Madam President! Today we are making progress in two important areas: defense: establishing permanent PESCO structured cooperation, defense industry cooperation, and a breakthrough in negotiations with the UK - congratulations to Michel Barnier and his team. A few words of mine about an issue that has not been discussed today, but that will be on the agenda of the December Summit: the European Pillar of Social Rights, proclaimed in Gothenburg on November 17. Today I have the impression that the physical sense of security related to terrorist threats, border tightness and migration will be a more important battlefield against populism than social security, because the economy is simply doing better. And if this social pillar is built in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, it will not multiply promises that cannot be fulfilled at the EU level, that's fine. For example, if it is to strengthen the Erasmus + program, cooperation between universities, recognition of qualifications, everything that serves mobility on the market, because there is still not enough mobility on the common market. But there are reasons why the slogan "social pillar" awakens the vigilance of many countries, especially in the east. Then, when the slogan of social dumping appears in his company and tough regulations are born, then the Polish plumber comes back a bit, which was promoted as the main threat during the French referendum. Now it turns out that truck drivers from the east or Spain or construction workers are stealing dream jobs from richer countries, which is not true. Yes, I warn you that this type of regulation, which may create a shadow economy, is also ammunition for populism. Political impact assessment is essential for creating the social pillar.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President!Once again a summit will deal with the causa prima of Europe, the refugee and migration policy, and once again - this prognosis is by no means daring - little will come of it.The conditions would be more favorable than ever.In its last session, the European Parliament decided on a balanced draft mandate for the reform of the Dublin system, on the basis of which the permanently delayed realignment could be tackled immediately.All it really takes is the courage to finally start negotiations.Maybe a Christmas miracle will happen.At least one problem could be tackled in the short term: As every year, this year tens of thousands of refugees are stuck in winter-unsuitable quarters, freeze and become victims of criminal smugglers.It would be my Christmas wish that the Member States finally honor the commitments they made to the UNHCR.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that we have now the opportunity to move on from phase one. While we should not underestimate the difficulties that lie ahead, we now have a real opportunity to agree a deep and comprehensive deal between the United Kingdom and the European Union. It has always been the case that the best way to find solutions to the question of the border between the United Kingdom and the European Union is to discuss the trade and customs arrangements. None of us want to return to the borders of the past, but equally I cannot tolerate or accept anything that would create an internal UK east-west border. The United Kingdom is by far Northern Ireland’s most important single market, and that must not be jeopardised – and that, Mr Barnier, I believe is the challenge we have to achieve. The UK and the EU now have an opportunity to agree on a deal that works for all parties that can only be achieved if we work together and with cool heads. Let us move on from the grandstanding and the megaphone diplomacy in some parts of this debate. It is time for that, it is for sure not for the future.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, last week a salutary compromise was presented by the European Union and the United Kingdom. This first step in the negotiations is not an end in itself, it is a clarification, but much remains to be done. I salute the work carried out by the Commission under the responsibility of Michel Barnier. Despite an obvious initial lack of preparation and a regular lack of clarity on the part of the British leaders, our negotiator has been able to stay the course, impose a timetable and defend our red lines, and I would like to say at this point or reiterate our gratitude and our gratitude to him. Guarantees are on the table today: preserving the rights of European citizens in the UK and those of British citizens in the EU, full settlement of UK financial commitments and no hard border between Ireland and the United Kingdom. North Ireland. There is never a good divorce, of course, but let's see the positive side: the sovereign choice of the British people has served as an electric shock to strengthen unity within the European Union, and it is by being united that we will have to make the second phase of the negotiations a stage in the service of European interests. When it comes to trade, for example, we must be vigilant. In strategic sectors, at a time when the British will necessarily have to rebuild their commercial attractiveness to the whole world, the United Kingdom must not serve as a Trojan horse for foreign investment. So, on our side, let us maintain our efforts. The report that I am bringing to Parliament for better monitoring of foreign investment will complement the work carried out to reform our anti-dumping methodology and to modernize our trade defense instruments. In this unprecedented negotiation, because there is still a long way to go, let us not let our guard down and continue to defend the interests of Europeans with pragmatism and determination.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Madam President, I would like to refer to the unacceptable document on migration that President Donald Tusk has presented for debate in the Council.In my country there is a saying that says: "Eyes that do not see, heart that does not feel."But with this document, Mr. Tusk seems to show that there are hearts that do not feel even if they see human suffering live.He is not listening either, because he has not listened to this Parliament, nor is he listening to the efforts that the Commission is making.The Council seems to insist on a proven wrong path on migration and refuge, which consists of moving away, making borders bigger, preventing more and more urgently the legal routes for migration.A proven wrong path.This is what President Tusk presents in his document.And so you are liquidating the prestige of the European Union and its values.And then they wonder that anti-European populisms are winning the battle.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: - Madam president. Congratulations, Mr Barnier, on your work and congratulations on conducting the most transparent negotiation in history. We have finally agreed to divorce. Now we have to talk about what the open relationship we want to maintain in the future will be like. We have agreed that the rights of citizens are protected by law and that our law will be incorporated directly into British law and, to guarantee this, that for eight years the European Court will be able to rule creating jurisprudence. We have agreed that the settlement bill will be reasonable and will meet three rules: that no one will have to pay more than what they are paying; that the commitments acquired will be fulfilled; and that the UK will pay no more than if it were a member of the European Union. On Northern Ireland we are committed, even if there is no hard border, to respect the Good Friday Accords, the territorial integrity of the United Kingdom and the integrity of the single market. It is very difficult and here we are going to have to use ourselves thoroughly because we are all going to support the position of the Irish Government until the end, until this declaration is possible. During the transitional period, the United Kingdom will continue to be part of the customs union and the single market, respecting the four freedoms, but will no longer be able to participate in the election or in the decisions of the European Union. What then remains to be done? The most difficult: closing the technical details of this political agreement; determine the length and scope of the transitional period and begin negotiating a trade agreement. This agreement is not the end of anything, it is simply the beginning of everything. This is a political agreement, with many loose ends from a technical point of view that Mr Barnier will now have to negotiate and will have to tie up. We have made it easy. Mr Barnier, the hardest part is coming for you now because, as always, success will be for us to reach a Brexit that will not look like a Brexit.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too want to congratulate our negotiator Michel Barnier on the excellent result.However, I would like to return to other issues that have been dealt with.In particular, the first package on the social dimension of the European Union, education and culture should be definitively approved in the Council following the meeting in Gothenburg, and I would like to appreciate this even if we are still far from what we would like.Secondly, we also appreciate the fact that a large package of proposals has been made on the euro area: it is okay that the Parliament is the Parliament of the euro area, we are also pleased to hear that, but remember that a democratic issue continues to exist.on all these matters, plus the question of defense, cooperation on defense, the democratic question, it is the role of Parliament in most of these matters which is not on par with that of the Council.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom ar dtús buíochas rialtas na hÉireann a chur in iúl do gach uile dhuine san Aontas a chabhraigh linn. Go háirithe, an dá Uachtarán, Tusk agus Juncker, an tUasal Barnier, Guy Verhofstadt, Manfred Weber agus gach uile dhuine. Mar a dúirt Donald Tusk, ní neart go cur le chéile agus thaispeánamar é sin.  The Irish Government, and indeed all of the Irish people, are very happy at the practical and sensible agreement announced last Friday, with the protection of the Good Friday Agreement, in all its parts, the preservation of the Common Travel Area and, above all, no hard border and full regulatory alignment to make that happen, which can be worked out in Phase 2.  Also, something which has not been mentioned enough is the willingness of the European Union to continue Peace (Programme for Peace and Reconciliation) and Interreg funding into the future, post-Brexit. And mentioning Peace, we do not want a hard border because there has been too much blood spilled in Ireland over the border, with a bloody civil war and 20 years of terror. Nobody wants to go back to that, and thanks to Mr Barnier, the Irish Government and, indeed, Theresa May, that will not happen.  Finally, I would like to say also to Theresa May that we appreciate her efforts in difficult circumstances to progress matters. Hopefully, she will get the backing of all her colleagues because this is not a time for disunity. We in Ireland are totally united, the European Union is totally united, and those in the United Kingdom have to stand behind Theresa May. It is not helpful when people make statements that commitments are only statements of intent. A commitment is a commitment, a guarantee is a guarantee, and nothing else. Finally, I would tell her that there is an old Irish phrase also which says ‘is binn béal ina thost’: ‘sweet is the mouth that is silent’. She may, in her wisdom, teach some of her colleagues that old adage.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Madam President! I congratulate you, Mr Barnier, on the outcome of the negotiations that you have presented to us. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Budgets, I was particularly concerned about the consequences of Brexit for the European budget, for which the United Kingdom has made far-reaching commitments. The result guarantees that we will be able to complete the medium-term financial framework as planned. It guarantees that the UK will continue to participate in the pension benefits of EU officials who have served the UK while it was a member of the European Union, and not a few of them are UK citizens Kingdom. But that also means that the foolishness about land and wine bottles we heard from the island has ended. I am convinced that Britain is weaker without the EU and that the EU is weaker without the UK. Against this background, I am pleased that Article 73 of the joint report mentions that Britain is considering further participation in EU policies. That is sensible and we should do it, subject to further contributions to the EU budget.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like, with regard to the Council, to express my most vehement disgust at the way in which President Tusk presented the refugee issue. I think it is unacceptable for a community of law that defends human rights, which is undoubtedly a reference for fundamental rights, that the issue of refugees is treated in this way and, therefore, this is deplorable and must be removed. We are on the side of the Commission and President Juncker on this matter. I would then like to congratulate Michel Barnier for the results obtained, for his commitment, for his determination, for the way he has defended the rights of European citizens, including all British citizens who are on the continent and who are also on the British Isles. And finally, there was a message for the Brexit minister, Mr. David Davis: once upon a time, even gentlemen’s agreements were binding. This is the message I wanted to leave. Even a gentlemen's agreement is binding, which will negotiate between institutions like the Government of Great Britain and the European Commission and the European Council!

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Madam President, I’m grateful to Mr Verhofstadt for his clarification that the phase one agreement will be put into a legal text, this is very important news, particularly for citizens who need the assurances going forward. But let’s be clear about the situation that we find ourselves in. The reason that the fantasists opposite have been able to claim, as they often do, that this is a betrayal, is because the government’s own rhetoric is wildly different from the reality that we face. You cannot have a hard border in Ireland and preserve the peace process. You cannot have a hard border in the Irish Sea and preserve the four nations and the integrity of the United Kingdom. This is integral to Brexit, and in the ‘full alignment’ that was agreed under phase one it will of course mean the following: the decisions on Britain’s trade and economic policy will be made in this House and in the European institutions, where we currently have a voice but where we will have none because of Brexit. And it’s up to the proponents opposite to explain to their constituents how that is taking back control. It is not taking back control, it is ceding it.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, when the history of Brexit comes to be written, one aspect of it is bound to play a prominent role: the quality of the communication between London and Brussels, especially in the media. ‘Communication’ may be the wrong word; ‘miscommunication’ might be better. The Council mandate of 29 April is crystal clear on what the EU expected from the United Kingdom. Yet, the British media have treated the negotiations as if they had never read the Council’s mandate. Who knows, maybe there is no ‘as if’ about it – certainly, much of the British media comment has reflected a very different mindset about Brexit: one in which the EU’s position has played next to no role. It’s bizarre. The UK is constantly trumpeting diversity and multiculturalism. Evidently, the EU, Brussels, the European Parliament and the 27 are not a part of this diversity.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, Brexit will dominate this week's meeting, ie whether enough progress has been made to move to the second phase.A joint statement was finally agreed last week, stakes increased, but the price of parting also increased.I hope for faster progress in the second phase, in which we will have to define the future relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom.As a Croatian Member of Parliament, I particularly welcome the provision that Croatian citizens will be treated in the same way as other citizens of the Union, because they are still subject to a temporary restriction on access to the labor market.I also support the historically important strengthening of joint defense cooperation, which was chosen by as many as 25 members.It is good that President Tusk has invited all members of the eurozone summit, given the importance of the agenda.But these are not the only topics relevant to the future of the European Union.I am glad that social issues, culture and education have also found their place on the agenda.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, the European Council should support the Brexit negotiations as presented here, especially with regard to the security of citizens who are at risk of insecurity following the UK's accession. While the United Kingdom is not united, the European Union has a united position. That is our strength and our advantage in negotiations. I would welcome the European Council to take note of its President Tusk's position on resolving the migration crisis. He said only what he thought. I wanted to call on Mr Timmermans, who said here that the Member States must strike a balance between solidarity and security. Mr Timmermans, you said that securing the border and fighting smugglers must be our priority. That is also my opinion. The Member States must be and are also in solidarity, but they also have a responsibility. This solution must be common and at the same time respect the situation and the position of the individual Member States. In my opinion, Mr Tusk said the same thing, we cannot ignore subsidiarity.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, Mr Negotiator, Mr Barnier, thank you for introducing - could we say? - "the wolf in the sheepfold". In any case, the word “internal market” in paragraph 49 of this long joint report which - I believe - is a common thread on which we will be able to build a lot for the future of relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom . But there are other subjects on the European Council's agenda and I am surprised that the Commission is not at its seat. I would have liked to invite him to stress the importance, of course, of Economic and Monetary Union reforms, even in the absence of a German government apart from an acting government. In fact, there are elements in the proposals on which we need to move forward, and in particular the idea of ​​a safety net for the resolution fund, because it is a point that otherwise risks blocking a lot of progress that we need, whatever the electoral calendar of the ones and the others.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Madam President, at many British tables, I think, Christmas lunch 2017 will still be surrounded by uncertainty. First and foremost, for European citizens and their families, and indeed, as many colleagues have said, more guarantees are needed here. But also economically, as the BBC reported that this same Christmas lunch will this year be 20% more expensive due to Brexit-induced inflation and price volatility. Yes, let us talk about trade, as that is also in the interests of our producers, our farmers, and our fishermen. But let us be clear: access to the single market is not free. You can’t have your cake and eat it. Finally, now that I am in the Christmas spirit anyway, let me warn this House against false prophets, like the Brexit prophet Nigel Farage, who, through nonsense, lies, and videotape, got his Brexit and then ran away. He talks about unelected bureaucrats but he betrayed his voters and, indeed, now he is absent. He had his videotape, he will post his speech on all the social media. But let us promise our voters and our citizens one thing: the work in this House will have to be done by serious and maybe less flamboyant politicians, and that is us. So when we reconvene after Christmas, let us get to work in the interests of the European citizens and also the Brits.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, curious things have been happening in these debates for some time: the Council is almost always reticent, while the Commission often makes high-sounding speeches - even today, I think of Dublin - it receives applause, but always the more they sound like the talk of those who cry to the moon The Council of tomorrow and after, in addition to Brexit, should address important issues: the proclamation of the social pillar has placed a lot of emphasis on Gothenburg, but the risk is that it will remain on paper, if it is not accompanied by coherent policies at European level and especially from rules and resources that I don't see yet. Second: immigration and Dublin. While the Libyan horizon risks darkening even more, the Prime Minister declares the European migration policy failed. I do not understand with what credibility the Council will explain to the European citizens and will think about presenting an assessment of its work which seems to me, at present, very, very unsuccessful.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, thank you very much, and thanks to Mr Barnier for having achieved sufficient progress in the negotiations. Now we need to go on further with the aim of a friendly Brexit negotiated with the Government of the United Kingdom, not undermined by the political forces here who are not even represented in the British Parliament. They are not only trying to undermine the negotiations; they are undermining the United Kingdom’s potential in the future.  Second, when the EU gets smaller, we need to get taller; we need to develop new trade relations in order to support not only economic development, but also strengthen a liberal world order. We need to ensure that we can have the strength in developing the European Union, not just by discussing form, but by securing that we have the right policies that can make our Union strong. (Applause)

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: - Madam President! At this point I want to go into the education policy, which deserves much more attention than it has received so far. At the Gothenburg Summit, the Commission kindly proposed the creation of a European Education Area by 2025. Now these well-placed words must be followed by appropriate deeds. With all due respect for the competences of the member states: What speaks against the member states finally agreeing on common, ambitious and binding educational goals and taking the necessary money in hand: for language acquisition, for lifelong learning, for modern key competences including digital skills? The goals must then be evaluated closely. Education is the future, and investing in education is investing in people's future. It is high time we recognized this in our joint political action. The European Parliament and the Commission will work together to create a European Education Area by 2025, and I urge the Member States to do their part to make this project a success.

name: Viviane REDING
text: (PPE). – Madam President, after 18 months of political denial, the UK has finally accepted the three divorce conditions and now everybody knows what Brexit really means. Brexiteers promised GBP 350 million a week to their citizens; instead, they have to pay billions of euro. They promised economic benefits; instead, the pound and British growth are at their lowest point. They promised sovereignty; instead, the government is at the mercy of the DUP at home, and of trade partners abroad. They promised global Britain; instead, they got a lonely Britain. They promised to take back control; instead, they are spinning out of control. I am saddened that the British people have fallen victim to political crooks and that the result is a divided and weakened UK. Fortunately, the European family is united after the Brexit wake-up call and, fortunately, the citizens’ problems found a positive solution in the first part of these negotiations. Thank you, Michel Barnier.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in thanking Timmermans and Barnier, a reflection: Brexit has also been a dramatic opportunity for millions of young people and students from Europe and the UK to rediscover the value and benefits of common European citizenship and the European project. It is therefore important that the EU-UK agreement provides among citizens' rights a specific protection of young people, students and those involved in European programs. The challenge of immigration also requires us to relaunch European solidarity, and the overcoming of Dublin, with Tusk's out of tune voice, but also the opening of legal avenues and new Euro-Mediterranean relations in which young Africans will have to play a leading role . Just as we ask the Council to formally adopt the concrete proposals of the social summit in Gothenburg, in particular, finally also, education and culture to expand the possibility of young Europeans to study in another country, create networks of universities with courses in at least two languages , recognition of diplomas, adoption of my proposal, which has become a proposal of the Parliament, of the European Student Card, and an Erasmus for young artists after 2020, as well as the access of cultural and creative companies to EFSI.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Today, on the threshold of the new year and new plans, is the time for positive energy and optimism. That is why I speak with a full measure of faith in our European Union and with the desire that confidence in it be strengthened among our citizens as well. Above all, they want more Europe in terms of security today - whether physical or economic and social. Ensuring security is increasingly linked to policies in areas that are currently the responsibility of the Member States (social, health, I think). On the other hand, with migration management. Both are the result of a changing demographic picture and finding common European solutions will be crucial in the coming years. We can only feel safe in an environment that respects democratic rules, listens to individuals and is in solidarity. And this is our greatest challenge - to keep the fundamental values ​​alive and to live in accordance with them. And if you, dear leaders, follow this guideline, we will also follow it, so that next year will be good.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I shall try and set a good example. I want to say thank you to Michel Barnier, not from me, but from the people I represent, from those people who live in Donegal, in Louth, in Cavan, in Monaghan, in Leitrim, the counties that border Northern Ireland, but also to the people of Armagh, Fermanagh, Tyrone and Derry, who link up with my constituents socially, from a business point of view, who see no invisible border, and want no visible border. Through his patience and determination, Mr Barnier has secured for them a future of which they were very fearful. Sometimes in this House those who grandstand, arrive and make great speeches, walk out and ignore the realities of what we are talking about here today. What happens will impact on people on the ground, and I hope that going into Christmas we have given them more reassurances, not just around the Ireland issue, but on citizens’ rights and financial commitments. It took your courage and determination, Michel. Have a good Christmas. You did hard work.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, the December Council has a very loaded agenda: the Brexit negotiation, structured cooperation in defense matters, which has been described as "Sleeping Beauty", which would force the agenda to be classified as "Cinderella" social, long delayed in handling the crisis and discussed in Gothenburg, but which is still pending practical achievements in terms of decent employment, social protection and relaunching opportunities for young people, including the Erasmus program, promoted by the remembered Spanish commissioner Manuel Marín, recently deceased. But where the balance of the Council is unacceptable and has to be fundamentally changed is in migration matters, because the Council continues to be contaminated with a negative outlook that links any foreign cooperation, including humanitarian aid, to the return of immigrants, to the which is always seen as a threat. It is necessary to create legal pathways, promote humanitarian visas and humanitarian corridors, particularly in North Africa. And it is the only opportunity to restore the free movement of people in the Schengen acquis, the most precious and precious thing for European citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Council can no longer turn a blind eye to immigration and turn Greece and Italy into repositories of souls. Mr Tusk must realize that his schemes for abolishing mandatory refugee quotas in the European Union will not work. In addition, Dublin III must be abolished and replaced by arrangements that will strengthen solidarity and not turn first-entry states into scapegoats. The structure and functioning of Economic and Monetary Union must change, as it has filled the eurozone with armies of the poor and the unemployed. The European Central Bank must become the ultimate lender. The European Banking System to be decentralized and to allow the recovery of national monetary sovereignty, with the right of the national central banks to cut money up to the percentage of their participation in the share capital of the ECB. In addition, the abolition of the draconian Stability Pact and the strengthening of social Europe are needed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I am missing Mr Farage. I wanted to express my appreciation for the most pro-EU speech he has ever made in this House. I very much appreciate it – in fact, he praised the European Union! Two remarks. First, as concerns Mr Barnier and the negotiations, congratulations. But there is really one issue that I would ask you to take into account, from the EP resolution, and that is the status of citizens because still, from a procedural point of view, there is insecurity for EU citizens. I think it should be pure registration with the burden of proof residing with the United Kingdom. The second remark I would make is on the euro. I really would appreciate it if the summit could take an important step towards better governance in the euro area. You might ask why a Czech is placing such emphasis on this. Well, I would like to show the Czech citizens and Czech politicians for once that they cannot use the excuse of bad governance in the euro area, so we could have a serious debate on the introduction of the euro in the Czech Republic.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Madam President, the Tusk document on refugees is unacceptable, provocative and anti-European. It is not the mandatory quotas that are divisive, but the document itself. Mr Maasikas, I would like to convey to the current President-in-Office of the Council that when I read this text I thought it was Mr Kaczynski or Mr Orban, not the President-in-Office of the Council. The Commission, with the support of Parliament, has taken the matter to the European Court of Justice against European governments for refusing to fulfill their obligations, and it is a disgrace for Europe for the President-in-Office to stab the Commission in the back. The European Parliament and the Commission, Mr Maasikas, expect both the Council and the Summit to do the right thing, because Greece and Italy alone cannot bear the burden of refugees with insufficient European solidarity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the conclusion of the first phase of the Brexit negotiations has confirmed a great truth: that when buffaloes fight in the swamp, frogs pay for it. The frogs in this case are nationals of European Union countries who have studied, live with their families and work in the United Kingdom. Given the facts so far, these people have every reason to worry about whether and to what extent these rights will be secured or not. Of course, we have heard Mr Barnier say today that these rights will be guaranteed for life, but no one can assure them that this will happen. We are concerned that the role of the European Court of Justice has diminished and that is why we do not know whether a future government will abolish or restrict these rights. The European Union must therefore support the rights of these people in an indisputable way. It will be tragic for them to get to the point of asking permission even to stay in their homes.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - Three things, Brexit, I would like to thank Mr Bernier for his excellent leadership of the whole negotiation process, and above all for putting people and their rights and freedoms before the interests of the benefit structures of individual countries and the like.Second, migration, leaders will also touch on this pressing issue.I would like to draw attention in particular to the letter from the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, in which he says that mandatory quotas are not the best solution because they divide the European public, and calls for more encouraging solutions to this problem.And thirdly, PESCO, no European common policy has so far had as much support as the creation of a defense and security union, so I am very happy that the leaders will also touch on this issue.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, yes, I can indeed take note of the optimistic statements by Mr Timmermans on the future of the European Union, but unfortunately the fine and good statements and intentions come up against the budgetary question. How do you put all these new policies in place without additional funding? We cannot accept that the structural policies of the European Union bear the brunt of this. On Brexit, I would like to both congratulate and thank Mr Barnier and all the negotiators for not giving in on the red lines that the European Parliament had set. I understand that there is still a long way to go to translate this first result into legal terms. There is one point that I particularly wonder about: that of the Irish border. I do not yet see how things can turn out and what solution will be adopted in the end. What I wish in any case is that it does not threaten the peace or the future, because I believe that sooner or later, no offense to Mr Farage, the UK will knock on the door again of the European Union.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! It was a really exciting debate today, which heralds a very interesting European Council from tomorrow, because we have all seen how quickly stars are falling in the European Union. All these attacks on the President of the European Council just because he has said a few things that are obvious that the system of forced dislocation is not working shows how easy it is to become an enemy of the European Union. How easy it is to say of someone - just because they say something obvious - that they are denying all integration. By the way, I am surprised by Mr. Tusk's political friends that they are not defending him. Now let's get down to business. Apart from the system of forced dislocation of migrants, which actually does not work, asylum law must remain the domain of states, because, for example, no one has the right to say to an interested state that an activist of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt is a political refugee who should be granted asylum.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, there are undoubted positives that have come out of the phase 1 negotiations when it comes to Ireland. Commitments to no border, regulatory alignment and citizens’ rights are all positive. Your statement, Mr Barnier, that there will be no going back is definitely a positive. But there is one thing that will drive this back, and that is triumphalism on either side. In particular, for people like Manfred Weber, I fear that his dislike of the UK is what drives him rather than his love for Ireland. I think it is love for Ireland that should drive it instead, because this is very important to us. When we talk about ties with Great Britain I don’t think people understand here how important it is. It isn’t about dependence, it is about co-dependence.  I am a Flanagan. My wife is a Kelly. There were 20 members of my mother’s and my wife’s mother’s two families, and 19 out of the 20 went to work in London. Three of my six siblings were born in London. We need each other. We depend on each other. We work together. Manfred remember that with your triumphalism. It doesn’t help.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, I rise to thank the 26 Member States of the European Union, Michel Barnier and his team and all of the institutions for their support for Ireland over the course of this negotiation. This has been a successful negotiation where we have stayed clear and we have come together, and we are stronger together. On the behalf of my constituents in Ireland we thank you for that solidarity and that support.  The clear message from this debate, as demonstrated by Mr Barnier, is that there is no going back on the commitments that have been entered into by the EU and the United Kingdom; no going back on the clear commitments for Ireland; no going back on the clear two other priority issues for EU citizens’ rights and the question of finance. We have a duty now to reposition this debate, to go forward together. We need a new relationship with the United Kingdom based on mutual respect, based on cooperation. Just as Europe has stayed loyal to Ireland, so too will Ireland stay loyal on the question of the integrity of the single market.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the first agreement reached on Brexit confirms that leaving the Union is not such a big deal. The economic crisis of 2008, from which the whole of Europe is still struggling to recover, was the spark to blame the European Union for everything, even for non-specific faults. The economic crisis, but also some inadequacy of the European Union, took advantage of those who, having never played a role of responsibility, were able to make a dissatisfied electorate believe that by regaining its sovereignty, Great Britain could have chosen its own destiny, even in a globalized world. But the facts go in another direction: with his choice, Great Britain took a leap into the unknown, away from any long-term political project. However, the Union is a project that unites, not divides. We have to leave a window open for when the British want to go back. We will realize that this period will have passed when the populists begin to quarrel with each other, as colleague Farage has already started to do with British Prime Minister May.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, I want to say now, on balance, that I think we have results and we must not ignore them. We need to look more at the issues that unite us than at the issues that divide us, but at the same time, I think we need to think about the things that have failed us, and Brexit, the departure of Britain, is something we failed to do. I congratulate the negotiators, both on behalf of Parliament and the Commission. I think they have scored extraordinarily well today that we need to think about this Brexit with the citizen in mind, that there should be no additional burden and that there should be no discrimination against European citizens. I also have fellow citizens there and I think that, institutionally, Great Britain must take over this task. At the same time, I think we need to think about how to do it next year and the Council needs to think about how to increase social cohesion - ultimately our important goal - how we can help European farmers, small businesses, how we can do more. we support the citizens. That is European policy.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, Mr Barnier, I have a very specific question: In Cyprus there are large military zones owned and controlled by Great Britain and inhabited by thousands of European citizens, whether Cypriot European citizens or from other Member States. I would like to know what is the future of these European citizens, what is the status under which they will continue to live and what will be their rights and obligations. But because we will soon have the Sakharov Prize, this gives me an opportunity to refer to a monument of human dignity - and I do not want to diminish those we will award today. From the Turkish prisons a prisoner sends a message that we must all hear is Demirtas, who in a statement concludes with the following: In the Erdogan regime you do not answer questions, because there is no justice in Turkey.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Brexit Negotiator. - Madam President, I will therefore try to be precise and quick at the same time, first to say to all of you who have spoken on issues other than Brexit, whether it is economics, immigration, education, social or economic issues, which I will obviously pass on your remarks to President Juncker and First Vice-President Timmermans, who regrets not being able to be there. Telegraphically, Manfred Weber spoke earlier about the transition. I want to confirm that the only legal basis for a possible transition is Article 50. There is no transition if there is no agreement on Article 50, a withdrawal agreement. I would also like to thank Esteban Gonzáles Pons for using the word "transparency". This is a key to the trust between us, with the Council as well, and we will continue, in conjunction with Guy Verhofstadt and the members of the Parliament's Brexit Steering Group, to practice these permanent confidence dialogues. On Ireland, Seán Kelly, Mairead McGuinness and other parliamentarians recalled the sensitivity of this issue. I will continue to be the negotiator of the Irish government like that of the twenty-six other governments and - if you will - by your side. The unity of the twenty-seven in the past months and for the months to come is very fundamental. I listened with great attention to Mrs in't Veld, Mrs Keller, Mr Kelly, who earlier mentioned the rights of citizens, as Roberto Gualtieri and Guy Verhofstadt also did with many by force. Two points on this question: first free movement, in the future, will be part, Mrs in’t Veld, of the next step in phase two, but I will not forget this question. The very important point on the procedures, which is a sensitive point: we put in the joint report very precise conditions, co-signed by the two parties, and I will endeavor - you can be sure - to ensure that these conditions are reflected in the withdrawal treaty itself, so that these procedures are simple and as less bureaucratic as possible. We are not at the end of this issue and the issue will only be closed in the Withdrawal Agreement. So, from that point of view, the vigilance of the European Parliament is fair and justified. Mr Mavrides, just a word on Cyprus: we will need to find specific solutions to preserve the current situation of the citizens concerned by life around the two military bases in Cyprus. I'm just saying it in passing. Gianni Pittella, Guy Verhostadt and, of course, Elmar Brok spoke about the strength of this joint report. It is serious work that we have done together, methodical, precise. It will be the basis of what we are going to transfer and transcribe into law, through a draft treaty. I say to Guy Verhostadt that my intention is to put on your table, before the end of January, this draft treaty based - for the most part - on the content of this joint report. As Elmar Brok said, it's about trust. The word "trust" is much more than a word, at this stage, between the British and us, because we cannot build a future relationship in matters of defense, security, judicial cooperation, for the university. , for trade obviously, without having confidence. Just one word about the context of these negotiations: they are difficult, and they are tough, very tough, because the issues are extremely complicated and because the consequences of the Brexit are very serious. I personally want to say, in response to a Member of the House of Commons, that Prime Minister Theresa May is courageous and respectable. I certainly respect her. I would like to say now, as Syed Kamall, Gabriele Zimmer and Manfred Weber alluded to the future relationship, that there is, with this agreement on the joint report, a step important thing that is done in the direction of an orderly withdrawal - and that is the condition, this orderly withdrawal -, through a treaty that will be submitted to you, and you will have the final say - to build a future relationship. From this point of view, I would just like to emphasize a point to which we will come back. This is the first time in the history of European trade negotiations - and we will have to build a free trade agreement with the United Kingdom -, that we will have, in a negotiated trade relationship, to work to control the divergence rather than to encourage convergence. We're going to have to get the regulatory divergence under control, to prevent it from becoming a dumping tool against us, rather than encouraging convergence, as we usually do. This is a very important point relating to the way of life, which Manfred Weber mentioned earlier, and also to a level playing field. This is a common thread, Mrs Berès, indeed, that this joint report, in the direction of an agreement, as Danuta Maria Hübner also said very well. Maria João Rodrigues, along with Daniel Caspary and others, spoke about the reforms that Europe needs. President Timmermans spoke about it. I think, I repeat that the future of Europe, which is made up of these reforms, this voluntarism, is much more important than Brexit. That’s also why, I think we had to stabilize this negotiation, so that the energy, your energy and the energy of the Europeans are devoted to this reform agenda. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for your appreciation of our work. I will share this appreciation without any complacency and even less with triumphalism. It’s really not my state of mind. I will share this assessment with my whole team, the Commission services, with the Parliament team, the Council team, who deserve it.If I may conclude in English: Let us keep calm and continue.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for all their comments made during this discussion this morning. I will convey them to the President of the European Council.  One observation from me, though. During the last 18 months we have successfully avoided Brexit negotiations – so skilfully conducted by Michel Barnier – overshadowing the EU’s other daily work for our citizens’, for our businesses’ sake. That is good. And when I hear this discussion this morning in this House, I notice a slight a similarity with a wider topic, that of migration, to be discussed by our leaders later this week. It is clear to everybody that solutions to the migration crisis can only be comprehensive. There can only be European solutions, and this is the spirit of leaders’ discussions this week as is clear from the letter of President Tusk, if you read it in full. So let us not let this one line in President Tusk’s letter overshadow the wide content of leaders’ discussions or prejudge its results. Let it not overshadow all the Union’s achievements in the field of defence, social, education, culture, digital, etc., that will be on the European Council agenda later this week.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, two motions for resolutions.The debate is closed.The vote will take place in a few minutes.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The letter on migration that President Donald Tusk has sent to the Heads of State and Government for discussion at the next European Council is unacceptable. Mr. Tusk seems to show that there are hearts that do not feel even if they see human suffering live. He is not listening either, because he has not listened to this Parliament, nor is he listening to the efforts that the Commission is making. The European Council seems to insist on a proven wrong path on migration and refuge, which consists in moving away, in making larger borders, in preventing more and more urgently the legal routes for migration. A proven wrong path. This is what President Tusk presents in his letter. The proposal is anti-European because it breaks one of the main pillars of the European project: solidarity. In this way, the President of the European Council is liquidating the prestige of the European Union and its values. It should come as no surprise to us that anti-European populisms are winning the battle.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - Progress in the first phase was not achieved until last week, after many rounds of negotiations. The British side has finally shown its willingness in the future to guarantee the rights of EU citizens living on its territory, as well as their family members. The same guarantees will apply to the British in EU countries. Such a non-discriminatory approach was one of the conditions for moving the negotiations to the second phase. Others concerned, in particular, the border with Ireland and the financial commitments of the United Kingdom, which, despite its departure, will have to be fulfilled really rigorously. The final transition to the second phase of talks should be agreed at the end of this week by the leaders of the Member States at the Brussels European Council. It is essential that British politicians continue to play heroes in the future and avoid arrogant proposals to punish European citizens on their territory and make them second-class people.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The letter on migration that President Donald Tusk has sent to the Heads of State and Government for discussion at the next European Council is unacceptable. Mr. Tusk seems to show that there are hearts that do not feel even if they see human suffering live. He is not listening either, because he has not listened to this Parliament, nor is he listening to the efforts that the Commission is making. The European Council seems to insist on a proven wrong path on migration and refuge, which consists in moving away, in making larger borders, in preventing more and more urgently the legal routes for migration. A proven wrong path. This is what President Tusk presents in his letter. The proposal is anti-European because it breaks one of the main pillars of the European project: solidarity. In this way, the President of the European Council is liquidating the prestige of the European Union and its values. It should come as no surprise to us that anti-European populisms are winning the battle.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the motion for a resolution.Progress has been made in recent weeks on what we consider to be the most important issues relating to the situation of European citizens, the Irish-Irish border and the question of financial commitments.The task now is to adhere to these agreements and not to demolish the basis of trust for the negotiations that will now follow on the future relationship between the EU and the United Kingdom.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: written. –I have received many reports in recent months from both British citizens living on the mainland and Europeans living in the United Kingdom. It often concerns families with multiple nationalities. It is no coincidence that four of the five points in the resolution now before us concern the rights of citizens. Although May has said that the rights of both groups will remain the same after the UK leaves the EU, I understand their concerns. After all, there are no hard guarantees yet. But my worries don't stop there. After all, what about the social rights of our citizens, for example? This topic seems to be being overlooked, but with the recently announced social pillar it is all the more important. This pillar has also been signed on behalf of the UK. It cannot be that the outcome of the negotiations means that social protection, in both the UK and the European Union, is being eroded. In fact, competition in social protection is simply unacceptable.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Jean Claude Juncker recently announced that the European Union would provide significant resources to help Member States wishing to adopt the euro. Of course, this also requires a common currency. The current EU initiative is a historic opportunity for Hungary. Europe would give money to modernize the Hungarian economy and bring the standard of living at home closer to the West. We could have access to additional EU funds and the Hungarian economy would be protected by the full firepower of the eurozone. All this for free, not with our sweat. All it takes is one thing: a commitment to the euro. Seven of the 10 Member States that joined in 2004 have already adopted the euro, and the rest are planning to do so, and Bulgarians and Czechs have recently applied for observer status. However, the current Hungarian government does not plan to introduce a common currency. This is a serious mistake. And the introduction of the euro would only bring benefits. The euro would reduce public debt and eliminate exchange rate risk, which would help foreign currency borrowers. With the introduction of the euro, Hungarian savings would be protected by the EU, not by the weak Hungarian deposit fund, which is also struggling to bankrupt a small rural savings cooperative. If there were a euro, Hungarians could receive EU unemployment benefits within years. The introduction of the euro is in the interest of the Hungarian people. Now we even get money for it. Not to be missed.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. - I note with great concern the processes that have recently begun in the European Council. While the Commission and Parliament are making significant efforts to establish a common European asylum system in line with current challenges, the European Council appears to continue to be characterized by day-to-day political considerations and cheap tactics. In the long run, the citizens of Europe will be the losers of this irresponsible delay and the far-right parties will be the winners. I am particularly concerned about President Tusk's recent statement questioning the essential elements of a common European asylum policy. It is a serious mistake for the European Council or its President to allow the extortion of some governments led by far-right adventurers and to turn their backs on the core values ​​of the European Union. Concessions to politicians who unscrupulously incite politicians to gain political gain do not create unity but, on the contrary, undermine the moral and legal foundations of unity in the European Union. Further procrastination, the denial of the principle of solidarity, the search for unprincipled compromises, the subsequent questioning of legitimate decisions will only lead to confusion and a weakening of confidence in the European institutions. The citizens of Europe expect the EU institutions to find a solution to the problems and firmly reject the demagoguery that undermines European values.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written.- We were able to take away a few important key points from the first round of negotiations.But I expect even more precision of the most important cornerstones: the rights of EU citizens in the UK and vice versa, the assumption of the costs of Brexit and the Northern Irish border.Furthermore, everything must be done to prevent the UK from profiling itself as a financial arena with tax goodies after Brexit and becoming a new tax haven.The fact is that the UK will continue to be a strong economic partner to the European Union.What exactly this partnership will look like has yet to be clarified in the next round of negotiations.The EU member states and we in the EU Parliament must continue to take our position firmly and firmly.One thing is clear: the focus is on people, for whom we have to create a clear legal framework and fair conditions.Its a lot to do!

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - I particularly welcome the fact that the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, has also publicly stated that mandatory quotas for migrants have proved ineffective and impracticable in practice. We must work together to find other solutions that are based on compliance with existing rules. Equally important is strict border protection, in which all Member States must be involved. The strengthening of European security is closely related to the PESCO strategy, in which Slovakia joined. As PESCO envisages a partial unification of the equipment of the armed forces of the member states, it is not clear to me why the Slovak Republic is going to extend the life of Russian supersonic Mig-29 fighter aircraft, instead of buying new machines. Robert dichico and the Minister of Defense should explain this dichotomy to our partner. In preparing the Brexit negotiations, the governments of the Member States will finally be able to rely on a concrete proposal from the British side. I expect the opinion of the European Council to be the same as that of the European Parliament, meaning that the priority is to preserve the rights of our citizens living in the United Kingdom.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - The current agenda for our plenary debate also reflects the fact that this week's EU Heads of State and Government should once again be devoted mainly to reconciling EU interests and negotiating positions in the Brexit negotiations. On each such occasion, I think it is important to recall that the situation, which is unnecessarily hampering European construction and detrimental to all actors, was caused by the irresponsible political tactics of a British right-wing government and anti-European, populist, nationalist demagoguery. I think we need to keep this in mind throughout the negotiation process as an important lesson, while the British side is working to tackle the problem it is causing itself and the EU negotiators are working to limit the damage done to European citizens. In this situation, I welcome in itself the fact that, at this stage of the negotiations, there is finally a consensus in principle on the way forward on three essential framework conditions. The European Parliament will have a key role to play in ensuring that these agreements are fully and in good faith transposed into the future final agreement and that the civil and social rights of our citizens, whether living and working in the Member States or the British Isles, are fully respected during the agreed transition period and even after Brexit. As a Hungarian Member, I pay particular attention to the fact that, unfortunately, many of my compatriots concerned - most of whom are seeking refuge in Britain from the economic constraints and political constraints of the authoritarian Orbán regime - and their families should not suffer further legal disadvantages.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - This time, the next round of negotiations between the European Commission and Great Britain was successful, moderately and late, but it's good that this year. The Commission said that "sufficient progress" has been made and in today's resolution the European Parliament recommends the Council to move to the second phase of talks on a future partnership agreement. The EP resolution highlights a number of aspects that should be addressed in the second round of negotiations, mainly concerning civil rights and the future trade agreement, but also future cooperation on foreign and security policy. From the point of view of the group that monitors negotiations in the field of culture, which I chair, the participation of the United Kingdom in the EU's flagship program Erasmus + is also important. The UK welcomes 200,000 students from EU Member States annually, which accounts for 28% of all exchange students and is the most frequently chosen course of study. In addition, students who start their studies before the UK's departure date must be sure that they will be able to complete the course on the same terms as they started, and that they will still have access to financial support under the same conditions. Another, especially important as it concerns thousands of young people, is the issue of recognition of education. Students must be sure that their qualifications will be recognized both in the EU and in the UK.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - The best development for negotiations between the European Union (EU) and the United Kingdom (UK) would be that which could lead to the UK remaining in the EU. There is, however, a democratic mandate by the British electorate to negotiate the exit, which must be respected as long as this is the express will of that electorate or whoever represents it. In this context, the European Parliament's joint resolution on the negotiation process for the withdrawal of the UK from the EU, affirms a sensible line of negotiation, defends the interests of the EU and the rights of its citizens in the process of withdrawal and moves forward general lines of a reference for future cooperation that can minimize the damage of the exit and preserve a good relationship between the peoples. The resolution under discussion therefore constitutes a good compromise text, which reiterates the red lines defined for negotiation defined by the European Parliament, identifies points to be safeguarded in the negotiation process in the field of rights, the issue of Ireland and financial compensation and delimits the future potential framework for association between the EU and the UK as a country outside the Union.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: representative of the democratic opposition of Venezuela awarded with the Sakharov Prize 2017. - Mr. President of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani, honorable members of the European Parliament, respected assistants and guests, delegation from Venezuela that accompanies us to receive this award today, girlfriends and friends. Undoubtedly, it is not easy to speak when your lips are as close to your heart as at this moment, but I want to convey to all of you that, since some sailors arrived on American soil centuries ago, Europe and Venezuela have had a one-way relationship. back. Although some try to change history, we have been twinned ever since. Today we Venezuelans have to thank Europe, you! They have extended a helping hand in what, without a doubt, are the darkest hours of our republican history as a nation. That is the same hand that we Venezuelans offered in the 20th century to thousands and thousands of Europeans who emigrated with the scars of war on their souls and bodies. Among them, my own parents and my grandparents. Some have returned to their places of origin, expelled by the devastating effects of the so-called "21st century socialism" that has been tried to establish in my country. And sadly, young Venezuelans have also left their land behind in the hope of finding in Europe, and in other corners of the world, the future and the opportunity that the Government of Venezuela has taken from them. This round trip, this common history between America and Europe has brought us here. Today the European Parliament recognizes the brave and tireless struggle of the opposition of the Venezuelan people by awarding the Sakharov Prize to the opposition democratically represented in the National Assembly - which I have the honor to preside over - and to all the political prisoners in my country.
