I would like, please, that we give applause to those who accompany us: Antonieta and Leopoldo López, my parents personal friend Leopoldo López; Antonio Ledezma, who had to flee from Venezuela, from the unjust prison to which he was subjected; Patricia de Ceballos, wife of Daniel Ceballos, who has been deprived of liberty for almost four years; in addition to the relatives and representatives of Lorent Saleh, his mother, Yamile; José Ignacio Guédez, representative of Mayor Alfredo Ramos, and Alejandra González, sister of Andrea González, imprisoned for three years and also a Spanish citizen; likewise, to Yon Goicoechea and the thousands and thousands of exiles from Venezuela. (Applause) We receive this award with deep appreciation. It is welcomed by the whole country. Venezuela makes it his whole and united. It is a recognition for the mother who deprives herself of food to save her children; for the child who rummages through the garbage trying to satisfy hunger; for the grandfather who dies of decline due to the shortage of medicines. It is also received by that young man who today has emigrated desperate to seek opportunities in other latitudes. This award is also received by the teacher who overcomes ideological blindness and clings to the task of forming free men and women for Venezuela. It is received by those who fight for human rights in Venezuela. It is received by Venezuelan journalists, who risk their entire lives to show the reality that seeks to be silenced. This distinction also goes through the bars of the dungeons in which more than three hundred and fifty young Venezuelans are unjustly detained. They and their struggle are also recognized and are present with us today. (Applause) But, in a special way, the Sakharov Prize honors the memory of one hundred and fifty-seven Venezuelans killed by the brutal repression of the government during the peaceful protests that we carried out during this year 2017. When Andrei Sakharov was recognized with the Nobel Prize of the Paz in 1975 could not receive it personally. He was standing outside a Lithuanian court, awaiting the unjust sentence that would mark the life of his friend, the scientist Serghey Kovalyev. In the Nobel Prize acceptance speech, which his wife read, were the names of more than a hundred political prisoners and exiles. His wife apologized for the ones she didn't remember, but she assured something important. She said: "Each name, mentioned or not, represents a concrete, hard and heroic human destiny, of years of suffering, years of struggle for human dignity." These words, without a doubt, today stir the soul of every Venezuelan and summarize the persistence of the struggle that we have and will have until we achieve democratic victory in the country. (Applause) I am convinced that our noble challenge is not alien to Europe. To you, honorable MEPs, the fight we are waging in Venezuela against domination and fear is not strange. In the 21st century, we Venezuelans resist and face a totalitarian state, a second Cuba but with the largest oil, gas and gold reserves in the West. I can assure you that we, like you decades ago, are determined to persist and overcome that perverse pretense of colonizing the conscience of every Venezuelan. The regime has hijacked democracy in my country. He established hunger to administer misery. Destroyed the healthcare system to manage death. He expropriated thousands of companies to spread misery. He indoctrinated the classrooms to offer ignorance. Unlike social democracy, the socialism of the 21st century is a renewed version and just as traumatic as the real socialism that you suffered for decades. And although it is doomed to failure, it has become the greatest obstacle to peace, progress and human rights in Venezuela. (Applause) The imposition of this system on our nation has caused unprecedented destruction and misery. Please listen carefully to the following. After having experienced the biggest oil bonanza in its history in recent years, The Venezuelan economy has just entered a traumatic process of hyperinflation: this year the cost of food will reach 2,000%. In other words, in Venezuela it is enough that a few hours pass to register the inflation that the European countries accumulate in several years. Hunger was established as a political system in Venezuela. 75% of Venezuelans have lost ten kilos, per person, in recent months and, as if that were not enough, official studies show that four out of ten children suffer from some type of malnutrition. Death also progresses in pharmacies: out of every ten medicines, nine are not available and people with chronic diseases are sentenced to death. The tragedy is obvious and painful. Only the pride of those who conceive power as a form of domination ignores this reality and underestimates it, to the point of closing the doors to many countries like you, who have generously offered us relief. Today I want to reiterate it in front of Europe: the opening of humanitarian cooperation for food and medicine is urgent for Venezuela. It is a requirement that cries out to heaven and that we have presented in all national and international instances. And, in an incredible way, the Government of Nicolás Maduro refuses to cooperate with medicines and food for the people. Sooner rather than later the long struggle for dignity referred to by Sakharov will bear fruit and allow us to regain freedom. We also cling to what our Rómulo Gallegos, great libertarian and president of Venezuela, said. "Evil is temporary," said Gallegos, "but truth and justice always reign." Far from what those who want to dominate us want, those of us here and those of us in Venezuela suffering are not full of hatred. And for this reason, I want to share with you what I consider one of our great triumphs: we do not hold a grudge against those who have done so much damage to Venezuela. Almost daily they push us to hate them, but they have not managed to do it and we will not do it. But neither will we lose hope nor will we stop fighting until we see a free Venezuela and of all Venezuelans. (Applause) The situation in our Venezuela is difficult. We are urged to carry out a political change towards democracy to face this terrible humanitarian crisis created by the regime that I have just described. We have not stopped raising our voices despite the distorting effect of censorship and propaganda. We stand firm in all spaces and on all possible terrain. That is why we turn to the international community, to you, to the free world, to invoke the principles of international social justice and find ways that contribute to the democratic rescue of my country. That is why we fight in the streets, in the Assembly, in the international arena, peacefully protesting to recover democracy in Venezuela. In our memory the images of the brutal repression that the State security forces deployed against unarmed citizens are still clear. Many of them young, who are in prison today and who are not over twenty years old. The arms of the Republic were dedicated to mourning one hundred and fifty-seven Venezuelan households. These weapons should not be used to resolve what we can resolve through word and vote, which is the vehicle for millions of Venezuelans to express themselves. The vote cast in freedom is a declaration of independence. Therefore, we are obliged to rescue him. In the coming months there should be a presidential election in Venezuela and we ask Europe and the free world to put all their attention on these elections. We are challenged to regain electoral conditions that allow Venezuelans to express themselves freely at the polls, without blackmail, without pressure of any kind, without repression, and that their will is respected. It is a fight that summons us all and demands the best of all of us. Therefore, we take with I am happy with the words of President Antonio Tajani and we formally ask that an electoral mission of the European Parliament accompany these elections that must take place in Venezuela, so that they are free elections and there can be a democratic transition in my country. Honorable MEPs, these are difficult times, but we look to the future with hope. I long for the moment when the cells will be opened, the exiles return and all Venezuelans embrace each other, we cry with joy and work together so that the Constitution is respected, we have the rule of law and a democracy full of opportunities. Friends of Europe, Christmas is approaching and many Venezuelan households will receive the Savior in the midst of serious material shortages, with nothing to eat. Surely, with the same humility, faith and love that Mary Most Holy and her husband Saint Joseph did so more than two thousand years ago in Bethlehem. On behalf of them, of those who suffer the most, of those who deserve a future of opportunities in Venezuela, I humbly welcome this award, which has been conferred on our indomitable love for peace, democracy, justice, progress and human rights. . On behalf of the Venezuelan people, many thanks to all of you! (Applause)

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: representative of the democratic opposition of Venezuela awarded the Sakharov Prize 2017. - Mr. President Tajani, honorable members of the European Parliament. I should be standing tall on this rostrum before you with a smile on my face, but I don't even have the strength to simulate it and, paraphrasing Sakharov, I repeat like him the words spoken by the lips of his devoted and unconditional wife when, at the moment of Receiving the Nobel Prize in 1965 - as our colleague Julio Borges reminded us - she said, on behalf of her husband, "that she could not be content and happy receiving that award knowing that there were prisoners of conscience in her homeland." Well, I cannot be happy or content receiving this award knowing that in the dungeons of Venezuela more than three hundred political prisoners remain unjustly deprived of their freedom. Sakharov, you who are spiritually present in this sacred place, allow me to greet you and thank you on behalf of humanity for your life dedicated to the defense of peace, progress and human rights of the beings that populate this earth and ratify, in the name of of the Venezuelan citizens who today, of course, proudly decked out with this distinction, that we receive it with the humility that has characterized our people, but also with the gallantry and courage that it has put on the showcase of our country as an example of the people in whose name we receive this laurel fight tenaciously. We want to turn this award into flowers. May we turn this trophy into flowers to take to Franklin Brito's grave. A man whose last days he lived in a cot, where he died starring in a hunger strike, defending the land that had been usurped. And in the face and in the face and in the name of Franklin Brito I see the peasants, the farmers, the Venezuelan ranchers who have suffered the attacks of authoritarianism because their farms, their farms, their property have been over and over again invaded. We turn this trophy into flowers to take to the graves of more than 350,000 Venezuelans whose homes are in mourning. Venezuelans like those who last year, more than 29,000 citizens, lost their lives at the hands of the underworld in a country where the rule of law has disappeared and the rule of law does not work but the whim of rulers who have pulverized the rules of the game designed to guarantee coexistence in a society with a democratic spirit such as Venezuela. This award will be in the tombs of the young squires who, as Julio said, shed their blood in the streets of Caracas and all the towns of the country to draw our sentimental map. Young people who did not reach twenty years of age; who fought for a democracy they never got to know. For these young people I invoke in this room a posthumous prayer as a tribute to those who knew how to defend the ideals that were not agreed upon and who did not play with the conscience of a people that today proudly receives this laurel to continue fighting for Venezuelan freedom and democracy was chair for Latin America. (Applause) This is a tribute to the children in Venezuela who are dying of hunger. This is a tribute to human beings who have ceased to exist simply because they don't have a medicine on hand. And this happens in an immensely rich country. Julio Borges has spoken of the thriving Venezuela in whose entrails is the largest oil reserve in the world. But it turns out that a country whose government has administered more than 1.5 billion dollars in recent years, an amount ten times higher than the budget allocated to the European Union, today exhibits - as we saw in the images that were projected a few minutes ago - human beings rummaging through garbage in order to survive. It is a people that fights for its survival. And in order to be free we have to have freedom. And it is the voice of those political prisoners on whose behalf Leopoldo López sent me this phrase or this thought that I want to share with you. Leopoldo says: «Freedom for those who live in healthy democracies is often an abstract. For those of us who lack it, it is as vital as oxygen. We ask Europe to remain firm in its commitment to achieve the freedom of more than three hundred prisoners and thirty million Venezuelans who today do not breathe freedom. (Applause) This is the reflection of all political prisoners. It is the reflection of a people that wants to resolve their difficulties through civic and democratic means. That is why we proposed a constitutional referendum last year. A civic, democratic, legal path to settle our differences. We are not looking for God in the corners. We are not stoking the fire in the barracks or the garrisons. Because, unlike those who today illegally hold power in Venezuela, who rule with guns or bayonets, trampling on the Constitution and the laws of the Republic, we want peace. Here we do not come to seek revenge but justice. Here we come free of hatred and resentment, because those are feelings that make the spirit sick and pervert the soul. We want Venezuela to regain its freedom and coexistence. And we wanted to propose electoral paths that the same regime closes, because Venezuela is in the hands, and I say this with regret, of criminals who have turned our State into a failed State. We are ashamed that today Venezuela is being talked about because there are high-level officials who are related to drug trafficking. And the Vienna office that controls narcotics operations in this continent has said it: that more than 60% of the cocaine that enters Europe comes from Venezuelan territory. And those who are not related to drug trafficking have links to international terrorism. And those that are not related to terrorism or drug trafficking they are filled with scandals or acts of corruption. More than 600 billion dollars that have been stolen from the public finances are deposited in tax havens around the world. And that is the paradox of an immensely rich country, with a people suffering within and with a pilgrimage of more than two million citizens of Venezuela who today suffer the pain of an absent homeland between their chests and backs. Therefore, friends, this award reinforces us. This award gives us more energy to continue fighting for the values ​​and principles of democracy that you share. To tell the world that peoples never again suffer from dictatorships. Let there never be talk of torture or political prisoners in towns that have dressed up as democracy. Never again speak of emotional divisions or fractures. May we open the way to harmony. And with the words of the Galician teacher I say goodbye saying to you: "Today more than ever we are convinced that the more one belongs to oneself the more one has his will and his whole life at the service of a collective ideal." Long live Venezuela! Long live democracy! Long live the freedom of the world! (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I take the floor to deplore the fact that the Communist group did not participate in the ceremony.This disrespect for human rights is a shame.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I wonder whether you would join me in sending congratulations and good wishes to the new Somaliland President, who will be sworn into office tomorrow. I think we should also send congratulations to the opposition party both for the manner in which the election campaign was conducted, and for the peaceful aftermath and transition. Once again, Somaliland has demonstrated to the world its commitment to democracy and the rule of law, and surely now deserves to be admitted as a fully-fledged recognised state.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before the vote, I would like to express my concern for the researcher and professor of the Free University of Brussels, Ahmadreza Djalali, who was sentenced to death by the Iranian authorities on charges of espionage.My letter to President Rouhani, in which I asked for Djalali's release and due process, has so far been unanswered.Now there is a serious risk that Djalali could be executed.I renew on behalf of all of you, I believe, my appeal to the Tehran authorities not to carry out the sentence.On behalf of Parliament I express the strongest condemnation of the death penalty in any circumstance contrary to the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to recall the terrible situation that my region of Emilia Romagna is going through at the moment due to bad weather.The flooding of rivers is affecting all of Europe and certainly this time too Parliament will be close to the many affected areas and to the populations that are suffering the causes of bad weather.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, I join, not only as an Italian, but also as President of Parliament, in your concern, in your closeness to all the European populations affected in recent weeks by bad weather.Last week the last king of Romania passed away, Michael I, and I want to remember his fundamental role in 1944 to bring his country to the allied camp, so I want to express our closeness to the Romanian people and parliament for the disappearance.of this figure who represents an important part of the history of Romania and of our continent.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to inform the House that I went to Ankara last week to attend the trial of the two HDP co-chairs and that a delegation made up of several national parliamentarians, as well as one European parliamentarian,access to the courtroom was denied by the Turkish police.I believe that this must be taken into consideration by the House when the relations between the European Union and Turkey are discussed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you for the information, Mr Forenza, you know how sensitive this House is to the problems linked to the defense of democracy and freedom in all countries, but especially in Turkey as well.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I just want to thank all of my colleagues in this Parliament. We are now reaching a milestone in the fight against money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance with the adoption of these recommendations against these phenomena. I want to thank my co-rapporteur Petr Ježek and the rest of the Committee of Inquiry into Money laundering, Tax avoidance and Tax evasion for one and a half years’ hard work on this issue.  We have a chance now to see whether it is not only talk but also action in the fight against tax evasion and money laundering. We need to put an end to the race to the bottom on corporate taxation and regulation in Europe. We need to put an end to the situation where the super rich, global corrupt elite are above the tax law and above the law as such.  This is a chance in this Parliament to show that we are on the side of the citizens, and I hope you will all vote for these recommendations and give a strong signal to Europe and to the rest of the world.  (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: - Mister President!I would like to point out that during the check you carried out earlier on Paragraph 45, Motion 6 was initially displayed on the screen and only afterwards 45. I do not want to call up the vote again now, but with such close votes it should be displayed very carefullybe what is voted on.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I understand that this is a request to our service technicians.There was, for two seconds, I found out from the secretariat, different information, so we kindly ask you to actually keep it longer.- After voting on para.139:

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, with all due respect to your proceedings, I would like to ask you: could it not be speeded up a little, please?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'll domybest.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the explanations of vote.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, yesterday a spokesman for the European Commission said that the phase one agreement between the UK and the rest of the European Union was not legally binding. It was, as he put it, a gentleman’s agreement. But when the UK’s Brexit Secretary, David Davis, said exactly the same thing, this House exploded in one of those moments of gibbering rage that we occasionally get, even putting an attack on him into the resolution on which we have just voted.  It is a pity because we ought to be approaching these talks in a spirit of seeking mutually beneficial outcomes. You rarely hear a speech by the British Prime Minister in which she does not look forward to a warm and close partnership with the EU and wish our neighbours every success. That is, of course, a great interest of ours. We want the EU 27 to be stable and prosperous, but it would be a very sad thing if that lack of reciprocal goodwill were to lead to a suboptimal outcome. Your prosperity will matter to the UK in all situations. We want to have wealthy customers next door. Presumably the same logic applies both ways round.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I welcome the results of the negotiations on Brexit, simply because we need clarity on this. However, we still don’t know what it means. Will the commitments made on Northern Ireland be upheld in practice? Will Northern Ireland become collateral damage in the Brexit negotiations? Will my son be able to reside, educate himself and get a good career in the UK if he marries somebody from Northern Ireland? The signals from the British Government have been clearly confusing. Mr Davis said yesterday that the agreement is not a legally enforceable thing. Sorry, but what does that mean? We need time to stop this confusion: the UK Government must stick to its commitments and translate them into legally binding text. We are worried about peace in Northern Ireland and that must be valued higher than the internal power struggle in the British Government.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, I did not support this report, I abstained and I will explain why. It is not just that the European Parliament is addressing this issue for the second time in a short time, and I find it a bit superfluous. But from a number of those amendments, I feel that they are still not driven by the good will of helping things, but rather by the bad will of complicating things. I say this with full responsibility as a member of this church. I really think that in some cases, ideology is winning here over a sensible approach, over a factual approach. After all, it started with the nomination of Mr Verhofstadt as the chief negotiator for the European Parliament, because he is a person who is certainly not politically neutral. I am very afraid that, in the final stages of this negotiation, the European Parliament's attempts will be pouring sand into it, as we say in the Czech Republic. I warn against this and I really cannot support reports of this type.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, it is extremely important to build a stable relationship with the United Kingdom quickly, at a time when the country is no longer a member of the European Union. This is in the interest of all European citizens, including Bulgarians living in the UK. An agreement on future relations and its smooth entry into force on 30 March 2019 is urgently needed. 2019 and 2020, is a positive sign. This reassures European citizens, including European producers and farmers, that there will be no interruption and turmoil in the commitments and payments already made under this multiannual financial framework. Without an agreement, a number of European manufacturing sectors will feel strong economic pressure stemming from both international import quota agreements with the European Union and domestic overproduction and commodities planned for the UK, for which they will have to seek new markets within the European Union. .

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this report.I think it is right that the European Parliament is constantly addressing the issue of Brexit, because we are a key body in deciding on the final arrangement of relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom.I am one of those who promote pragmatism in negotiating future relations with the United Kingdom and removing ideological labels and personal antipathies.I am glad that it seems that the first phase of Brexit is perhaps agreed, that is, things that concerned the citizens of the European Union in Great Britain and the commitments of Great Britain to the European Union.Now is the time to address our future relationships.Personally, I support the best possible cooperation, because in my opinion it is beneficial for European trade.I am from the Czech Republic, it is important for Czech business to export further to the United Kingdom and I would not personally support any obstacles.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, I welcome the EU-UK deal as a good basis to move ahead. As the clock is ticking, it is important to break the deadlock. Congratulations and full support to the EU negotiator Michel Barnier. An agreement is an agreement. The commitment must now be cast in stone, but polarisation and lack of clarity in the UK is hampering the process. We need to know what Downing Street wants.  It is most important that EU citizens’ right to live, study, work and unite with their families in the UK must be turned into law after Brexit. I also fully support Irish people in ensuring continued free movement between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. I just do not see how to avoid a hard border when the UK leaves the single market. The Treaty principles are non-negotiable. The internal market with its freedom is indivisible. The time has come to tell the truth about the consequences of leaving the single market. Even the best free-trade agreement is a setback compared to single market benefits. There is no soft Brexit, and I conclude: only damage control. Now negotiations should proceed with calm, focusing on the long-term interests of the people of the UK and of the EU.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, it is rather with more relief than pleasure that we can say sufficient progress has been made on the Brexit negotiations. I fully supported this resolution, because it means we can move forward and in the new year we will face discussions on the transition phase and on a future partnership with the United Kingdom.  As has been said here in this House, we all want a good relationship going into the future with our UK neighbours and partners, but I will repeat my concerns around the ultimate solution to the Irish border question. Today, the United Kingdom is part of the single market and customs union and the situation on the border is invisible, as we want it to continue. It would be the best solution to the conundrum if the United Kingdom would remain in the single market and the customs union, although we know that if that is not the case they will still have to come forward with very unique solutions to solve this conundrum.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President!Unfortunately, with my vote, I did not support the adoption of the report assessing the state of play of the Brexit negotiations and setting out Parliament's current position on EU positions.I always consider the starting point for judging the issue of Brexit to be that this situation, which is unnecessarily hampering the construction of Europe and is detrimental to all actors, was caused by the irresponsible political tactics of a British right-wing government.In this situation, I welcome in itself the fact that, according to the report, the agreement in principle needed to move forward, three essential framework conditions, has been reached by the end of this stage of the negotiations.So with regard to the mutual status of citizens, the financial settlement and the Northern Ireland border, and this is awaiting the approval of the next European Council.However, in the absence of concretes, a sufficient number of concretes, I do not consider all this to be sufficient.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I supported the resolution today and I was happy to do so. I am pleased that we have reached a point where we can now say, as a Parliament, that sufficient progress has been made in Phase 1 and we can move on to Phase 2. I want to thank Michel Barnier in particular and his team, and Mr Verhofstadt and his team here in the Parliament, for their particular attention to the Irish question, the Good Friday Agreement, the need to ensure that no border would be put in place on the island of Ireland. That was very important and the efforts that they made to understand that issue are to be commended and are well-recognised where I come from; we thank them for that. What has been stated now is that the status quo will remain on the island of Ireland, that the freedom of the movement that is there between two communities will continue, that trade will continue unimpeded, and that this is very important and will remain for the future agreement, whatever that may be, between the United Kingdom and the European Union.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, after six months of negotiations, the British have finally put their signature to something that recognises that different arrangements need to be put in place for the north of Ireland – a form of special status, if you like – but they are already going back on it. I am pleased that this resolution calls them out on that, but we need to be very vigilant – that is the European Parliament, the EU negotiators and the Irish Government. We all need to make sure that there is no going back on the commitments of last week’s communiqué.  The north of our country cannot be pushed back or placed under the yoke of British self—interest once more. This resolution gives us the means to ensure that this does not happen. It gives us the means to protect the Good Friday Agreement, including trade and open borders, as well as rights and equality. We are not there yet; we have not achieved the full outworkings of ensuring that all of Ireland remains together within all the EU frameworks yet. The agreement provides the scope to achieve that. We must redouble our efforts if we are going to get to that essential position.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we have hours14.38 and 49 seconds, atAt 14.45 we will have to make the room available.I am sorry to say this, but unfortunately I will not be able to allow the speakers on the second point.We just don't have enough time.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the only sure thing about the UK's exit negotiations and the context of both future relations is that international politics is cynically and unbalanced beyond the real needs and challenges of the people but instead proposing it. selfish benefit of some states. Especially on budget issues, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark are well aware of this, as they reduce their net contributions with ad hoc agreements beyond those in force. The crossroads are obvious: the Union will either continue the current punitive measures with arbitrary and unilateral criteria until it is completely degenerated or will apply the conditions for proportional assistance to the Member States in the context of cooperation and solidarity. I am voting against the motion for a resolution, as it highlights the Union's problems and existential concerns in the choices the UK is called upon to manage, ignoring the paradox of undermining the sovereign decisions of a democratically elected government by appointed technocrats.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir.Chairman!I think it is becoming increasingly clear that, for the EU, Brexit is in fact a welcome opportunity to focus on something other than all the institutional problems that the EU itself has: with the unguarded border, with illegal immigration,with the euro not working and the consequent economic recession, especially in southern Europe.All the problems that until Brexit occupied the Europeans, who today most of all look at the negotiations between the EU and Britain.But there is reason to remind the Commission and everyone else here that Brexit will soon be a reality.Britain should probably manage.We are talking about one of the most centrally located and historically strongest countries in world history.The big question is how the EU will cope when the haze eases and it still has all the problems that are currently hidden from the negotiations, but which the citizens are worried about.It will be the moment of truth for the EU.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Over 3 million EU citizens living in the UK followed with great interest and concern the negotiations between the European Commission and the UK over their rights and the rights of their family members after Brexit. It seems that progress has been made in this regard, but the citizens of the Union still feel threatened. Unfortunately, the UK authorities seem to be cautious about the agreement, so the European Parliament must make it clear that respecting all agreements is essential. The citizens of the Union should retain all their rights and this fact should be protected by the European Court of Justice. In the resolution, the European Parliament calls on the UK to ensure that acquired rights apply not only to EU citizens already living in the UK and their current partners, but also to the future. It is very important that there is a free declaration procedure for European Union citizens who wish to claim their rights, for example one common form for the whole family. These are necessary conditions, and I therefore supported Parliament's resolution on this with great conviction.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I voted for the resolution on the Brexit negotiations with a heavy heart, in the knowledge that it is the wrong solution for the United Kingdom. But the question before this House is whether or not the negotiations have made sufficient progress, and unlike October – when there was no joint agreement to vote on – it is clear that progress has been made, but sufficient progress means just that: not a conclusion.  While I welcome what has been achieved on citizens’ rights, not least for the unborn grandchildren that I may have, who won’t be English or German or Scottish or Irish or even Geordie or Schwaben in their identity; they will be European. We have made a start for those people, but there is much more to be done. And to those who write to me constantly on this issue, I say: don’t give up. Lobby your MPs at Westminster, and make sure that you have a meaningful vote and they have a meaningful vote on the final deal.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I supported this resolution. I must say that I perceived the decision of the British electorate as very unfortunate for the future of our common continent. However, it must be respected. It is important to me that the European Parliament has repeatedly addressed this situation. We must let us know what the position of the European Parliament is, because it is unrevocable at the end of the process. So, unlike my esteemed colleague, Mr Zahradil, I think it is important that we deal with this intensively. For this reason, I also welcome the agreement that has been made, because it provides at least some basis for the uncertainty in which we have found ourselves so far. In fact, those who did not vote in favor of the report contribute to some uncertainty to some extent. I did not want to join this crowd, which is why I supported it, even though I also did not like something about the parameters of the agreement. But if we don't reach a final agreement, it will be a really big disaster.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.(Explanations of the vote will continue tomorrow in plenary on Thursday 14 December 2017)

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: I apologize for the delay in resuming the session, but the truth is that, firstly, we ended voting time late and, secondly, I had to meet, at the request of President Tajani, a compromise thatIt has prevented me from arriving earlier.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the current debate (Article 153 bis of the Rules of Procedure) on the expansion and strengthening of the Schengen area: Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia (2017/3009 (RSP)).I inform the honorable Members that neither the incidental request to speak procedure, ie 'catch the eye', nor the 'blue card' procedure will apply to this debate.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Schengen area, as many in this House know, is the largest area of ​​free movement in the world and one of the greatest achievements of the European Union. A stronger Schengen area - I am convinced that Commissioner Avramopoulos shares this statement - a stronger and more united Schengen area improves security and trust in the European Union. If we want to strengthen the protection of our external borders, it is often said here in this House that we must strengthen the protection of the external borders. Well, if we really want to strengthen the protection of the external borders, then we must without hesitation enlarge the Schengen area to Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia, when Croatia is ready. Our group asked, in agreement with the whole socialist family, with the president of the European Socialist Party Sergej Stanišev, the whole socialist family, and the parliamentary group of the Socialists and Democrats, they asked for this priority debate because we consider it to be a ' injustice to exclude Romania and Bulgaria from the Schengen area and, when ready, Croatia. There cannot be, in the European Union, Serie A and Serie B States. We have always said one simple thing to our Bulgarian, Romanian and Croatian citizens: whoever respects the Schengen criteria has the right to join the Schengen area. And President Juncker - the Commissioner may confirm - has already recognized that Bulgaria and Romania have met the criteria. So it is not an invention or a request from a parliamentary group, there is an acknowledgment from the European Commission. And Croatia is on the right track. Now, it cannot be said from the Council - and I am sorry to always turn to the Council, I also have a bit, let's say, of sadness in arguing, unfortunately you deserve it, it is not my bad will, it is that you do not decide, and I necessarily owe it to you take, if you decide, I would be happy to say: thank you to the Council of Member States.Do it, and you will have the appreciation and thanks of the Socialists and Democrats.Do it on the Schengen area!Do not hesitate again, do it in the interest of Europe, it is fundamental for the security of the European Union, that Romania and Bulgaria, and then Croatia are part of the Schengen area, and therefore to the Bulgarian Presidency - I saw the minister, who Ihosted in our group yesterday and which I greet affectionately - I say to the Bulgarian Presidency: you will have all our support to ensure that the Council keeps its commitments and integrates these countries into the Schengen area.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I want to thank you most cordially for the chance to take part in this topical debate which is very close to my heart, on a case on which I have, in my national capacity in the Council, intervened repeatedly in the direction that Mr Pittella just indicated.  Ten years ago, on 6 December 2007, the Council decided to lift internal border controls for nine Member States that had joined the Union in 2004. The decision, which applied as of December 2007, marked a significant step forward for the benefit of people travelling in the enlarged Schengen area with no internal border controls. In recent years we have been faced with migratory pressures and terrorist threats to an extent not seen before. This has put the Schengen area under heavy pressure, but we have not remained idle. Many steps have been taken to sustain the full and proper functioning of Schengen, and many proposals are in the pipeline. At the Justice and Home Affairs Council in October this year, ministers had an extensive exchange of views on Schengen, particularly on the proposed Schengen border, the Borders Code Amendments, in relation to temporary internal border controls. While progress has been made on a number of files, a number of questions remain outstanding, with internal border controls in place in six countries in the Schengen area. It is therefore necessary for us to further intensify our work to get back to normal operation of Schengen, including viable alternatives to internal border controls.  Against this background, the Presidency organised an informal debate between the Ministers of the Interior at last week’s Justice and Home Affairs Council on 7 and 8 December. Ministers had a good and constructive debate, and even if there are diverging views on some issues, there is a general consensus that we must do our utmost to reinstall and strengthen our trust in Schengen.  Ministers took stock of measures already taken, such as the entry/exit system. We looked at measures currently discussed, such as the EU Travel Information and Authorisation System, the Schengen Information System proposals and the proposal for amending the Schengen Borders Control. And, in direct relation to the issue discussed in our debate today, Ministers also reflected on how we can move forward on the pending full application of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania. Both countries have fulfilled all the necessary conditions and have made significant efforts to guarantee the security of the EU’s external borders. However, the decision to fully apply the Schengen acquis for the two countries, for which we need unanimity, is still outstanding.  The improved situation regarding migratory pressures, and expected early agreement on a number of the measures currently under discussion, could perhaps change the situation. The Presidency on 7 December was happy to conclude the discussion, concluding that we have to continue working hard in the coming months on strengthening the Schengen area, including via enlargement. As for Croatia, it is still in the process of being evaluated in the run-up to full application of the Schengen acquis. The Council has already adopted several implementing decisions setting out recommendations to address the deficiencies identified with a view to Croatia fulfilling the conditions necessary for the application of the Schengen acquis. A small number of issues remain to be evaluated and we are looking forward to receiving the Commission’s proposal for implementing decisions thereon in the near future.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my thanks for adding this very important debate to the agenda and, in particular to thank Mr Gianni Pittella for this initiative. I know that this was – and remains – a priority for all political groups. Only some days ago we also had a fruitful and frank discussion in the Justice and Home Affairs Council with the Ministers of the Interior.  Let me start by highlighting the following. No matter how much work we collectively do in the three institutions, in the end, we will be judged by our success or failure only on three or four topics. Schengen is one of them. For our citizens, it is the symbol of the European Union itself. It is the most tangible example of European integration. It represents all the rights and benefits of being European, as it is closely connected to the freedom of movement and the notion of European citizenship. You all know my personal commitment to safeguarding and upholding Schengen since the very first moment I took office. We said in the past that a unified Schengen is a stronger Schengen. We are convinced that Bulgaria, Romania and also Croatia, as soon as it is ready, should fully join the Schengen family. This will enlarge the area of free movement and make the Schengen tools perform better and thus increase security. For a long time the Commission’s position is that Bulgaria and Romania already fulfil the necessary conditions. They were positively assessed between 2009 and 2011. As you know, it is now for the Council to decide on the lifting of internal border controls with Bulgaria and Romania unanimously, and it is high time that this happened. Our discussion with the Interior Ministers last week left me optimistic that there is agreement that this issue must now again be seriously considered. As far as Croatia is concerned, we are working closely with the authorities to identify the areas where improvements are still necessary in order to positively conclude all the Schengen evaluations as soon as possible. This will allow us in the Commission to complete the first stage and conclude that Croatia is also ready to join Schengen. Then it will again be for the Council to decide. The Schengen evaluations in 2016 and 2017 verify the necessary conditions for the application of all relevant parts of the acquis. In some areas, Croatia meets the necessary conditions for joining Schengen. In other areas, further improvement is required, and we stand by the Croatian authorities to continue with the same commitment. A full implementation of the Schengen acquis will also allow the drawing of full benefits from systems such as a Schengen Information System and the Visa Information System in relations between Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia and the other Schengen states. It would also allow them to implement the Entry—Exit System in the most efficient way, without installing it in border sections which would become internal borders after their accession to Schengen. The implementation of the EES will be a particular challenge for Croatia given its long land border. Here the European Union is willing to provide support. Finally, the setting up of the ADS will strengthen the management of the external borders and therefore Schengen. Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia are playing their equal part in protecting the European Union’s external borders. Fully joining Schengen is not only politically fair, but it is also needed from a security point of view, because the internal security of one Member State is the internal security of all and the security of all our citizens. I hope that we can welcome these Member States to Schengen soon following a positive decision by the Council. As I said before, from the moment that I took office, I have been advocating that we need a strong and unified Schengen. Today I would like to commend and to praise the authorities of the three countries for their commitment. We are running the last mile. Let us run it all together. Today the Parliament and the Commission, tomorrow the Council. I hope your message will be heard by the Council, Mr Pittella.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Schengen area is one of the greatest achievements of the European project. It is a dream come true. After World War II, few people could imagine that one day Europe would be united and living in peace. Seventy-two years after, borders between European countries do not exist any more. They exist only on maps and in the heads of those who want to destroy the Union. Four hundred million nationals of more than 25 different states travelling free with no passport check, with no border controls and within a single country: this is what Europeans have accomplished, and we have to be very proud of it. But Schengen will not be completed until all members who want to be part of it have the chance to join. My Group has a clear position on this: any Member State that fulfils the membership criteria should join Schengen, and the truth is that Bulgaria and Romania fulfil these criteria. Already in 2011 this House adopted the Coelho report confirming that Romania and Bulgaria were sufficiently well prepared, and regarding Croatia, even if they have not yet fulfilled all the conditions, they are making great progress. In this situation, trying to politicise this debate with different issues is a huge mistake. First, because these three countries are not in the same situation, and second, because accession to Schengen cannot be mixed with the cooperation and verification mechanism. The decision on accession to Schengen must be based on technical criteria, and a delay based on political reasons is simply unacceptable. There are no first-class and second-class countries. We are all European countries and we all deserve the best. That is why we stand today with our Romanian, Croatian and Bulgarian colleagues. This is what we can all call solidarity, and the day we stop showing solidarity among us is the day we will lose the right to call ourselves Europeans. We ask the Council to please do all that they can.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me first thank Mr Pittella for raising this debate and bringing it to the plenary of the European Parliament; it is extremely important. As was already said, it is difficult to imagine the European Union today without Schengen. This is a very tangible expression of our solidarity and of the freedom and unity of European citizens, and it brings a lot of economic benefits – but not for all Europeans. For six years now, Bulgaria and Romania have fulfilled the criteria for membership, and what is happening is a double standard and treating the two countries in a discriminatory way. It should be stopped, because it may look as though this is an issue only for Bulgaria and Romania, but it affects very fundamental issues and principles of the European Union. First, it is about credibility if we as a Union follow our own rules. We do not. Second, the economic benefits will bring benefits to all citizens of the European Union. Thirdly, it is about security. Instead of wasting money for internal controls, we should strengthen through resources and enough financing the external borders of the Union. This is what is needed; this is what is effective. We often complain that anti-European forces, populists, are using arguments against the European Union. This is one of the cases, because it shows injustice to too many European citizens, and now the European Council has to do its job, which is not performed – an injustice has to be stopped. This should be a very clear message from the European Parliament today.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - When Romania and Bulgaria joined the Union in 2007, their legal systems were not yet complete. They had to catch up and implement necessary reforms. The fight against corruption and organized crime also needed to be stepped up. Since then, the Commission has been monitoring the situation through the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism, called CVM for short. Recently, together with my ECR colleague Macovei, I denounced recent developments in Romania. The government had issued ordinances to condone tax crimes and thwart police investigations and lawsuits, all to keep corrupt rulers in power. I asked the European Commission to follow up on the matter. Romania was therefore judged on this in this year's CVM report. When assessing the eligibility of these three EU Member States, we should focus on the CVM reports of November 2017. This also applies to the provisions on organized crime. After all, the Schengen area has no internal borders. It is therefore fundamental to avoid importing crime into our regions in this way. However, little progress has been noted. Yes, there are positive developments, but not enough. That is why my delegation, N-VA, is against the accession of Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia to the Schengen area. More efforts really need to be made before a political green light can be given.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, securing a common area of free movement for people within the Schengen area is one of the biggest achievements of the European project, as it brings people together, makes life simpler for businesses and builds a sense of belonging together. During the last few years, this historical achievement has been put under threat. Under pressure caused by the collapse of the asylum system in 2015 and the unwillingness of certain Member States to address the obvious flaws in the Dublin regulation, we have seen a domino effect in play among Member States as they start to reintroduce border controls. The Schengen area also faces another fundamental challenge, namely the discrimination against Bulgaria and Romania. Both of these EU countries have for a long time now fulfilled all the criteria for joining the Schengen area but are still being refused access by other Member States of this Union, and for political reasons alone. This is unacceptable and has to come to an end. We cannot, on the one hand, criticise certain Member States for not respecting due process and then ignore ourselves the rules that we have set up for accession to the Schengen zone! I am proud that this Parliament always fights for the Union and for the rights of its citizens. Today, I would like to reach out to Romanian and Bulgarian citizens and say that you enjoy the same rights and the same values as any other European citizen! Member States need to show respect for common agreements, allow for the full integration of these two countries into the Schengen area without any further delay, and allow the full integration of Croatia as well, as soon as it meets the criteria.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the three countries to the Schengen area. I am very happy, because, I am elected in Greece, but I was born and raised on the Bulgarian-Romanian border. I believe in Schengen. But do the Commission and the Council believe it? Because for the past two years they have been turning it into garbage. How; Extending border controls imposed by some states to block refugees. Greeks wonder: Why do they undergo offensive checks when they arrive in Germany, France or Belgium? Was Greece finally excluded from Schengen and we do not know? And one more thing: Fortunately, the Commission and Commissioner Avramopoulos rejected their plan. But are they honest? Why - let's not forget - the Commission's proposals for Schengen changes, which extend border controls for up to two years, are like saying "well done" to states that have refused to show solidarity with the refugee tragedy, and so thousands of refugees could be trapped. in Greece and Italy. I ask the Commission, the Council and all of you, colleagues: is that what Europe wants? Is this Schengen?

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think Schengen is one of the most fundamental expressions of the European idea, the idea to cross borders, to overcome borders, overcome differences that divide us and to grow together. That is the European ideal, and that is being expressed by Schengen. Every Member State has the right, but even the obligation, to join Schengen as soon as it fulfils the criteria for the common membership. And those conditions, those criteria, are very clear. They are crystal clear and the procedures should not be changed in the middle of the process.  Precisely because Schengen is so important, it is such an important right for all European citizens, it cannot be withheld from particular Member States and from their citizens. It is a right, and we cannot allow second-class citizens to be established. Another rightful expectation of citizens is that the rule of law be upheld. If we are looking now at Romania, this does not seem to be totally guaranteed. We are very worried about the proposed changes to the justice laws that are currently being discussed and debated in the Romanian parliament, and EU citizens in Romania are expecting Europe to do something about it. I think we absolutely have to do something, and I want to thank those people in Romania who go out on the street and demonstrate for their rights, for democracy, and are telling all of us, all the time reminding us, that democracy is more than going to vote once in a while, it is more than having the rule of the majority. It tells us that there is also the responsibility of the majority for all citizens. We stand with you. But it is very clear that Schengen is also and especially for those people – they are European citizens, they need to be allowed to travel freely like everyone. I am also very proud that the European Parliament has been very clear on this all the time and now it is time for the Council to act, and I hope it will do this very soon.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, at a time when the Schengen area is under considerable strain from mass movement of illegal migration, I find it remarkable that a debate on expanding the Schengen area has been considered. For as we all know, and yet many choose to deny, having no border checks at the internal borders helps to facilitate the free movement of terrorists and the free movement of weapons. It assists criminal gangs by allowing them to easily transport illegal drugs. It also plays a significant role in facilitating human trafficking across the EU. Citizens in our own countries ask our governments to commit to some core responsibilities. One of the most important of these is to ask that our people can feel safe. I would ask you to consider this, because it is something that is very seriously at risk here and people constantly ask us about safety and governments keeping the people safe.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to respond to Mrs Keller, who, in the European Parliament, is urging the world to hold street demonstrations, urging the world in the European Parliament to overthrow democratically elected governments - democracy. Dear colleagues, democracy is about respecting the vote. In Romania, the prospect of joining the Schengen area has become a kind of discussion about the sex of angels, Mr. President, colleagues - that is, as scientific as it is useless. All politicians promise in the election campaign that they will convince Europeans to receive Romania in Schengen, but neither the citizens nor the politicians themselves believe such a thing. A few months ago, President Macron came to Bucharest and from there went to Sofia to convince us to support France's position on the Posting of Workers Directive. When asked about the Schengen area, he cut it short: Schengen must be reformed and, only after that, we are talking about the accession of Romania and Bulgaria. I understood very well the retention of the Western countries regarding the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen in 2007. I also understood it in 2010. I was able to accept this in 2012. During all this time, the efforts to secure the border cost many, many money. In 2015, however, the invasion of refugees did not take place in Romania or in Bulgaria, dear colleagues. It is clear that keeping these countries out of Schengen has another reason. I can also understand this reason: namely that some countries or some politicians in the West believe that the Union must have two speeds. I can also understand President Macron, who suggests that he would like to renegotiate the Schengen agreement. What I can't understand is hypocrisy and false friends. It is okay for nations to want to control their borders. It is okay to have a Union with two or more speeds. But it's not ok like big countries either strong to prevent smaller or weaker countries from adopting the same protectionist measures as large ones.I support the competition with all my might and I am convinced that egalitarianism inhibits the desire and ability to progress.I am therefore not advocating for the homogeneity of Europe, but I want to ensure equal opportunities and real independence for the Member States.If the big and strong states want to prevent, through artificial obstacles, the smaller countries from making progress, then the European Union will cease to exist.The reform of the Schengen area can be an interesting project, but it necessarily implies the beginning of a profound reform of the entire European Union.From 1957 to Maastricht, the European Community developed through successive additions, which were possible because the number of Member States was small.But now, it is no longer possible with the patch!We need a real reform of the European Union, dear colleagues.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, Schengen is no exception but an implementation of the additional controls on Greek passengers these days, as well as the modern electronic methods of obtaining biometrics, monitoring, filing of peoples of Europe, refugees and migrants, with border guards and the unacceptable Doub. Schengen means people with their hands and feet tied, since only capital and cheap workers without rights have the right to move freely in the interests of business groups. This is your European acquis, which is now being extended to the Balkans. The Tusk letter is not a contradiction of the European Union, but a confirmation of its policy, of the European Union-Turkey agreement, which traps refugees and immigrants in miserable conditions like Moria in Greece and Italy. The Greek government also bears a huge responsibility, which, he says, does not guarantee the lives of the refugees, but on the other hand provides guarantees for fast track deportations back to the hell of the imperialist war, which it and its allies reward and provide facilities to. Solidarity of the peoples, for the refugees to reach their destination, against imperialist wars, European Union, NATO, governments and exploitation!

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Mr President, Romania has secured its borders and fulfilled its commitment under the Accession Treaty. He spent over one billion euros from his own money and from the Schengen facility, under the leadership of a Franco-German concert. The Romanian border is much more secure than other external borders, such as France, in the south, on the Mediterranean Sea. Unfortunately, this happened in 2011. I met all the conditions. We were not accepted in Schengen or later. The reasons given are purely populist or national, because of the national elections: each state wanted to show voters what efforts it is making for a subject that does not exist. I believe that this situation must be approached differently. The fact that in Romania there are, I know, political events that are not in accordance with European norms is true. And now there are such things: the laws of justice are being challenged in Parliament. These things need to be addressed separately and I ask the Commission to do so. But Schengen must also be treated separately. I think joining airports is common sense right now. The Council should do so without delay and, subsequently, also at land borders.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, in my Group we remain strongly committed to the full and immediate accession of Romania and Bulgaria in the Schengen area. We demand it now! If we say we are a community of values and based on the rule of law, we should act like one. It is quite unacceptable that, despite the required conditions being fulfilled, the decision on accession has not yet been made.  Fragmenting, or creating a second-class Schengen, with the solutions found in the entry/exit system for example, is putting the integrity of freedom of movement at risk. Such political games by the Council erode the trust of our citizens in the European project, which we are so desperately trying to protect from collapsing. I would also like to welcome Croatia as soon as it meets the criteria. Have we really forgotten that Schengen is one of the greatest achievements of the European integration? We are tired of hypocrisy: promising restoration and full functioning of the Schengen area by the end of 2016 failed miserably. On the contrary, the Commission further proposed the extension of internal border controls beyond the current legal basis this year, while admitting that the conditions are not fulfilled. If you do not to reverse the course of action soon, I am seriously afraid that Schengen as we know it will be a thing of the past, and there is no European Union without Schengen.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, I am one of the biggest supporters of Romania's entry into Schengen. But I work for it and I do not come empty-handed, as do the socialist colleagues from PSD and ALDE, who are in government and who say they want Romania in Schengen but, in reality, I do everything to prevent this. I will give you some examples: at this moment, the Romanian Parliament is voting to amend the justice laws in an emergency procedure - practically, in secret, without debate. People watch TV and see on TV what is changing and all this in order to subjugate justice politically, to no longer have the rule of law - by the way, the rule of law, which must unite us - and to create mechanisms of investigation, of threatening and blackmailing judges and prosecutors. Why? To escape the ruling ALDE and PSD politicians. If you do such things and claim that you want to enter Schengen, then you ask yourself a question: do you really want to enter Schengen or do you just come and speak in the plenary of the Parliament and say that you want to enter Schengen? Yes, I want to enter Schengen and that's why I don't even link the MCV to Schengen, because the MCV is one. The Commission has never asked for this link, and it must stop when all is said and done. Anything that happens today in Romania, on justice, is contrary to the MCV. Yes, let's enter Schengen, but work for it, dear socialist and ALDE colleagues.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for six years now we have been reminding you that Bulgaria and Romania have met the criteria for the Schengen area. Not allowing us into Schengen is a violation of European law. The arguments "against" are only political. Then the counter-arguments should be the same. Paradoxically, the argument is that both sides are under monitoring and do not establish legality. And the answer should be the same - a violation of the rule of law. It is a paradox that 3,264 kilometers of the Union's borders should be guarded without pretensions to Bulgaria and Romania, and that they should be denied access to Schengen. It is a paradox to look for supporters for the future, but to apply another standard to Bulgaria, which is a loyal partner, with very good budgetary discipline and a lasting direction towards strong integration. It is paradoxical that despite the rejection, Bulgarian citizens are among the Union's biggest supporters, but there is also a belief that political arguments will back down.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: - Mr President! Schengen cooperation is one of the benefits that EU citizens appreciate most about the EU. It has provided significant benefits to both EU citizens and businesses, enabling over 400 million Europeans from 26 European countries to travel without a passport. In connection with the refugee situation in 2015, it was put to the test when several member countries reintroduced border controls, including my own, Sweden. When the controls were introduced in 2016, there were far-reaching financial consequences when the commuting time increased and the number of travelers between Sweden and Denmark decreased by 15 percent. It cost the region 152 million, but only 78 people out of the approximately three million people checked were refugees. The idea is, after all, that all Member States should join the Schengen cooperation as soon as the conditions are met. But we can not come up with new requirements for acceding countries than those that already exist in existing regulations. Since 2011, both Romania and Bulgaria have fulfilled the conditions for joining the cooperation and should be allowed to become full members as soon as possible without being blocked by other member states of the Council. The same, of course, applies to Croatia when the technical criteria are met.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - Schengen was initially a very sympathetic treaty because why should we not trust each other, right?But in the meantime, the composition of the population in Western Europe has changed and terrorist threats are commonplace.The mistake that is deliberately made here, also in this debate, in the European Parliament, is to confuse the free movement of persons with passport-free travel.Fortunately, however, the Commission has now also admitted, in response to questions from me, that these two things have nothing to do with each other.In practical terms, Schengen has long since passed away.The obituary has just not yet appeared in the newspaper.A growing number of Member States, including Germany and France, renew border controls every six months.And that sovereignty actually pleases.Let us recognize that Schengen dates from a different era and is no longer applicable today.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, the accession of Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia to the Schengen area has been unduly delayed. Since they want to join and meet the criteria, only prejudices have kept them out for a few years now. The problem lies not in the number of states that will belong to Schengen but in the very provisions of this treaty and especially how they are implemented. At the moment we are talking, many European countries have temporarily suspended the application of Schengen for flights coming from Greece, under the pretext of the possible entry of illegal immigrants. It was the German government through Chancellor Merkel that invited illegal immigrants to Europe from the beginning, but now, after the political damage suffered by its party, it decided to make this micropolitical move, which is mainly addressed to its internal audience. In any case, this proves the gaps in this treaty. Our proposal is the complete reinstatement of all border controls, without this meaning that the passage of people is restricted; it will simply be controlled. So far, the greatest benefits of the uncontrolled movement of people within the Union have been reaped by various criminals, smugglers, drug traffickers and traffickers.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, upon the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU in 2007, the European Union has committed itself to accepting both countries as full members of Schengen when they are ready. They have been ready for several years. This has been confirmed by the governments of both countries, as well as by the European Parliament and the European Commission. Nevertheless, we are witnessing the repeated postponement of the decision to join Bulgaria and Romania to Schengen. Objectively speaking, it is not fair to apply such double standards to Bulgaria and Romania. It is not fair not to recognize the efforts and results of both sides. It is not fair not to acknowledge the fact that Bulgaria has had the best results in the refugee crisis. Bulgaria has long proven that it generates security and stability in a very problematic and complex region. Bulgaria has proved to be a reliable external border of the European Union. Bulgaria has a heavy responsibility to protect our external border with Turkey and it is doing an excellent job. Bulgaria does not threaten the security of Europe. The Council must immediately decide on the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the Schengen area. We must stand together and united against the threats in a cohesive Schengen area. The future of the European Union depends on the extent to which the countries are united and in solidarity with each other. It is this solidarity that requires Bulgaria and Romania to be admitted to Schengen immediately, and Croatia - when it fulfills the conditions.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Minister Maasikas, I tell you from the outset that I do not intend today to teach my colleagues at the ECR, much less Mrs Macovei, what Schengen means. It would be a waste of time. Romania and Bulgaria are two deeply European countries, with major contributions to Frontex, recognized as such, and contribute considerably to ensuring the control and security of the European Union's external borders, being committed, at the same time, with honesty and loyalty to building the future of the European Union. . Successive reports by the European Parliament and successive evaluations by the European Commission after 2011 have confirmed that all - I repeat, all - meet the technical standards set out in the accession process. The opposition of some Member States is based more on political and economic reasons, already becoming a clear form of discrimination, which continues to affect, including economically, negatively the two states. The European Parliament must today call on the Council to finally follow up on the Commission's proposal two months ago for the immediate reception of Romania and Bulgaria in the Schengen area, convinced that the values ​​of solidarity between Member States and the exclusion of double standards are not just good slogans for election campaign. I conclude with confidence and hope that the European partners of Romania and Bulgaria and Croatia will thaw this file, so that the two countries, Romania and Bulgaria, become members of the Schengen area as soon as possible, and Croatia joins when the conditions are met.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner Pavlova, colleagues, let us be honest: the reason why Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia are not in this area is only political. The technical criteria have long been met, but three countries in the European Union are taking into account their internal political problems, making concessions to parties that are, to put it mildly, anti-European and Eurosceptic, and because of their internal problems they are hindering our countries' accession. And here I agree with my colleague Hyusmenova: this is a violation of European law, this is unfair and this is a double standard. I recently heard from a colleague that crime was a problem. Colleagues, where is the Molenbeek district, known for having more illegal weapons than the entire Belgian army, for being a center of trafficking, of drugs, of violent trafficking in human beings, of women? Well, it is neither in Bulgaria nor in Romania. Located in the Kingdom of Belgium. Where are the problems that are in the Netherlands? Because we are talking about these countries. Let's say them. The countries that are interfering are those, dear colleagues. So are we talking here about excluding these countries from Schengen? Probably not. It is high time to put an end to hypocrisy and the double standard, ladies and gentlemen, and to respect European law. Bulgaria and Romania must be part of Schengen, as well as Croatia, because we guard the European Union's external borders.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I want to assure you that the Schengen area is also a symbol for Romanian and Bulgarian citizens. What our citizens do not understand is why we allow some Member States, with so-called consolidated democracies, to make fun of the symbols of the European Union. If we all privilege freedom of movement, if we all want more Europe, why do we accept that some do not respect the European treaties and introduce parasitic and precarious conditions in treaties that do not provide for such conditions. Mr President, we are convinced that we have met the criteria, but we are becoming increasingly convinced that a double language is being formed, a European Pharisaism that our citizens do not accept. We are European citizens, we are citizens with equal rights, we want more Europe, we want more trust in Europe and those who created this Union must understand that trust depends on everything, not cheap partisan political games. If France, if the Netherlands, if Austria, if Germany, want more Europe, they will have to vote at the European Council for the Schengen area. This will prove that they trust what they say in their public speeches and that they do not use a double language, politically initiated in relations with other countries. Romania is not a colony, Romania is not a peripheral state, Romania is a member of the European Union, it has a language that is the language of the European Union and, for that, Romanian citizens demand the respect of those who forgot to give it to us too a long time.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today in this House we are discussing whether to expand and strengthen Schengen, and therefore to allow the free movement of people within the European Union without any kind of border controls. Instead, I say clearly that border controls must be carried out, indeed I say more: borders must be closed, because in recent years Islamic terrorists have circulated freely in Europe. Or have you forgotten the attacks in Paris, Brussels, Nice, London, Barcelona? Have you forgotten about the hundreds of people who died as a result of murderous fanaticism, as a result of Islamic terrorism? This boy is Luca Russo, indeed he was Luca Russo. He was 25 years old, he was an engineer, he lived in Bassano del Grappa, a few kilometers from my house. On August 17th he was in Barcelona with his girlfriend Marta. Marta came back injured, he died. Luca Russo's family begged me to never forget this boy. Luca Russo's friends asked me to do everything to stop these bastards! To intervene to stop this Islamic terrorism. I address this plea to you: we must stop these terrorists, we must stop Islamic terrorism, the invasion, the immigrants who are arriving. We have to check the borders. Schengen must be suspended, you must rethink Schengen, we must block the borders, we must stop this invasion. Minutes of silence are no longer enough, demonstrations are no longer enough: we need a rethinking of Schengen.

name: Željana ZOVKO
