text: - Mr. President, a number of current developments and security challenges, the refugee and migration crisis faced by the Republic of Croatia at the end of 2015, when more than half a million refugees passed through the country, made border security one of the main priorities of the Croatian Government. Much has been done from that period to the present day. In preparation for full membership in the Schengen area, Croatia has used almost all the resources of the Schengen instrument: it has procured ships, helicopters for border surveillance, built a new one and renovated existing border police stations, thus contributing to the full implementation of the Schengen acquis. I believe that special attention should be paid to strengthening the external borders of the European Union, which are also our national borders, especially if we take into account that Croatia has the longest external border with the European Union. All of the above points to the need to include the Republic of Croatia in the Schengen area as soon as possible. I hope that Croatia will meet the technical criteria as soon as possible and I expect in 2019 to be a full member of Schengen.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, when the Commissioner spoke, it was a detailed explanation of why the full integration of Romania and Bulgaria must happen now. At the heart of that, he said that Schengen was precious to the whole idea of the European Union. I have never heard, in all the years that I have been here, a stronger case made for anything about the central cause of this European Union. Let us also be clear about this institution, the European Parliament, for anyone who is in any doubt. Since 2011, for six long years, the European Parliament in its Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), has had unambiguous majority debates, well—examined, detailed debates, making one conclusion, namely that second class status for Romania and Bulgaria is not an option. They must be fully integrated into Schengen. We have supported the measures to grant Romania and Bulgaria access to the Entry-Exit System, the Visa Information System. We have even talked about visa-free travel to the US. We are doing this and being proactive in this cause, not just because we believe it, but because we have examined the case for these countries. This is a case not just for justice but for practicality. This is not just a case for the politics, but for understanding what it means for Romania and Bulgaria to be full members. Then I refer again to the Commission and I ask the Council on this: this has not been a static process. In all of these six years, we have been strengthening the external border: Entry-Exit System, external border controls, the border agency, one of the fastest files ever created in this Parliament. All these measures and the hard work that has gone on with all of the issues of privacy and individual liberties that we had to tackle was to safeguard the external border. With all of this, we can surely ask that today there is an unambiguous and clear demand that two countries have justice and are fully integrated Member States of the European Union. Schengen is precious, all the measures are coming to make it, and I echo what the Commissioner said: together, all of us together, will make this happen.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: I see some requests for the use of the blue card.The point is that in debates of this nature the Regulation does not contemplate either the use of the "blue card" procedure or the "catch the eye" procedure.At the beginning of the debate I pointed it out, but I see that there are those who request it.It is a purely regulatory issue, it is not arbitrary, it is not a whim of whoever is currently presiding over the Plenary, I simply comply with the Regulations.Thanks for your understanding.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, great migratory pressures and the terrorist threat have left their mark on Schengen, which is not even foreseen for the circumstances that currently prevail in Europe and its immediate neighborhood.The proven weaknesses, however, are not a reason to reject Schengen, but a real impetus for its improvement.What the Schengen area has represented since its first day - an area of trust, security and peace, we need in Europe today more than ever in the last twenty years.But the whole concept is rather meaningless if it does not include all states with external borders.Of course, there are very objective criteria that need to be met, but now that this goal is within our reach, we should push Croatia, Bulgaria and Romania to join Schengen as soon as possible.Therefore, from this point of view, I once again call on all those who participate or contribute to the decision-making process to speed up the accession of these three countries to the Schengen area as much as possible.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, I would like to thank my colleagues from S&D for this very topical issue that they have raised. As security threats increase, so does the need to create a single European security area, ie the inclusion of all European Union countries in the Schengen area. The shattered Schengen area not only makes it difficult to control external borders and security, but also communication, free movement of people, goods, capital and services, and thus weakens the European Union's economic strength, especially creating inequalities between Member States and EU citizens. Therefore, I welcome the announced entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area, as well as my Croatian country as soon as it meets the conditions. I am glad that both the Minister and the Commissioner said that Croatia has very few criteria left to meet in order to become a member of the Schengen area, and as I oppose all inequalities and unequal treatment of Bulgaria and Romania upon their entry into the Schengen area, I expect the decision on Croatia's accession to be adopted on the basis of criteria, on the basis of technical and administrative capacity, and not on the basis of political criteria, requirements and conditions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President! It is somewhat confusing when the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, appears to ignore the latest report from his own authority on Romania and Bulgaria. The report clearly states that neither the reform of the judiciary nor the fight against corruption and organized crime are satisfactory. Now Mr Juncker wants to include both countries in the Schengen area as quickly as possible, to integrate them into the Schengen information system - they are supposed to secure the European external border. Of course, it would be desirable if the European external border were secured and protected a little further to the south-east. But the framework conditions must also be right, and the Commission's report clearly speaks against it. How reliable border security should work in the event of corruption in the police and also in the judiciary is beyond my knowledge, but perhaps Mr Juncker has a suitable answer here. One thing is clear, however: Schengen, which has already been established several times today, needs to be revised, Schengen is in need of reform. And it is also clear: with the hasty shot of an enlargement, for which the framework conditions are not yet right, Europe will not become safer, the borders will not become safer! And whether you want to hear it or not, our citizens in Europe see it that way.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr President, last week we were to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the entry into the Schengen area in the Czech Republic. However, the celebrations were almost imperceptible. The unique idea that people can move freely and without controls across the European Union is now taken for granted by many of us. In addition, the Czech Republic is economically almost dependent on the smooth functioning of the movement of goods. It is all the more surprising that we cannot appreciate the Schengen area. Many politicians do not hesitate to misuse the Schengen area for their populist games in connection with migration and security policy. The Schengen area is undergoing a fundamental test in its functioning. Just to give you an idea, according to a study by the European Parliament, the abolition of the Schengen area would cost one hundred to two hundred and thirty billion euros in ten years. From the beginning, the Schengen area was conceived as an organism that includes elements of freedom and security. Freedom of movement without internal borders has been balanced since the beginning of this idea. Balanced not only by the important protection of the external borders, but also by a system of a number of other related regulations. Over the last two years, the security aspect of the Schengen area has significantly strengthened. They have strengthened Frontex's powers, and we have approved the introduction of an entry / exit system (EES) and a number of other regulations to improve border control. I look forward to new members of the Schengen area. Bulgaria and Romania and Croatia must be admitted to the Schengen area immediately after meeting all the binding criteria.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, first of all I would like to thank Gianni Pittelli and his group, on whose proposal we are discussing the enlargement of Schengen today. The debate, quite rightly, includes Croatia in addition to Bulgaria and Romania. Thanks also to Commissioner Avramopoulos for the clear and encouraging views of the Commission. As many as one billion and two hundred and fifty million trips are recorded annually in the Schengen area. The economic, political and integrative effects of this great achievement of the European Union need not be talked about too much. The rules of accession are clear - it is a comprehensive list of technical criteria that a country must meet before accession. In the end, however, the key - political - consent of all EU members is needed. It is important to continue the implementation of the Schengen acquis. This strengthens the level of trust among the members of the Schengen area. Equally, one should have confidence in the members who have been working intensively for a long time to meet all the criteria. I would like to point out that since joining the Schengen Information System, Croatia has performed 75 million controls in just 4 months and identified over 4,000 violations. Proof that the preparations already made bring results. In addition, Croatia has the longest external land border of the European Union of all members. We want to contribute to better security of our part of the external borders of the European Union. We want the internal borders of the European Union without the barbed wire that separates us from our neighbors today. It is up to Croatia to meet all the criteria for joining Schengen, which we expect by the end of next year. It is then up to the Council to acknowledge all that has been done. The credibility of the European Union will be clearly confirmed on this issue.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Avramopoulos, while Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia become members of Schengen, Greek airline passengers from Greece are subject to illegal checks at German and Belgian airports. I had denounced the imposition of a German quarantine on Greek passengers in this room here on 15 November. Nevertheless, the illegal checks of Greek passengers not only continue at German airports, but also extended to Brussels Airport on 4 December, a question on which I asked you, Mr Avramopoulos, an urgent written question and I await your answer. In addition, here at Strasbourg Airport, all Schengen passengers, including MEPs, are subject to passport controls on arrival and departure. Thus, while Germany, Belgium, France and Austria do not apply Schengen, in the end it is applied by Greece, with the result that our country has become a magnet for the thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants. In view of all this, Greece must leave Schengen here and now. I have said it before in this room.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, these are seven years since the last technical evaluation of Romania's Schengen dossier took place. Since the summer of 2011, the Commission and the Parliament consider that Romania is ready to enter the free movement area. Since then, several European governments have opposed this entry. The argument was that the security of the Schengen area is affected by the defective way in which the rule of law in Romania works. The Cooperation and Verification Mechanism thus became the key that was to open the Shengen gate. In the last five years, the governments of Bucharest have had three attitudes regarding MCV. The first was the direct undermining of justice, including constitutional justice. The Ponta government and the majority of PSD-PNL threw Romania, in the summer of 2012, into a very serious institutional crisis, adding new criteria to be met in the MCV file. Later, upset that the Europeans were waiting for an independent judiciary, Prime Minister Ponta and Foreign Minister Corlățean said that they were no longer interested in Schengen. The second attitude was the effort to improve the functioning of justice. It is the short period, unfortunately, in which Dacian Cioloș was prime minister. Finally, at the beginning of the year, the assault on the rule of law was resumed by the Grindeanu and Tudose governments. The majority of PSD-ALDE wants to limit the independence of magistrates and protect the corrupt. In January they used an emergency ordinance adopted at midnight. For several weeks they have had a voting machine at hand, well greased by corrupt people, sailors or incompatible deputies. As the critics of 6 years ago from other member states have not changed their opinion about the Schengen-MCV relationship, as long as there is no justice in Romania, there will be no complete freedom of movement for Romanians.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner. Once upon a time, in the European Union all the institutions - when talking about Schengen - spoke the same language, aware that it is, together with the European social model, the most precious and most precious asset of the European construction for five hundred millions of Europeans. But that time has now run into a problem. And the problem is called the Council, which has not only suspended the free movement of people, the most precious asset by Europeans - Schengen -, but also threatens to extend the suspension until 2020 and, above all, excludes two from that free movement. Member states of the European Union that have done their homework, that have met all the technical criteria. And, therefore, it perpetrates a grave injustice against Romania and Bulgaria and threatens to do the same with Croatia, preventing the free movement of people to European citizens who are full body and full-fledged. The Socialist Group wants to tell Romanians and Bulgarians that it fully supports your right to free movement and does not want Romanians and Bulgarians, or tomorrow Croats, to be less citizens than others in the European Union and tells you, Commissioner, that the suspension of Schengen deteriorates the credibility of the European Union as a global actor and deteriorates the consistency of the European project before Europeans. And, therefore, it feeds those rampant enemies that threaten and stalk the European Union: exclusionary nationalism and populism.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, ten years after Bulgaria's accession to the European Union, our country will take over the Presidency of the Council of the EU for the first time and will lead the Union at an important moment in its development. point of change in migration policy and Schengen. At the same time, however, Bulgaria is not a full Schengen member, although it fully implements the Schengen acts, actively uses the Schengen Information System, gained passive access to the Visa Information System and is within the scope of the newly established entry / exit system. Having met all the technical criteria for joining Schengen - the only criteria for accession, Bulgaria has proven to be a reliable partner in the protection of the external European border. It is time for the repeated recognition of words to be supported by clear and unequivocal political action by our European partners. At a time of growing political populism, traditional parties, especially when they are in power, should show common sense and not succumb to populist tactics. European rules and laws should not be trampled on in the name of winning votes. It is not a show of solidarity, nor is it legally sound to change the rules for some for others. I therefore call on the Member States to take a positive decision as soon as possible on the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to Schengen. Only in this way will they prove that their words are backed by real intentions within the framework of rules that they themselves have written.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! I grew up in Upper Austria, in a region that was surrounded by borders, barriers and barbed wire narrowed my horizon. These borders did not protect us, they prevented us from establishing contacts and weakened our region. Europe: For my generation it was the dream of living without border bars. Schengen changed Europe, brought people together and increased our prosperity. Austria in particular has benefited from this. Open borders are a valuable asset. They require trust, and that trust needs to be handled carefully. But we must not prevent others from enjoying this freedom of movement. That is unfair and unjust, unwise at that, and it destroys trust in a common Europe. It is high time to finally do what you should have done a long time ago.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – The Schengen area is the largest free travel area in the world and the biggest achievement of the European Union. It has marked a significant step forward for the benefit of people travelling in the enlarged Schengen area with no internal border controls. Romania and Bulgaria have fulfilled all the necessary conditions and have made significant efforts to guarantee the security of the EU’s external borders. It is time to take the necessary steps to enable those countries to finally become full members of the Schengen area in order to make citizens’ lives easier and boost our economies.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Accession to the Schengen area is one of the strategic priorities of the Republic of Croatia, which is approached with great seriousness and commitment because the Croatian external border is the longest external border of the EU. The European migration crisis and the problem of radicalization and Wahhabi settlements growing on the other side of the border, in BiH, make the issue of enlargement and the necessity of Croatia's entry into the Schengen area urgent and necessary. These settlements serve as centers for employment and training of radicalized members who are a direct threat to European security, so increased control and mutual cooperation and support with other Schengen members is an important element of security of the EU external border with BiH. external border crossings. The goal of the Republic of Croatia is to achieve technical readiness during 2018 so that the Council can make a political decision on Croatia's accession to the Schengen area at the beginning of 2019 at the latest, and certainly before the end of the mandate of the current European Commission. This would be a significant decision and send a positive message in favor of a united and strong Europe, because only through joint efforts can adequate protection be provided to European citizens. I hereby express my support for the entry of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen area, and I believe that Europe without borders is the only path to a united and secure Europe.

name: Kati PIRI
text: written. - Today we are debating whether to allow Croatia, Bulgaria and Romania to join the Schengen area. According to the Commission, Bulgaria and Romania meet all the criteria set. When we talk about Schengen, we are also talking about borders. Last summer, we received more than 200 complaints about border abuses in Bulgaria: long waiting times, having to pay bribes and unjustified fines - it all happened. In addition, our own investigation has shown that no border official has been convicted to date. A major stumbling block in this is integrity. People are open to bribes, but is the step to organized crime not easy? All in all, it means that after ten years of membership, Bulgaria is still not up to standard and little progress is being made despite all EU funding. That is no longer possible. It is time for the country to take a serious approach to corruption and no longer hide behind sham solutions.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. - I believe that the enlargement of the Schengen area cannot be postponed any further: the Commission has already stated that Romania and Bulgaria are ready to join and that these countries and their citizens have been waiting for a positive decision from EU Home Affairs Ministers for years. EU monitoring of the two countries' judicial systems has nothing to do with Schengen accession, a violation of European law if these two things are linked. The Commission could also consider introducing an EU mechanism similar to the monitoring report for the amount per Member State, as Member States will accept this type of control if they do not differentiate between them and do not feel it is a double standard. This kind of monitoring mechanism could, of course, be applied and operated with great care, but if we really aim to build a citizens' Europe, the EU cannot do anything else.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Following the efforts made by Romania to meet the criteria for accession to the Schengen area, it is obvious that our country can no longer live on empty promises and must be part of this area. As the European Commission and the EP have been acknowledging for more than six years, our country meets all the technical criteria. Moreover, Romania is already a part of and implementing the systems set up to better manage the Union's external borders, such as the Schengen Information System or the Visa Information System. However, I consider that this ambiguous status in which Romania is both an observer and a de facto participant must end. Instead, we should focus on strengthening the current Schengen area and its external borders and placing more emphasis on solidarity. The refusal to expand the Schengen area in Romania betrays a lack of solidarity and disregards the commitments made. Joining Schengen is not a favor granted to Romania or Bulgaria, but a situation of normalcy and necessity for Europe. This permanent postponement does nothing but bring a bitter taste of injustice and erode the popularity of the European project and the principle of equality between Member States.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - Accession to the Schengen area is a strategic priority for Croatia. Until we achieve this, we cannot talk about the equality of all members of the European Union. The evaluation procedure for the application of the Schengen acquis in Croatia has been applied since July 2014. We submitted a statement of our readiness for evaluation to the European Commission and submitted answers to 384 questions and translations of all relevant legal acts in August 2015. So far, evaluations have been conducted in 6 areas (data protection, common visa policy, external border management, return and readmission, police cooperation and firearms regulations). For all identified shortcomings and recommendations for corrective measures, Croatia submitted action plans to address the shortcomings and most of the recommendations were met. Under the Schengen instrument, 120 million euros were available to Croatia, of which 116.7 million or 97.33% were spent. Our goal is to achieve technical readiness during 2018, so that the Council can make a political decision on Croatia's accession to the Schengen area at the beginning of 2019 at the latest. In this sense, esteemed colleagues, we look forward to your support, the support of the European Parliament to this realistic plan.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the implementation of the social pillar (2017/2974 (RSP)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, to start with let me thank you for the opportunity to intervene here today on the European Pillar of Social Rights. The pillar has rightly attracted a very high level of attention. On 17 November at the Social Summit for Fair Jobs and Growth in Gothenburg, our three institutions – the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission – proclaimed the 20 rights and principles of the social pillar. The purpose of the pillar is to serve as a guide towards more efficient social and employment outcomes while taking into due account different socio-economic environments and the diversity of national systems. The tools for delivering on the pillar are in the hands of the Member States, the social partners, civil society and the EU institutions. We must respect national competences, as well as the diversity that exists in Europe. We must all do our utmost to make the pillar a reality for our citizens. This is our shared political commitment and responsibility. The pillar sets the framework for various legislative and non-legislative initiatives, including the first legislative proposal on work-life balance, which is currently under discussion in the Parliament and in the Council. The Council is also looking forward to working with you on the proposal to revise the Written Statement Directive. Further initiatives are included in the 2018 Commission Work Programme, more specifically the social fairness package with proposals on a European Labour Authority, access to social protection for atypical workers and a European social security number. As far as the implementation of the pillar is concerned, another very important instrument is the European Semester for economic policy coordination. The European Pillar of Social Rights also ties in with the discussion on the social dimension of Europe taking place in the framework of the broader debate on the future of Europe. During the Estonian Presidency, the Council adopted political commitments to reduce gender segregation in education and employment to facilitate independent living and to respond to the ongoing changes in the world of work. We also reached a general approach on the European accessibility act. I would like to thank the European Parliament for its strong commitment to a more social Europe. Your strong impetus helped to make the social pillar happen. We all agree on these principles, it is now time to put our values into practice. We look forward to working together as co-legislators in an endeavour to promote the social dimension, hand-in-hand with further deepening of economic convergence, implementing and enforcing the single market in all its dimensions by June 2018, just as our Heads of State or Government have repeatedly called for.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on 17 November in Gothenburg, the three European political institutions proclaimed our European Pillar of Social Rights at the first social summit in 20 years. This proclamation is a unifying message to our citizens and to the world. In Europe, we share important social values and we stand ready to defend a shared vision for a fair society now and in the future. The European Parliament had indeed a major role in shaping the Pillar, and I would like to thank the President of the Parliament, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), the President of the EMPL Committee and the rapporteur Ms Rodrigues and the shadow rapporteur Mr Tom Vandenkendelaere and the shadow rapporteurs of the other groups for their steering role and political commitment to the Pillar ahead of the Gothenburg summit. The Pillar is our chance to reconnect Europe with its citizens. As the Commission President rightly said, if we want to be credible, we have to deliver. The time has come to make sure that the Pillar’s rights and principles are effectively guiding our actions at European, national, regional and local level. The Pillar is essentially a joint endeavour. Its implementation should entail full respect of subsidiarity and the division of competences within the Union, as well as of the role of the social partners in delivering employment policies in Member States. This is the message that I have just sent to all Ministers, social partners and all the stakeholders. I strongly encourage Member States to continue their efforts to make the Pillar a reality on the ground, in close cooperation with the social partners and the civil society at large. We, from our side, will make full use of the European Semester. The European Semester will be the key instrument to steer the process of social convergence every year, and we are starting now. The 2018 Annual Growth Survey already makes clear that the Semester will be key for delivering the Pillar. The joint employment report includes the new social scoreboard to monitor areas covered by the Pillar, such as the share of school leavers, the youth unemployment rate or the impact of social transfers on poverty reduction. The employment guidelines – as you know, the legal basis for the country specific recommendations – have been aligned with the principles of the Pillar. We will now bring this forward in our bilateral contacts with Member States within the framework of the Semester, where we will identify together the main challenges. The Commission is already doing its part to translate the Pillar into concrete initiatives. We proposed an initiative on work-life balance, and I welcome the Estonian Presidency’s efforts to make progress on our proposal, and I count on you to deliver on this important file within the mandate of this Parliament. As the social partners could not agree to start negotiations for an autonomous social partner agreement, next week we will present a proposal on the revision of the Written Statement Directive. The aim of this proposal is to increase the rights for the most vulnerable workers. We want to ensure clarity for workers and employers on their contractual relationship, irrespective of the type of the contract. We are also working on a social fairness package, to be launched on 7 March 2018. This social fairness package will include a proposal for a European labour authority and one on a European social security number, to ensure that European Union rules on labour mobility are enforced in a fair, simple and effective way. It will also comprise an initiative on improving the access to social protection of people employed on non-standard contracts and in various forms of self-employment. To achieve our aims, we also need a budget. The negotiations on the financial programming after 2020 are crucial. The European Pillar of Social Rights should be a compass to guide us also in these negotiations. We count on the support of the Parliament for working in this direction and to make the social dimension of Europe visible also in the next Multiannual Financial framework (MFF). We can only build a fair and a more social Europe by working together. Our common goal is to improve the life chances of every European. I count on you to help deliver on all our legislative initiatives that are implementing the Pillar, and I count on all Members of this House to be ambassadors of the Pillar, and to tell your constituents that the European Union stands up for the rights of its citizens.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - The European Pillar of Social Rights was signed on 17 November at the Social Summit in Gothenburg. With these 20 principles, a foundation is laid for developing a number of basic game rules at both the European level and the Member State level. At the same time, a strong signal has also been given that the European story is not only about the economy, but also about the social, that we must move forward in both areas. And that is necessary. The rise of digital platforms and the associated economic revolution is undermining all established principles of our labor market. New forms of work are emerging. Old jobs, such as the man or the woman at the checkout in the store, will eventually disappear and new jobs, such as the Deliveroo bicycle courier, will take their place. Our social security and labor market policies really have to adapt to this. The key question is actually very simple: who will protect those people? My answer is clear: then we must do. Europe must do that and the European Parliament must also be able to do that. In doing so, we should not only focus on fair competition, as we do with the abuse of posted workers. We must also ask ourselves what the new labor market will mean for European citizens. What about pensions, social rights, digital literacy? That's where the social pillar can show us the way. That is precisely the function of the social pillar as a compass. I support the principles of that pillar: equal access to the labor market, the right to aging with dignity, being prepared for digital challenges. But we must be able to do more. We have to convert it into practical rules.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Social Europe is back in European debates and political initiative, and the proclamation of the Social Pillar is indeed a very important moment to make sure that the roadmap for the future of the European Union will be guided by this ambition to update our social dimension to cope with the new challenges. This is the level of ambition we should bear in mind. And we should have a second ambition, which is to make sure that all European citizens, wherever they live or work, in all Member States, can count on a powerful upward social and economic convergence, because we are still dealing with many inequalities, and without stronger cohesion there is no future for the European project. Now, after the proclamation, the time for delivery has come, and let me be precise on the expectations from the S&D Group. We are now really focused on making sure that all people in employment, whatever the kind of job, can count on two very important things. One is a transparent and decent labour contract. This is particularly important for young people. The second thing is full access to social protection throughout the life cycle, and we believe these are two key pieces to building a welfare system for the 21st century. So we are now expecting the Commission to table a legislative initiative on this, now that the social partners could not come to an agreement. But let me also say that we believe that updating social standards and social law is not enough. We need to redirect social policies and economic policies, and that is why the European Semester is so important, because the European Semester must become a powerful process to coordinate these policies for upward convergence.  We appreciate the package presented by the Commission. It moves in this direction, but let me tell you that the big test will come when Member States are confronted with big macro-social imbalances and we need to correct the situation.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! The competence for the European labor markets lies with the nation states for good reason. Each nation state is responsible for what social benefits it can afford and what it cannot do financially. That is why there is also a ban on assuming liability in the euro zone. Every nation-state must answer for the social benefits that it should not have afforded. With the social pillar, the planned creation of a European labor authority in the first half of 2018, the European social security number and various other legislative initiatives, attempts are being made to draw labor market skills to the Union level. The foundations of the European treaties will be changed, because responsibility for politics will also shift responsibility for costs to the European level. This undermines the principle of personal responsibility. Furthermore, one would like to enforce convergence, the economic approximation of the member states, especially within the euro zone. This requires transfers between the Member States. Social rights should lead to the right to transfer. These transfers will create convergence from above, the exact opposite of what was promised to people at the beginning of the Eurosystem. The fiscally responsible countries should share their relative prosperity, if one can speak of it, with everyone. The social rights pillar is not just a catalog of ideas for Member States to use. Although the concerns presented in the 20 principles are not legally binding and the implementation is to be transferred to the responsibility of the national governments, the choice of words, the emphasis on "rights" and "principles" can be used by courts, possibly also by the European Court of Justice, that is actually derived from this Claims.The ECJ has already used political documents of this type in other cases to assess the division of powers.The FCR is skeptical of the social pillar for the reasons mentioned.We reject a substantial work and social model of the EU.Subsidiarity and personal responsibility are our principles, and they used to be the principles of the EU.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: au nom du groupe ALDE. - Monsieur le Président, c’est toujours un plaisir de débattre avec vous, Madame le Commissaire, et d'avoir l’honneur de vous parler, mais je continue in Spanish. Fortunately, it can be said that the year 2017 is the year of the social in the European Parliament and in the European institutions. At last one has realized that we were not a cabinet of financial bailouts and financial policy, but rather an instrument for making European citizenship and the social has to play a primary role at this time. It is also the year in which, together, the fight for inequalities is born and something very important also happens, which is the introduction in the European Semester of the social aspect, the social value, the measurement of inequalities and the attempt to correct them. But of course, we want results. We want something tangible, so it is very good that you already have some things in place and, of course, you do not need to ask us to help you and accompany you. We will accompany them to actively develop this but we will also demand of them. I think it would be good if a prioritization of the topics to be developed and an action plan were carried out - instead of one thing here and another there, no matter how important each one is -, and that with the idea - let's be serious as political - to prepare a new convention in which the social dimension will have to be much less subject to the barrier of subsidiarity. You just heard right now where the problems are coming from. I would also tell you that, of course, the free movement of people should never be impeded, nor should free competition be prevented by setting administrative prices to any factor. But, within that, you create citizens with us through social policy, but for that we need solidarity financing.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! A brief reply to Mrs Trebesius: I do not know whether you can argue with the same self-confidence and arrogance towards the homeless and hundreds of thousands of poor people in the European Union that the European Union should still be a Union in which first the interests of the banks and the economy are served and in which we are no longer interested in what we have in common - the cohesion of the Union. You have just pleaded that we should give up solidarity between people, that we do not care at all whether in Greece, in Portugal, in many Eastern European countries, people have the chance to get prospects for the future, and that they do not give us the same are important, like the people in our own countries, for whom we fight to bring them out of social hardship. So I just want to address one point because I think we're still going around in circles at the moment and the cat is biting its tail. If it has now been decided that the Fiscal Compact will be transposed into EU law, in my view that does not mean any improvement in our situation and the contradictions in which we find ourselves. As long as the priorities in the European Semester are still directed towards not exceeding the debt limit, intervening in budgetary management and allowing cuts, especially in social, educational and health expenditure, we will always come into conflict. I support all efforts to ensure that we strengthen the social security systems in the Member States. But that would also be possible with concrete support from the European Union. We don’t need to break any treaties, we don’t need to break subsidiarity, we have to live up to our shared responsibility. In this sense I support you.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, in defining and implementing these policies and actions, the European Union takes into account the requirements linked to the promotion of a high level of employment, to the guarantee of adequate social protection , the fight against social exclusion as well as a high level of education, training and protection of human health. This, dear colleagues, is the wording of Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In this perspective, we are delighted that the European Pillar of Social Rights has finally been officially validated by European Heads of State or Government. If all the rights set out in this document - the right to equality, the right to education and health, the right to a job and to a decent income, the right to social protection - were realized in practice, the He European Union would have made immense progress on the path to shared prosperity. But now, this catalog of rights is at this stage only a declaration of intent, and we do not yet see the emergence, within the European political space, of a majority to transform it into binding legislation, a necessary condition that these objectives are achieved. We have seen this with the “EU 2020” strategy which gave us the objective of reducing the number of poor people in Europe by 20 million and, three years from the end, that is to say 2020, we can do anything. at most hope that this figure, after having increased by 6 million, returns to its level of 2010. The situation is clearly catastrophic within the euro zone. So, well-meaning people will tell me that the best way to guarantee social rights is employment. The Commission recently welcomed the unemployment rate to return to its pre-crisis level, but at what cost? To that of constrained part-time work, even 0-hour contracts, to that of wages below the poverty line or that of massive exclusions? Even the European Central Bank admits it: the rate of underemployment, twice that of unemployment, is the only true measure of the phenomenon. If work lifted people out of poverty, we would not have 21 million working poor in Europe. The crux of the matter is that, in their choice of economic policy, the majorities in power in the Member States and at the European level go completely against the requirements of the social rights base. What are we talking about? On the one hand, completely counter-productive budgetary rules and, on the other hand, fiscal and social competition between the Member States, all complemented by a weakening of collective bargaining in the Member States and crowned by treaties. of free trade favorable to multinationals. All this can only result in two things: on the one hand, the reduction of public expenditure and investments absolutely essential to the guarantee of social rights and, on the other hand, that of wages, working conditions and social protection. - I conclude, Mr President. Without questioning these political choices, we will have no chance, dear colleagues, of realizing and making the European Pillar of Social Rights a reality, and that is what we expect.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it was 2015 when, in this very House, Juncker, the President of the Commission, presented the idea of ​​creating the social pillar. And on November 17, two years later, so after long gestation times, in great fashion, with great fanfare, in Gothenburg we finalized the creation of a container, nothing more. A beautiful vase that today, however, we have the duty to fill with concrete proposals and effective measures. Certainly an important instrument, which must guarantee social justice, must guarantee hope for all those citizens who today, within the European Union, see their rights and protections increasingly mistreated, from the essential ones, such as housing. , like food, like clothing, to wages, to occupational ones. Today we have an important commitment to make, which is to make an instrument, a base, a truly solid instrument, a vessel filled with concrete proposals. The Commission will probably provide us with the proposal for some directives; those must be the basis for giving concrete answers. Europe asks us for hope, it thirsts for hope, it thirsts for social justice. Here, I believe that starting to put pen to paper legislative proposals that give a real dimension to the need for hope is a commitment. Parliament has already expressed its opinion on the need to create this pillar aimed at upward convergence. The document on which we worked with my colleague Rodríguez is fundamental, and I will never tire of saying that I believe that the European minimum guaranteed income instrument is an effective tool, which can allow the millions of citizens living in poverty and social exclusion to to have guaranteed a dignified life. I believe that upward convergence is done by thinking that the rules do not apply for some and are interpreted for others.Mr Trebesius, I come from a country that has a non-positive vision in the eyes of him.Yet what do we want to do with the surplus from Germany?When will your country decide to take responsibility for the macroeconomic imbalances it has caused in other states?There is a need for upward convergence, yes, but there is a need for social justice.So the rules must apply to everyone, my country will respect them, because it is right and necessary, but it is also necessary that the other countries, those that for years and in a thousand different ways have been damaging certain economies, take on the responsibility of putting an end tocertain practices and policies that certainly damage the economy of others, who unfortunately now live in conditions of poverty and social exclusion.This is not a polemic against him, but I firmly believe that solidarity is a principle on which the European Parliament was founded and that it must be respected.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- The Ministers of Social Affairs have approved 20 principles as social pillars of the European Union and these are mainly socialist principles, which are priceless and deprive freedom.Intervening in the labor market, intervention in wage development, intervention in entrepreneurship, intervention in pensions, the unions are back in power.Now socialist ministers are allowed to pursue socialist ideals, but this is worse.They will be EU principles and soon European values.That is why it is no longer part of our national democracy, we have lost that sovereignty.With this socialist policy as EU law, it becomes illegal to pursue other political principles nationally.Socialism becomes the state religion.Am I now the only one here who finds the European Union getting a little scarier every day?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, with the pillar of so-called social rights, the European Union is even surpassing itself in making black and white. He calls work flexible employment, the constant wandering from part-time work to unemployment, that is, the tombstone to permanent permanent work with rights. He calls gender equality the downsizing of men and women (see: raising the retirement age for women), job security the dissolution of collective agreements, rights and working hours with individual business contracts, linking wages to profits, getting cheaper and cheaper employees for the sake of competitiveness, with active aging, crumbs pensions as an individual affair, while social security in favor of private insurers is dissolved and blackmail to work is done to death. Your social partner and your right hand employer trade unionism is a pillar not of rights but of sharing poverty and social barbarism. You can not do without it, employees can not do with it. These are applauded by the SYRIZA-ANEL government, which is very capable in dirty work, and fearing reactions, is methodizing the abolition of the right to strike, as elsewhere. It will not pass and it will not pass you. The working class will win and live.

name: David CASA
text: - The President, acting as a member of the State Party, shall be informed of the number of cases in which he has been indifferent. Irridu nirrealizzaw li ma teżistix soluzzjoni one size fits all għall-pajjiżi Ewropej kollha, għalkemm l-isfidi huma komuni. Pereżempju, sfida minnhom hija li kull ħaddiem u daddiema tiffaċċja kuljum huma l-isfidi tagana u allura huwa dmir u dover tagāna wkoll li nassiguraw li jkollna pereżempju for the purposes of this Regulation, the Member States concerned. The rapporteur, on the other hand, considers that the balance sheet is a balance sheet and the balance sheet - work-life balance, which does not include the Directive, which is ambitious in nature. Jiena nemmen illi, biex jinkiseb dan il-bilanċ bejn l-iżvilupp ekonomiku u l-bózonnijiet taċ-ittittini, Pilastru Ewropew, allura, tad-drittijiet soċjali se jerġa 'jpoġġi l-aspett soċjali u l-bżonnijiet tan-nies fuq quddiem nett tal-aġenda Ewropea. In all cases, the following conditions have been observed, the first and second part of the application has not been completed and the use of certain substances has been confirmed. In addition, the rapporteur was drafted by the rapporteur, Mr and Mrs Madame Rodrigues, and the rapporteur was informed by a vote in favor of the Parliament.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - The European Pillar of Social Rights is an important example of how the European Union stands up for the rights of its citizens in a fast-changing world, said President Juncker. And of course the social pillar is a new chapter in the social history of Europe. Still, I and many of my S & amp; D colleagues in the EMPL Committee are concerned about whether the social pillar will really become the example of how Europe stands up for the rights of its citizens. The pillar should lead to better access to social security for all, longer parental leave and better working conditions for workers in the platform economy. However, the plans for the reform of the EMU do not take the pillar into account, and the joint declaration to be signed tomorrow does not mention the social pillar. Also in the Commission work program for 2018 there is more emphasis on economic proposals than on social ones, not to mention the competence battle between Member States and the Commission. You no doubt understand my concerns and the concerns of many of my colleagues. After all, it is time for concrete measures to be taken that so many Europeans long for. The European Union is still too much of a market and does too little for the people and that really needs to change after the Gothenburg summit. I therefore hope that we will put an end to the situation where the Commission is pointing to the Member States and vice versa, because the Commission must also come up with proposals. And to the Council, to my own Prime Minister Mark Rutte, I say: a signature in Gothenburg is not free, concrete proposals must be made.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman!The European Pillar of Social Rights is an activity that strengthens the social dimension of the European Union.This is a good direction, because Europe is made up of its citizens, because Europe is people.However, I would like to emphasize that the social pillar should be treated as a road map.So it is good that it is in a non-legislative form.It should support the functioning of labor markets and social protection systems, while taking into account national competences and the principle of subsidiarity, because it is the Member States that are responsible for building social rules and rights, and the European Union can help in this matter.At this point, I would like to draw your attention to a very effective social program implemented by the Polish government.Thanks to an increase in wages, a decrease in unemployment, and the 500+ program according to Eurostat, we are in the first place among EU countries in combating poverty.It is worth following us.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the EU is in the fifth year of the growth – economic recovery – 250 million more people are at work. So yes, it is time to fix the roof when the sun is shining. Some improvement of the necessary living and working conditions, gender equality, etc., is necessary. Nevertheless, Commissioner, I feel that a social pillar might be just partly about it. The bigger part is about minimising the extreme-right parties. We have realised that they are creating a problem in every single European country, making it impossible to form the government, spreading xenophobia, etc., which are serious problems, and therefore we started to fight them by closing the borders and starting to be protectionistic. I feel this is the wrong way to go. It might jeopardise growth, it might jeopardise openness and mobility, and it might end up by not minimising the extreme right. Then we have a double problem. The social dimension is the right strategy if we want the EU to be something more than a single market, but do not let it be nationalism and protectionism. We need openness and growth, and we need to protect it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I noticed in your speech, you were talking about this social chapter as being an important tool to be used against political parties in their own countries. Do you think that is the primary purpose of legislation and ideas coming out of Strasbourg and Brussels – to interfere with the democratic process and to combat parties that you personally don’t agree with?

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your question. As I said, the Social Pillar is necessary to fix the things that have not been fixed. Minimising the influence of extreme-right parties is not something that I will be sorry about, and if this is done, I will be happy. But the problem with that is, as I said, that we cannot let it be protectionism and nationalism by itself. We have to keep openness, we have to keep growth, and we have to fight for it.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, colleagues, social pillar! 99% of European citizens have been waiting for him for 2 years. They still do not see adjustment of its application. In order to be able to implement the pillar and impose sanctions where it is violated, legislation is needed, both in the European Union and in the Member States. How is this going to happen; What will be the way to commit the Member States to implementing social policies based on the European pillar? And I still ask you: How does Article 9 of the Treaty apply? How are European policies controlled by their social implications? Ladies and gentlemen, we need to implement binding social indicators in order to be the pillar.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: - Mister President! What happened in Europe 60 years ago is really like a historical miracle. People who had met on the battlefield shortly before, who should actually hate each other, pulled themselves together, and the project “European unification” was born. If we want to continue building this “European unification” project for the next 60 years, then we have to show the same courage and the same vision that people had 60 years ago. I believe that a very central point will be whether we manage to achieve more social justice within the European Union. The pillar of social rights is an important first step. But we should actually go further: we need a legally binding document on social rights enjoyed by all EU citizens. We need more legislative proposals, such as a minimum income directive or a Europe-wide minimum wage, to really show people that the European Union is getting a more social face. Sixty years ago something was written in the contracts: namely equal pay for men and women. Today we are still so far from that goal. It really is high time the Commission finally presented something in this area too.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, the Social Pillar: yet more lefts talking about rights. A wonderful example of the superstate trying to control every aspect of our lives. Interference in every single way. Terms like ‘social protection’, ‘economic convergence’ – and it’s all tied in to the Single Market. Well, the Europhiles and faint hearts back in the UK, when they tell us about soft Brexit and staying in the Single Market, what they really mean is staying in this: having this kind of stuff imposed upon us and told what we can and cannot do. Control over our lives. No say for the national parliament. What this is about is no control of our personal working lives, no control over our businesses, no control of us over our society. The answer that must ring clear, certainly from the United Kingdom, to this – and I would urge all of our friends in Europe to say the same – is no, no, no. Only a true and clean Brexit for the United Kingdom will allow us a true, independent democracy. And we will then free the individual from the ever-growing, ever-grasping deepening clutches of this superstate.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Mr President, we can only support, in principle, the idea of ​​non-negotiable social standards between European countries. It should be remembered that despite promises of prosperity and full employment, the European Union today has 18 million unemployed and 119 million people at risk of social exclusion. In France, between 2005 and 2015, a million new poor joined the ranks of French people living below the poverty line. The situation is only getting worse as the growing instability of work, through what the Commission modestly calls "atypical contracts", leads to the emergence of the precariat as a new social class. In fact, the working poor now represent 9% of the working population. The incantations in favor of common social standards will however remain a dead letter, as this general pauperization results from the race to the bottom between Member States since the pay differentials range from 1 to 10. Sign that the European Commission has no intention of dealing with the evil at the root, the reform of the posted worker set the tone by maintaining the attachment of the worker to the social system of the State of origin, which is the main cause of social dumping. Once again, Brussels therefore deplores the effects of which it cherishes the causes by staying the course of a Europe of free trade, contrary to the will of the people.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: - Mr President, twenty years, it will have taken us twenty years to have a new social summit. The last one was Luxembourg. This is to say if Gothenburg was expected. Some ask the question: is this base anything other than a communication operation? Well, I think this question shouldn't arise, because we don't have a choice, we don't have the right. This social floor must represent a window of opportunity to relaunch the idea of ​​a social Europe, but this will only be possible if the Member States do what they have to do. They need to take their responsibilities. European construction cannot continue without a real social footprint. This is why we have to put economic and social issues on the same footing. At the start of the legislature, Jean-Claude Juncker pleaded for the social triple A. Well, let's go, it's high time! We need a clear and precise roadmap, with legislative proposals, with dedicated resources. A first step can certainly be the establishment and reform of the "written declaration" directive. It is also necessary to continue to organize the mobility of salaried workers, in the most balanced way possible, and in particular to work on the coordination of social security systems. But today, too many women, too many young people, too many disabled workers, too many migrants, too many people suffer from insecurity. It is essential to have the collaboration of States so that the Union puts in place the mechanisms for coordinating policies and appropriate financial instruments. It must be an added value. Social Europe is a necessity, it is indispensable for the future of the European Union.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Mr. president. Now that in the European Union we are recovering a moderate optimism from the hand of the economic recovery, after having spent a few years of heart attack, it is time to face the scars, the very serious and deep scars that they have left behind the years of the great recession. Social scars that have above all a common pattern: inequality. Inequality between countries, divergence - when we were a converging machine - and inequality within countries. An inequality that has generated pockets of poverty, fear, uncertainty, and resentment. Things we have seen every time we opened the polls on the continent in recent years. And it is in this framework - in a time of social fractures - that the European institutions have agreed on a European pillar of social rights. A positive step, a step in the right direction, a modest step - it must also be said - that wants to establish opportunities, working conditions and social protection. Which for us is seen, for the socialists, as the soul of the European project. But we need this soul to take shape, to take shape in the form of binding regulations, public policies, instruments and resources necessary to regulate working conditions in the face of precariousness and wage devaluation; to fight against gender discrimination; to face the pockets of child poverty that we have. And to do all this also within the framework of the European Semester, the true machinery for the coordination of economic policies of the Union. That is why we are disappointed that the Commission's legislative agenda is still poor. This cannot become another source of frustration for citizens. We have in our hands the opportunity and the need to regain the legitimacy of Europe and to move from being seen as a cold tool of globalization to a warm home that protects citizens. That's what the pillar of social rights.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr Chairman!The European Pillar of Social Rights covers three categories of objectives and tasks, namely equal opportunities and access to employment, fair working conditions, and social protection and inclusion.It's a good idea, it's a good document.It is very important that the document allows for the application of the diversity of social policies of individual member states.It is only a guideline and not a unified duty in creating social standards.This document is also a kind of European response to the negative effects of globalization as a fair equalization of disproportions.We strongly demand that Europe become an authentic ambassador and model of social values.However, we are opposed to any attempts by the Commission to unify the social security system in individual Member States of the European Union.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Social Pillar is the historical embodiment of the European spirit, that is, this ambition for progress, this desire to always do more and better, in short: this constant non-conformity with the achievements of life and history . The European spirit was born from the Battle of Salamis and the defeat of obscurantism. It is based on Greek philosophy and Hellenism, on Roman law, on Renaissance humanism, on the illustration of the Enlightenment and on the triumph of scientific rationalism over myths and superstitions. This idiosyncrasy of Europeans means that only 7% of the world's population produces more than 20% of the world's wealth and spends around 50% of all social expenditure on the planet, allowing Europe to achieve peace, freedom and freedom. democracy, collective welfare levels unmatched anywhere else or any other time in history. And it will be this European spirit that will soon allow, through the robotization of the economy, to free man from the oppressive and alienating aspects of work, transforming him into a voluntary contribution to the economic, scientific and cultural development of humanity.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: - Sir. Chairman! Dear colleagues. If you now become unemployed after the next election, you can, for example, come to Denmark and work in Rungsted for less than DKK 22 per hour. Or harvest vegetables in Tåsinge for DKK 24 per hour. The fact of the matter is that workers around the EU are being pressured. Their working conditions are worse now than they have been for many years. This is partly due to The EU's single market, which allows employers to move their labor around according to where it suits them. And if they fall on the scaffolding or get injured, then they do not have to wait for much help, because the social cuts that follow from the fiscal pact and the European Semester have pulled the safety net away under the vast majority. That is why it also sounds hollow when the EU elite last month launched a social pillar to solve the problems. After all, the European Semester and the Internal Market are enshrined in the EU's fundamental treaties and take precedence over everything else. And then "a social pillar" becomes just fine words. And if there is something they can not use on the scaffolding and in the nursery, then that is fine words. If we want to put action behind the words, we must break the treaties and put trade and social rights first.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr President, the scars of austerity are enormous: twenty million unemployed in the European Union; 25% of the population at risk of poverty; increasingly temporary, precarious contracts; young people with very damaged prospects for the future ... And it is evident that we currently have a problem of political choice with the fiscal regulations that we have adopted and a problem of institutional coordination that puts our social and fiscal systems in competition. And now we want to make a social pillar, which is a good idea, Commissioner, but we are concerned about what is behind the social pillar. You announced today the revision of the Information Directive in writing, but I have to tell you that this was already planned before the social pillar. Also the new package of work and family conciliation measures, that was also foreseen by the withdrawal of the proposal for a Directive on maternity leave. With which, news we have the new employment agency and the social security number, something important but limited. I make two proposals: a directive on minimum income and a directive on minimum wage. Let's be a little more ambitious, please.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the Göteborg social summit on November 17, 20 points or principles supposed to constitute this European social base were adopted. Big and beautiful declarations of intent are still the best thing Eurobeaters can do. But consider, for example, the question of the minimum wage. Six Member States, and not the least, do not have minimum wages set by law or by cross-sectoral agreement: Denmark, Italy, Cyprus, Austria, Finland and Sweden. And among the other States, what disparities! In France, the gross minimum wage is around 1,500 euros, as in the Netherlands, Belgium or Germany. In Luxembourg, it is almost 2,000 euros, but it is less than 500 euros in no less than nine countries, even going down to 275 euros in Romania. How can we not believe that harmonization will lead to a race to the bottom? But beyond these disparities that cannot be eliminated with a magic wand, the fundamental problem with all your catalogs of good intentions is the total lack of questioning. The European Commission claims to provide solutions to problems for which it is largely responsible: budgetary austerity, unfair intra-European competition, with in particular the posting of workers, a single currency whose rigidity and management penalize the economies of many our countries and, of course, the removal of border protections. We used to talk about the "social pillar", now it's the "base". The Commission is thus trying to create an illusion of stability, but the European Union is - you know - more fragile than ever. In a recent interview with a Belgian daily, you said, Commissioner, that “we want competition to be fair”. So you recognize that it is not! But signing free trade treaties in all directions is not the way to fix it. Mrs Thyssen, your portfolio includes “mobility”.I know that is a buzzword, a real imperative of ultraliberal ideology.But it is clear that the dogma of the free movement of capital, goods and people is, by its excesses, ruining our countries.You have the ambition to make recommendations to Member States in social matters.You recently lamented, and rightly so, the declining birth rate in Europe, and Mr Juncker never misses an opportunity to encourage immigration as a false response to this problem.Rather, you should suggest social and fiscal measures to encourage births that our nations could then implement.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - Yes, we must all improve together in Europe, there can be no doubt about that. And yes, the EU must work on that. We need a socially fair Europe and a social pillar could be a big step in the right direction. Member States must be supported and encouraged by Europe to make social progress. I fully support such European social initiatives. But - and there is an important but - the pillar should not be an excuse for an ever-increasing European extension of competence contrary to what the member states agreed in the treaties. Subsidiarity and proportionality are very important principles. These ensure that social policy is adapted to the needs of the citizens. A one size fits all approach in social policy simply leads to a one size fits none result. This realization should really sink in and I regret that this is not or not sufficiently present in the current concrete proposals regarding the social pillar.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, the usefulness of the social pillar will not be measured in grandiloquent proclamations devoid of content, but in its effective implementation, and it will contribute to improving the working and living conditions of workers. We make several proposals to him from Parliament. The first, that they listen precisely to the legislative proposal of the unions, starting with the reform of the Directive of the written declaration, so that the conditions of employment of all workers are explicitly recognized. They have to promote a framework directive of minimum incomes, carry out inspections and controls that kill the false self-employed and also with letterbox companies in the single market. Specific proposals that we have been demanding for a long time and that cannot be delayed to the next legislature. The Council and the Commission must ensure that the rights recognized in the social pillar, the right to a decent salary, to a decent job, to collective bargaining, to social protection, are interpreted by analogy with the rights already recognized in the European Social Charter, making them binding and unifying the international regulation of social rights with the European acquis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - President! I welcome the fact that the European Union has put in place and declared its principles on social rights. I am convinced that an effective and successful economic policy must always precede social policy. Social protection for citizens will be sustainable if it has the economic cover. If there is sustainable and non-credit-based economic growth and job creation, it can be spent on social goals and so people will live better. The same is true for people with disabilities. For years, I have been emphasizing that they should also be basically thought of as employees. Hungary has been on the right track in this area since 2010, and the results speak for themselves. Unemployment is around four percent and the number of employees is changing since the change of regime, the highest since 1989, with 4,445,000 people currently working, or 775,000 more than in 2010. So 68.7 per cent of adults of working age work, 3.5 per cent more than in France, for example. But the work is not over, we must continue to do everything we can for our citizens.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - Yes, ladies and gentlemen, we do have a pillar of social rights and twenty principles that define the future and essence of social Europe. And, indeed, I very much welcome the fact that we are finally realizing that the European Union has no future if we do not invest in people's lives, in our social policy. I am, in fact, very grateful to Commissioner Marianne Thyssen and Commissioner Věra Jourová for presenting the draft directive on reconciling work, family and private life. At the same time, however, I appeal to both the Presidency and the Member States as to why I do not see the harmonization of the Work and Life Directive in the priorities of the Eighteenth Declaration. Indeed, it is essential that paternity leave, parental leave and leave for sick family members be paid in part, at least as proposed by the Commission. I therefore strongly urge the Member States, the Presidency, the future Presidencies to take this very seriously, because it is absolutely necessary in our aging Europe, given the demographic situation. And I address Commissioner Marianne Thyssen together, and we Social Democrats have repeatedly said that it is necessary to lift some twenty million children out of poverty who live in a wealthy family in the European Union, so a European child guarantee is needed more than ever. I think it would be a very good result if we had such a guarantee in the implementation of the social rights pillar in particular.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! Welfare tourism and social dumping have been some of the cornerstones we have seen since the EU began to interfere in countries' social policies. SU and child benefit, which are sent out of a country like Denmark and sent to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe in particular, are the consequence of the interference that the EU has already made in the countries' social systems. With the social pillar, we are getting another rambo into national welfare schemes. I am sure that the European Court of Justice will use the new charter to once again extend the interference that the EU is already making unjustly in the countries' economic and social policies, and there can only be a clear and resounding NO to it. , that the EU must move even further into the engine room of welfare states. Especially because we in Europe have chosen to organize ourselves in 28 different ways, and therefore it is only fair that the taxpayers found in the different countries pay for their own citizens and not for the whole of Europe.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the twenty principles listed in the said Social Pillar constitute a hoax, an attempt to whiten the policies of the European Union and to propagate the idea of ​​compatibility between labor and social and political rights that objectively limit or deny them. Social justice is inseparable from economic policy. A truly social Europe is not compatible with the policies of the euro, banking union, economic governance, the European semester, militarization, securitarization, the constant attack on sovereignty and the development of peoples. The Pillar is an exercise of intentions contradicted by those policies, and empty of concrete measures, which promote the effective fight against the serious existing social problems. A truly social Europe is only possible based on the uncompromising defense of working with rights, collective bargaining, real wage increases, a fair redistribution of wealth and tax justice, social protection supported by universal and quality public services, universal access and free to health and education. It is not compatible with European Union policies or the interests it protects.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, recently I have had the opportunity to meet with entities that fight against extreme poverty and, although they consider that the social pillar is a very important step, they value it as a mix between hope and skepticism . It is true that the signing in Gothenburg highlights the political will of the European institutions and the Member States to move towards a fairer and more equitable European Union, but, Commissioner, we have raised very high expectations and my concern is that we do not get to fill them. Ratification is a sign of the political commitment of all member states to prioritize social aspects in their policies. Commitment that must be reflected and that requires the joint responsibility of all the institutions, including the social partners. Many European countries already have social aid, but if finally we cannot count on a larger Union budget, as would be desirable, we have to achieve a better management of existing aid so that it is truly effective and reaches the most excluded citizens. And for this, Commissioner, we need the support and participation of NGOs that work with the most vulnerable, as well as people living in poverty, since their knowledge is key so that the policies directed at them are the most appropriate.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, on 17 November the Presidents of Parliament, Council and Commission personally and solemnly proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights. Its articles state that delivering on the Pillar is a shared political commitment and responsibility, while for the proclaimed principles and rights to be legally enforceable, they first require dedicated measures and legislation. It now seems, however, that the Commission considers this to commit principally the Member States. President Juncker, in co-presenting the way forward on 28 November, stated that: ‘You can be sure that the European Commission will continue to play a strong role in this endeavour’ [How?], ‘notably through the country—specific recommendations in the European semester process’. But this is woefully inadequate.
