The joint declaration on the EU’s 2018-19 legislative priorities just being adopted mentions only at the very end – and almost as an afterthought – that progress is also needed on social protection and social rights, referring to the 20 Pillar principles. More, the social fairness package promised by the Commission as a concrete follow—up on the Pillar, has totally disappeared. This sort of delivery has shown the whole Pillar exercise to be no more than a feeble excuse for further aggravating austerity, including by injecting the so-called fiscal pact into the Treaties, thus in actual practice delivering another severe blow to social Europe. Do not deceive yourselves. The people will not fail to notice.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Mr President, the right to lifelong learning or the right to personalized protection in the event of unemployment are not rights, but entitlements. The difference between a right and a claim is that a right, such as the right to freedom of expression, costs nothing. While claims cost billions and billions of euros. This is nothing new. In the years before the elections, populists across Europe promised, and guaranteed after the elections, the demands that cause huge debts today. Best seen in Greece. The populists promised 100-month severance pay and huge pensions, a number of rights, in fact claims, and thus bankrupt Greece. But Spain, Italy, Portugal and France are also taking public debt from one record to the next, as populist politicians have promised people things that no one can pay. And it is in Greece to see how difficult it is for people to give up their rights and how willing they are to take to the streets. That is why I recommend to the European Commission not to drive Europe into socialism and bankruptcy.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, for the first time in ten years the European Commission recovers the word social and this makes us happy if it means that it finally realizes that the recipes for dismantling the social state have only generated more poverty, more precariousness and more inequality . Among the proposals of this social pillar there are positive advances such as the proposal for a Directive on conciliation, which, however, must undergo important changes if we want it to be truly effective in the fight for equality in the labor market and not to perpetuate gender distribution in care. However, most of the new social rights that are mentioned are not so new because they are already included in the European Social Charter and the new legislative proposals are for the most part directives that needed to be reformed. Europe must talk about why wages are still so low, why inequality continues to grow, why quality jobs are hardly being created and why there is more and more social exclusion. As long as we do not make a 180 degree turn in the economic and social policies of this Union, we will be talking about an absolutely empty social pillar.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Social development and the improvement of living and working conditions are inextricably linked with economic development. Sustainable and sustainable growth can be achieved by combining policies that support investment and employment, while supporting initiatives that strengthen social cohesion and compensate for regional disparities. That is why I believe it is right to include the European Pillar of Social Rights in the economic governance process of the European Semester. This will allow better monitoring of the implementation of the pillar's assumptions and will send a clear signal to the member states that social and employment aspects are inextricably linked with economic governance. The latest Annual Growth Survey report shows positive trends, a decline in unemployment and a reduction in poverty. The European economy is back on the growth path and this is a good time to focus on increasing investment and productivity, which must be followed by wage growth and improving working conditions. In this area, the task of the Union is first and foremost to support the Member States in reforms that stimulate growth and increase social inclusion, as they are primarily responsible for implementing the Pillar's commitments. I also hope that in its activities at the EU level, the Commission will rely on proven instruments, such as the European Social Fund, which has almost a quarter of all financing under the European Union's structural and investment funds. It is also important to speed up the work on the European Skills Agenda.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Social Europe is often invoked in Sunday speeches. But now it's about delivering real results. We can no longer watch how the distribution of prosperity in Europe continues to diverge, we must not watch when labor law is trampled across Europe, when we look at the new plans for social regression in Austria, for example - the unspeakable 12 -Hour working day - and we must not watch when the citizens lose their faith in the dream of a Europe in which everyone benefits from prosperity and our children are better off. Neither nations nor miraculous forces of the market will save us. So we have to save ourselves and act now. The social summit in Gothenburg was just the beginning. Minimum social standards must apply to all member states, because only with minimum social standards, minimum income schemes and the prevention of wage and social dumping can we overcome the east-west divide and the north-south divide.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I think this is a very important element of European legislation and European policy, and it shows that Europe is leading the way towards a modern social economy. We need a pillar of social rights for a social market economy to be successful and competitive, now and in the future as well, and that the living and working conditions in Europe converge for the better for all. The world of work and our societies are changing fast with globalisation, digitalisation and changing work patterns, and also with communications. We have plenty of opportunities but we also have challenges, and we need to shape these developments and to make very good use of them. Most of all, I think we need to make sure that economic and social developments go hand in hand and that Europe continues to be a world-class place to live and to work. The proclamation of social rights by the social partners is very much welcome. I also think the social scoreboards are very welcome, because we know there is a wide divergence between Member States when it comes to social rights, yet we must respect individual States to make decisions for themselves. I think it is very important that we set standards and lead by example and, indeed, set minimum rates. When we look at maternity leave, the highest amount is over 50 weeks, and yet in some countries paternity leave is not yet legislated for. I believe issues such as this, and the work-life balance, are extremely important, particularly from a female point of view. Paternity leave, work-life balance: they encourage women to participate in the workplace, to participate in education, and all in all, increasing the social content and the social progress of our European states.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: - Mister President! Even the former Commission President Jacques Delors knew: Nobody falls in love with an internal market. Anyone who wants the EU to gain support from the population must be able to make it clear that Europe benefits people, improves people's living conditions, not worsens them. Unfortunately, that has not always been the case in recent years. Many people associate the EU with adapting to a globalization that benefits only a few and harms many regions and people. Incidentally, this is also one of the reasons for the growing nationalism, which unfortunately has no prospects. That is why the new discussion on the social dimension of Europe is so important. But warm words are not enough. We need concrete European measures and laws, such as a Posting of Workers Directive that provides effective protection against intra-European wage dumping and social dumping, such as a European child guarantee that guarantees all children access to free education, health care and adequate housing. But we also need a different economic and financial policy that finally puts the focus on combating unemployment, and above all youth unemployment. The beautiful Sunday speeches must finally be followed by legislative initiatives and changed deeds.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of the year, it is traditional to look in the rearview mirror in order to take stock of the past months. 2017 was the year of progress in social Europe, in particular with the proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. These efforts must absolutely continue, as there are still many projects before us: coordination of social security systems, finalization of work on posted workers, work-life balance and, of course, all the issues surrounding digitization. The advent of digital technology will bring about the emergence of new and very diverse forms of employment, requiring the development of workers' skills and, in this respect, education, vocational training, apprenticeship, access to education throughout the world. life-long skills, focused on new skills, which keep pace with technological developments, are essential. The digitization of society and the world of work is leading to a proliferation of forms of employment, which are very diverse and for which we today lack legal clarity. What employment contract to offer these workers? What social coverage should they provide? It is therefore necessary to ensure that the traditional labor rules also apply to these employees. This is what is at stake for the construction of the European Union.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner and colleagues, last week my country, Finland, turned 100. The Finnish story is a rising story. From one of the poorest countries in Europe, it grew into one of the most equal and prosperous countries in decades. A key factor here has been equal social opportunities: counseling, free education, public health care, and the organization and protection of workers. Everyone is involved in the development. Now, with the right-wing government, my own country has become a country that fears the setting of minimum EU standards, upward cohesion and cooperation in sharing best practice. Unfortunately, Finland is not alone in the Council. When did we Europeans start to fear improving people's living conditions? Social investment is a source of economic growth. The EU needs a strong socially binding pillar, as many Europeans no longer recognize the EU as a defender of their rights. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, which is already in force, and with it the rights of Europeans, have been left behind by other policies. Hopefully the Gothenburg Summit was a new beginning.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Marianne Thyssen! Outside this room, Paul Rübig and other Austrian MPs have just handed over the light of peace from Bethlehem to the European Parliament. Here in the Chamber we are debating with the Commissioner responsible about the implementation of the social pillar in the European Union. Both belong together. Social and economic cohesion is an essential prerequisite for peace in Europe. A fairer Europe, a more competitive Europe and strengthening its social dimension are among our common top priorities. In Gothenburg, you could say that we were given a large package by the Commission. In this package there is a kit that we now have to put together with the Member States and in Parliament, which we have to implement. We have already achieved that the social market economy is sustainability, the European regulatory model. We have already achieved that fundamental social rights are part of the Charter of Fundamental, Civil and Freedom Rights. We must now achieve that the social dimension becomes part of European politics in a very concrete way and that we achieve a balance between competition, the economy and the social dimension. The social pillar is a must and it's like a Christmas present. Let's do it!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the social rights pillar reminds us of the current protection of social rights in the European Union and adds some new principles that respond to new challenges, such as the need to ensure a minimum income. I would like to remind you that social policy remains within the competence of the Member States, just as there is a need to respect the different socio-economic situation and the diversity of the Member States' systems. Although I consider the protection of citizens 'social rights a priority, I would like to remind you that all interests need to be balanced, for example, if we want to effectively strengthen employees' social rights, we should also allow new forms of business and employment, such as crowdworking. These innovative forms of work create new job opportunities. So we have before us a political plan for the social sphere, which, in my opinion, should not be detached from economic and political reality.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of the social pillar is one of the most important tasks ahead of us in this parliamentary term. Unfortunately, national differences and diversity are a brake on deepening social policy cooperation. No one questions the need for a stronger commitment to promoting, for example, gender equality. However, a topic that is particularly sensitive and long-term for employees across the Member States of the European Union is the general inequality of access for employers, especially large companies with operations in several EU Member States. As we have supported the Posting Workers' Directive in the past, we will be very pleased and expect you to show similar helpfulness and support in closing the often abysmal pay gap between workers producing the same products for the same employer in different EU countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the implementation of the social pillar is a necessity for the European Union. But this cannot be done as long as the EU leadership pursues policies of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment that dismantle the welfare state, slash wages and pensions and fill Europe with millions of poor people and armies of the unemployed. Only when the European Union abandons the neoliberal choices will the way be opened for the triple social leap of the Union. Social Europe presupposes the institutionalization of a European minimum wage, a European unemployment income, an unemployment benefit and a European minimum income. The leadership of the Union must therefore abandon bilingualism and crocodile tears for the realization of the social pillar, because it has enormous political responsibilities for the 123 million European citizens who are threatened by poverty and social exclusion.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, social services in Cyprus, Commissioner, but also in other Member States are collapsing. Cyprus is probably the only country in the European Union without a National Health System. Hospitals and doctors and hospital staff are unable to cope with the big problems. Older people wait up to tens of months to get a critical examination of their lives. While the memorandum in Cyprus is implemented to the letter, its only element with a social dimension, which is the National Health System, is faltering despite the efforts of both my party and the Minister of Health. What about pensions? The other day we had a group of visitors from Cyprus and I was ashamed on behalf of all of us, when an elderly lady told me that she lives on a 300 euro pension and has to pay for food, housing and medicine. After all this, how can I come out and defend your point of view and tell the citizens of my country that the European Union is defending their social rights?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me thank you first of all for this vital debate. Let me continue if you will allow me, dear Mr President, in my mother tongue - in Dutch - because I know that we have a perfect interpretation service here. The proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights, ladies and gentlemen, is ultimately, as we all know, a start. It is a good thing that we are having a good debate here today, because we ultimately need to build on a social Europe here. We must discuss the next steps together. I see this debate today as the start of that debate. We have set ambitious goals, most certainly. We have said that we want more convergence in Europe, that we want upward convergence in Europe, that is, better working and living conditions for our citizens. We also said that with our pillar we want to adapt our social institutions to the conditions of the 21st century, to ensure that we have a competitive, a dynamic, but also an inclusive market economy, that we can build a social market economy that makes it possible for our people to have and to take good opportunities in the field of education, training, lifelong learning, access to the labor market, fair working conditions and access to social security, to social protection and adapted accessible, affordable basic services. That is our ambition, no more and no less. And we must of course do this with respect for the internal market, that leaves no doubt. The internal market is also an asset to achieve this. Many colleagues have said in the debate that we ignore subsidiarity, that we are entering the territory of the Member States. I would ask all those colleagues who have commented on this to read the preamble to the pillar. Look at points 17 and 18 in the recitals and then you will see what the framework is that we put together have agreed. We have to make that happen together. We are not changing the division of powers, but that means that the importance of cooperation is all the more important and that is why it is also good that we have proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights together with the three political institutions. This also means that we must take responsibility together, each in his own field, and that we must also work on this in the future. There have also been quite a few comments about the fact that on the economic side the Commission is not quite sure what it wants on the social side and vice versa. Let me point out that we have taken a clearly deliberate approach from the start of this Commission. This applies to tax policy, budgetary policy, our trade policy and the way we deal with the social partners. In the field of tax policy, I refer to the numerous proposals that have already been made by my colleagues in charge of tax policy, Moscovici and others. By the way, these proposals are supported throughout the Commission, by the decisions taken by Mr Vestager, to ensure that we get fair taxes, that taxes are not eroded. We make maximum use of the powers that we have for this purpose. This Commission has a smart budgetary policy. We make maximum use of the flexibility available in the Stability and Growth Pact and we speak to Member States so that we do not have to penalize. That is not our point, but rather encouraging the member states to pursue a sustainable fiscal policy. Because let us not forget that: without sustainable tax conditions we cannot develop sustainable social policy. On trade, I invite you to look at the new trade agreements concluded under this Commission. You will see that there is a lot more attention to the social and to a number of aspects of our citizens rightly expect from us. There is more transparency and more attention is also paid to a number of aspects that may have been slightly pushed aside in the past. And with regard to the social partners, the social dialogue, I would like to point out that this Commission has made and continues to make a great effort to relaunch the social dialogue and in order to build capacity in the Member States, the social dialogue must be launched or should be promoted. We also consult the social partners in much more areas than we are obliged to under the treaty and we like to do this because we very much appreciate their added value, both for the design and the implementation of our policy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen in Parliament, Mr President of the Council, the Pillar Proclamation sends a very clear message. That is a message of unity, a message of hope and a message of action. A message of unity, that we in Europe know what we want together and defend the same values, the values ​​that we have proclaimed together. The Council with a mandate from all 28 Member States and the other institutions have jointly proclaimed this pillar. That is a sign that we defend the same values ​​and we must now prove that we do. The responsibility for this rests with each of those who have signed and proclaimed this pillar. It is also a sign of hope, because it gives hope to the people that we are doing things, that we know that the future is in our hands and that if we have a good policy we can shape that future in such a way ' In a way that all people can count on us to accompany all changes in society and in the economy and that they themselves, and also their children, still have a good future. It is also a message of action, because we have taken joint responsibility. This should give a boost to everyone to act effectively on the words one has itself proclaimed.That is also the atmosphere, ladies and gentlemen, that I have felt here today in this debate and that strengthens me, as far as I am concerned, to continue working from the Commission on the implementation of that pillar.Because it ultimately comes down to realizing that pillar in the field.We have promised a lot and we will all have to work on it now.If we keep our promise, each in their own field, and if we are all ambassadors of that pillar together, then we should succeed.That is the task that awaits us.As mentioned, that pillar is a beginning and not an end.It depends on us what we make of it, but I'm optimistic.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I wish to thank the Commissioner and the honourable Members for a very rich and timely debate. It is clearer than ever that the European Pillar of Social Rights is a widely supported initiative. It will bring about tangible improvements in the living and working conditions of our citizens thanks to the engaged involvement of all stakeholders at all levels.  When it comes to the implementation of the Social Pillar, account needs to be taken of the different starting positions and situations of the Member States. The country-specific recommendations in the framework of the European Semester offer essential instruments for ensuring that all Member States strive towards the same goals. The European Pillar of Social Rights gives a solid embodiment to our common values within the EU. It is reassuring to note that there is a broad consensus across the Union and its institutions on these values.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - I will never tire of repeating it: it is essential that the Union reduces the economic and social gap between its Member States, starting with the Mediterranean regions and the lagging regions. This is the only way to create the conditions for true European citizenship, to create a more united and stronger Europe. In this sense, I believe that the Gothenburg Summit sent a clear message, inviting us to deal with the enormous differences that still mark the reality of European citizens, from the search for work, to opportunities for women and for new businesses, up to assistance for the weakest citizens. The welfare systems of the Member States are now called to face completely new challenges. Europe must lead this process, respecting the specificities of the different cultures but aiming at a single goal: to lead the whole Union, without exception, into the new global economy, through fair opportunities and inclusive, sustainable and harmonious growth. Listening to the social partners was at the heart of the final drafting of the European Pillar of Social Rights. Its implementation must also be inclusive and shared, and focus on the needs of young people and work.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. The process of building a European pillar of social rights is proceeding at a particularly slow pace. At the same time, tens of millions of people across the European Union are in daily distress over their work, their health, their social security and their living conditions in general. It is therefore not enough to have the lengthy wish list that we voted on here in the European Parliament in January this year, nor the joint declaration of the Commission, the Council and Parliament in November, which merely repeats the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. We need concrete policies to improve the real living conditions of the people, based on financial instruments from the Union budget. Such actions may be the granting of a European unemployment benefit, with emphasis on cases not covered by nation states, such as the hidden unemployment of the self-employed, the strengthening of the national health systems to cover the cost of pharmaceuticals in very serious diseases at high cost, the subsidy of students participating in the Erasmus programs to cover the cost of accommodation and much more. We need deeds, not words.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - In a changing Europe of the labor market, it is important to take into account the changing realities of this market - for example, the advanced digitalisation of society requires a development of the digital skills of the labor force. It is also why it is very important to clearly define the content and role of the European Pillar of Social Rights, as well as how to ensure equity and social justice in Europe. There is already a strong social dimension in Europe, but there is a need to focus on increasing the contribution of social Europe to Europe's global competitiveness. At the same time, I believe that the social pillar must provide a positive project for all European citizens, regardless of the region in which they live and throughout the life cycle stages. I also believe that it is beneficial for its provisions to apply to all Member States of the Union, in order to ensure equal opportunities and access to the labor market for all citizens, as well as fair working conditions and social protection and inclusion.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The so-called “Social Pillar” is more than a kind of social facade that you want to place in a structurally antisocial building. It does not detract from the intention to level below the living and working conditions in Europe. On the contrary, it gives you shelter. Social justice is inseparable from economic policy. A truly social Europe is not compatible with the policies of the Euro, Banking Union, Economic Governance, the European Semester, militarization and securitization, the constant attack on sovereignty and the development of peoples. It is clear that, while discussing the “Social Pillar”, it is decided to internalize the so-called Budget Treaty in the EU legal order. This Pillar is a fray of intentions contradicted by those policies and a vacuum of concrete measures that promote the effective fight against the serious existing social problems. A truly social Europe is only possible with the uncompromising defense of working with rights, collective bargaining, real wage increases, a fair redistribution of wealth, tax justice, social protection supported by quality and universal public services, universal and free access to health and education. It is not compatible with European Union policies or the interests it protects.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - In 2016, over 40 percent people employed in the EU worked under non-standard contracts or were self-employed. It is estimated that at least half of them do not have sufficient access to social protection and related benefits. The European Pillar of Social Rights, which is part of the work undertaken by the European Commission towards a deeper and fairer Economic and Monetary Union, should contribute to the proper application of international labor standards and to the modernization of the social acquis. Moreover, the standards contained in the European Pillar of Social Rights should be applied in all countries participating in the Single Market, and the legislation and governance mechanisms needed to achieve them should apply to all EU Member States. It is important to ensure that social protection systems are balanced and fair. Workers must be protected, whether they are employed under standard contracts, new types of contract or are self-employed.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. –The social pillar should be the backbone of the EU, but this should not be a slogan but must be reflected in concrete measures for social cohesion. We still have many poor citizens, children living in poverty, social inequities, lack of access to the labour market for people with disabilities. Closing the borders and protectionism will not solve the social problem, nor will non-admission of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen increase well-being in the other states. The concept of the EU, the philosophy of its existence, consists of solidarity, social cohesion and the security of citizens’ lives. Together, Member States are stronger, but there is a need to improve the mechanisms that increase social cohesion and improve the lives of social generations.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - The head of the European Commission indicated the establishment of a social pillar within the Union as one of the priorities of his term of office. The idea is the most noble, because everyone should be protected regardless of gender, place of residence or work. Currently, the disproportions between women and men, inhabitants of towns and villages, or those working full-time or within flexible forms of employment are very large. We need good solutions under the principle of subsidiarity. Defined at the Gothenburg summit, the document contains good ideas and good proposals. It should be agreed that everyone has the right to quality education, training and lifelong learning in order to maintain and acquire skills that will enable them to cope effectively with changes in the labor market. This is extremely important because in the coming years we will observe radical transformations related to the development of new technologies and the progressive automation and robotization of the economy. Only quality education and lifelong learning are the right answer to these challenges. In addition, we must accept that the era of full-time employment is ending. Therefore, innovative forms of employment should be supported, but only those that guarantee high-quality working conditions. Nevertheless, actions in these areas should be undertaken taking into account the specificity of individual countries and regions.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - It would appear that the ins and outs of the European Social Pillar of Social Rights (EPSR) are not changing despite the work carried out in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee (EMPL). The EPSR always seems to reflect the need for the European Union "to operate a paradigm shift towards a strong European social model": in short, harmonization and therefore unfortunately a race to the bottom! Europe has existed for many years, and each of the states that make it up (we are not talking about member states here but sovereign states) has successfully adapted, according to its own needs, taking into account the particularities of each profession has its own social model. We must preserve these peculiarities and strive upwards by exchanging good practices, and not deconstructing! Beyond harmonization, I denounce a more serious underlying desire: that of propaganda aimed at passing the EU off as the only solution to citizens' problems, the desire to save a damaged European project, without carry out the necessary reforms in depth.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - The European Pillar of Social Rights was proclaimed in Gothenburg on 17 November. A step in the right direction, with which the European institutions have committed themselves to putting the social dimension at the center of their agenda. But the time has come to follow the words with the facts. To do this, it is necessary, first of all, for the list of twenty principles and rights to become a concrete tool for influencing the social policies of the Member States. This can be done through the European Semester tool and the inclusion of social indicators in specific recommendations to Member States. Secondly, it is essential that the pillar becomes a tool for relaunching concrete EU legislative initiatives in the field of social policies. The Commission's proposal for a directive on balancing family and work life and a revision of the directives on contracts, working time and posted workers is therefore welcome. Finally, for the pillar to become an effective tool, it is essential that it becomes a tool for a review of the economic governance of the eurozone. In this respect, the idea of ​​a social scoreboard is good, but, like S & amp; D, we propose more incisive measures, starting with a "common European scheme against unemployment".

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I am pleased that the idea of a European Pillar of Social Rights, presented by the European Commission at the beginning of its mandate, is taking on a more concrete form.It is true that inequalities in the labor and social markets between Member States must be lower than they are at present, and this should be pursued by the governments of the Member States.However, we must be aware that we will not achieve this if countries do not adopt key reforms.Only on a well-off economy that is able to respond to shocks and adapt to them can we build a just social system.A healthy economy will bring a regulated market with fair working conditions, adequate and sustainable social protection, equal opportunities and access to the labor market.Good action at Member State level will provide the strong social system that Europe so desperately needs.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: written. - Thanks to the social pillar and its 20 principles, social policy is finally back on the political agenda as a priority. Of course I welcome this. However, there is a life-sized "but" that threatens to dampen the festive mood. The social pillar may be full of good intentions, but it remains an informal "compass" that member states "can" but should not use to improve their social systems. As long as the social pillar remains a symbolic gesture of goodwill, it is in danger of being pushed aside by Member States when it really matters and workers want to assert their rights. For me, the social pillar must lead to concrete measures and enforceable legislation to provide, among other things, protection to all workers, regardless of their status. People in temporary or on demand contracts should also be able to enjoy better protection. In addition, unpaid traineeships and zero-hour contracts should be banned and better legislation on maternity, paternity, parental and caregiver leave should be ensured. I therefore call on the European Commission to take legislative initiatives to meet the expectations of the social pillar and the Council to deliver on its promises and to support concrete measures, funding and legislative initiatives.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- Social justice is inseparable from economic policy.A truly social Europe is not compatible with the policies of the Euro, Banking Union, Economic Governance, the European Semester, militarization and securitization, the constant attack on sovereignty and the development of peoples.The Pillar is an exercise of intentions contradicted by those policies that are empty of concrete measures that promote an effective fight against the serious existing social problems.A truly social Europe is only possible based on the uncompromising defense of work with rights, collective bargaining, real wage increases, a fair redistribution of wealth and tax justice, social protection supported by public, universal and quality services, accessuniversal and free access to health and education.It is not compatible with European Union policies or the interests it protects.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: written.- After many years of political pressure from Social Democrats, the Commission has presented a proposal on the “European Pillar of Social Rights”.For the first time in the history of the European Union, “social Europe” is placed on the agenda.The proclamation on the Social Pillar sets the roadmap for a Social Europe.The declarations of intent must be followed by concrete measures such as a framework directive for decent working conditions, basic security for children in poverty, the European Labor Authority and minimum social standards for all member states.It is high time we regained the confidence of workers across Europe.Only a social Europe is a just Europe.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the 2030 Agenda and the Eurostat report on "Monitoring progress towards the EU Sustainable Development Goals" (2017/3006 (RSP)).

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the EU demonstrated strong leadership in the negotiations that led to the adoption of the 2030 agenda and its 17 Sustainable Development Goals in September 2015. We must continue to lead the implementation phase as well. After agreeing on what to do, we now have an obligation to do it at national as well as at the EU level.  The joint adoption of the new European consensus last June is certainly a very important step, as it will guide both the EU and its Member States for the next 12 to 15 years. The Member States have been leading by example, notably through voluntary national reporting in the context of the United Nations High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development. However, more needs to be done in terms of implementation at the EU level across all policies – internal and external. The Commission Communication of 22 November 2016 was a step in that direction. However, the Council, in its conclusions from 20 June 2017, urged the Commission to elaborate by mid-2018 a comprehensive implementation strategy to reflect the 2030 agenda in all relevant EU policies. The Council largely shares the views expressed by the European Parliament in that regard in its own-initiative report that was adopted last July. The EU needs a clear vision of how all relevant EU policies will contribute to the realisation of the 2030 Agenda in a comprehensive and holistic manner. At this stage, the Council is certainly looking forward to receiving more specific sectoral implementation proposals from the Commission. In this respect, the Council adapted its working methods to be better able to monitor the implementation of Sustainable Development Goals at EU level in a holistic manner.  The Council, under the Estonian Presidency, established a dedicated Council working party that will deal with the Agenda 2030. The mandate of this working party will be to ensure systematic, effective, participatory, transparent and integrated follow-up and review of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals at EU level in order to track progress, assess achievements and ensure accountability.  The working group starts its work in early 2018 and will be reporting to the General Affairs Council. Also, in November the Council welcomed the first implementation monitoring report on progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals in the EU prepared recently by Eurostat. Even though this is still early days, the report provides useful insights in terms of trends, showing that our performance is on the right track with some goals, but less so on several others. However, there is a need for a fully-fledged analysis of gaps and a comprehensive EU implementation strategy to ensure that all policies are covered, both internal and external. This will allow the EU to remain a global leader in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, with the signing of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development on 25 September 2015, 193 countries from all regions of the world committed themselves to implementing the 17 Sustainable Development Goals and 169 related targets to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure prosperity and peace.  The 2030 Agenda prescribes a regular follow—up and review of progress towards the SDGs as a crucial element to support accountability to citizens. Governments have the primary responsibility for follow—up and review at national, regional and global levels. To follow up and review the goals and targets, the 2030 Agenda foresees the development of a reference indicator framework for global monitoring, complemented by indicators at regional and national levels, which will be developed by the Member States. The European Union has its own monitoring process. The Commission Communication on ‘Next steps for a sustainable European future’ of November 2016 announced detailed and regular monitoring of the Sustainable Development Goals in an EU context. It also announced the development of a reference indicator framework for this purpose. On 20 November 2017, Eurostat released the first monitoring report. This monitoring report is based on the European Union SDG indicator set, which the Commission developed in cooperation with a large number of partners and stakeholders, including the European Union Member States, Council committees, academia, civil society and international organisations. The indicator set will be regularly reviewed to make sure that it includes the most relevant and highest-quality indicators and that it aligns with the UN global indicators. The European SDG indicator set includes indicators which are relevant from an EU policy perspective and which are already available. They include detailed information on gender, age groups, regions, educational level, degree of urbanisation, income, and disability. Fifty-six of the 100 European Union SDG indicators are also part of the UN set.  Eurostat’s monitoring report builds on Eurostat’s long experience in monitoring sustainable development in the Union. As a matter of fact, from 2005 until 2015, Eurostat regularly monitored progress towards the objectives of the EU Sustainable Development Strategy. The report finds that, over the last five years, the European Union has made progress towards all SDGs. Progress for some goals has been faster than for others and within the goals movement away from the sustainable development objectives also occurred in specific areas. The European Union has made significant progress over the last five years towards the overall achievement of the goals concerning affordable and clean energy, responsible consumption and production, life on land, sustainable cities and communities and good health and well—being. But let us be clear about this progress. In this way that progress towards a given goal does not necessarily mean that the status of that goal is satisfactory for the European Union. For example, in the case of terrestrial ecosystems, the indicators mostly show good progress, but this should not lead to the conclusion that ecosystems or biodiversity in the Union are in good health. As an example, common bird species have been declining in the Union since 1990 and only recently showed signs of slight recovery. We also have eight SDGs in which the European Union has, over the last five years, made moderate progress. These concern quality education, partnership for the goals, industry innovation and infrastructure, gender equality, decent work and economic growth, no poverty, zero hunger and reduced inequalities. These results are visually presented on a newly created and dedicated section of Eurostat’s website, which I invite you to consult. There you will find links to additional products, a short brochure, and a series of online articles in the style of Wikipedia, which aim to reach the widest possible audience. To conclude, monitoring progress towards the implementation of the SDGs is essential to meet the expectations raised by the 2030 Agenda. Eurostat will continue to evaluate and improve the list of indicators and produce annual monitoring reports. Next year, the Commission will present a reflection paper ‘Towards a sustainable Europe by 2030’. It will be accompanied by a ‘distance to SDGs’ analysis to provide, in addition to the trends, an understanding of the distance we still need to cover in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in the sustainable development goals there are two sides – firstly to decide how the European Union is acting towards third countries and the rest of the world to get the goals right, and there, indeed, I think we need quite a lot more and better coherence.  Then, on the other side, when we look inside – and I thank Commissioner Thyssen for mentioning this – when you are getting closer to the goals or you have progress that actually does not mean that you have achieved the goal or that the progress would be anything else than just nominal as we can see in biodiversity or in the state of oceans when we refer to life below the waters for example, and other such matters, with the climate effect actions that are being dictated here in Europe very heavily at the moment. That is why I congratulate the Commission and Eurostat on being so effective, of having effective indicators and the Eurostat monitoring scoreboard where we can see the actions. What I would hope is that we could have in the future this sort of sustainability or end goal so we could really measure how close or far we actually are from the sustainable achievement or target itself. The second point is that to be really effective inside the EU, I hope that you could work with the Council in the future so that we could get this monitoring on all of these 17 points to the European Semester so that we could follow up and monitor effectively what the Member States are doing.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, sustainability is not just a buzzword. It is a sine qua non for the future of our planet and for the future of our people. Therefore, reaching the sustainable development goals within the EU is vital. To do that, today we now have the Eurostat monitoring report, which should show us the way in the progress that we are making within the European Union. Let me be frank. There is something fundamentally wrong with this report. It says that we are making progress and we are moving in the right direction. It gives us nice arrows and these arrows are painted in hopeful green, but when we peel off the green glitz, we are left with an unsatisfactory report lacking the essential data, focusing on the past and missing the point of the universal character of the SDGs by not taking into account their interconnection nor their impact on EU policies. You could say that, in times of fake news, it is good to have data. Of course that is true, but when you look at the data and you see that, for instance, the 1% is being qualified as progress of the highest category, then we are fooling ourselves. Some say that 15% is a good way forward in the 12 years to come, but if we know that we need 40% to get, for instance, the Paris climate goals in place, then we know that we are fooling ourselves. Heading in the right direction is not the same as being on the right track fast enough to go in that same direction. As you mentioned, Madam Commissioner, some of these SDGs will not be met. They are in your portfolio – no poverty, reducing inequality, decent work. That is really worrying, because it outlines that we do not sufficiently take into account European policy and governance. Let me conclude. We need to revise our measuring tools, using better indicators and data and providing a clear plan for the future. You need to do that not just with Parliament, but also with NGOs.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the goals for sustainable development are at the heart of the political debate today. The survival of our planet is at stake neither more nor less. These objectives adopted in 2015 by 193 countries seem to be reduced for some of our Member States to an essentially academic function. Indeed, their implementation is slow to start. This is not surprising, because this is not the first time that announcements made with great fanfare have not been sufficiently followed up. This is particularly the case for official development assistance. Announced four decades ago, we are still only halfway towards the target of 0.7% relative to GDP. The reason for this failure? It is the lack of a method for obliging Member States to report on the objectives to which they have subscribed. However, the same causes produce the same effects, which is why it is important now to equip ourselves with a method to achieve the objectives for sustainable development. To this end, it would be desirable to know the strategy of each Member State. In addition, it seems to me essential to specify a time axis to know who does what and when. So that these efforts are not in vain, the establishment of a parliamentary control system seems essential to me. Said system of parliamentary control and supervision should respond to the prerogatives of both national parliaments and the European Parliament. Member States responsible for significant gaps in the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals should come to the European Parliament to report on their political action in this area. It is not enough to go to New York, to be generous in the podium of the United Nations, to return to your capital and to rely on the short memory of those to whom you have made very strong commitments. This concerns both the interior and exterior shutters and when it comes to sustainable development, we are all developing countries, including within the European Union.We are all in the same boat and all have the same accountability to our citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. Little progress has been seen since the 2030 Agenda was approved, two years ago. It is urgent to increase political will, to prioritize the objectives of sustainable development. To this end, the European Union and its member states should appoint political leaders who have the power and, above all, the political will to guide the entire government and advance this agenda; establish a structured and clear government process to implement the agenda, involving all ministries; and carry out a thorough and honest analysis of deficits, clearly indicating where there are contradictions between policies. And so we would be strengthening the principle of coherence of development policies. We must also adopt an implementation plan to meet the agenda that encompasses national and international policies, especially trade policies, and establish a robust monitoring framework, in the private sector as well, because not a single goal will be achieved if we are not capable to regulate the behavior of our companies, and for that we need binding rules on due diligence. Therefore, it is incoherent to sign the Sustainable Development Goals while we continue without developing, for example, binding legislation in such deadly value chains as textiles, or if we continue to obstruct the process for the creation of a binding treaty on companies in the United Nations and human rights. Otherwise, we will be going back to business as usual: nice words, pompous objectives and, in practice, we will be working in the opposite direction. At this rate, neither in 2000 nor in 3030 will we reach our targets.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the SDG agenda is deeply social in the sense that the core and underlying principle is ‘leave no-one behind’, and this is most appropriate following the debate that you have just led, Ms Commissioner, on the implementation of the Social Pillar of the European Union. This is of course what we also have to practise in our external programmes and policies. There needs to be a deep commitment to fighting inequalities and in favour of equality.  Basically, the challenge for me would be that we cannot go on taking decisions as if it were business as usual. We cannot work in silos, and I think this has been understood but not really implemented yet. For instance, in our House we don’t have a mechanism, to my knowledge, to make sure that our efforts for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals are concerted and coordinated. I think we should all together think about a mechanism for how that could be done, because we need to reach true coherence in our policies.  In fact we do have some ideas already from existing policies. We do have the notion of policy coherence for development, which we have been insisting on very much, Mr Goerens, for at least five years if not longer. We should use the mechanisms that we have been able to put in place for Policy Coherence for Development and expand them to all Sustainable Development Goals. We also have the Commission’s Trade For All policy paper which has been revised recently and it also gives some instruments and indications for how we should combine our efforts across the board. Finally, the High-Level Expert Group on sustainable finance is just about to publish its proposals. We will have to see how we will improve our investment policies so that they are truly sustainable.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission said a year ago that the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were integrated into all of its ten priorities.Yet the Eurostat report reveals that in just five years, five SDGs have shown significant progress, such as SDG 7 “Clean and affordable energy”, SDG 12 “Responsible consumption and production” oragain SDG 3 “Good health and well-being”.For the rest, there are eight goals that are not progressing significantly.These include SDG 4 “Quality education”, SDG 1 “No poverty”, SDG 2 “Zero hunger” ”and SDG 5“ Gender equality ”.Worse, we learn that due to insufficient data, four SDGs cannot even be studied.Let us be clear, states are still the best placed to achieve the goals they have approved themselves.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, the Sustainable Development Goals are enshrined in the fundamental treaties of the European Union and are also integrated into key sectoral policy projects and initiatives. The survival of our planet is truly the task of us all, it is our own responsibility. As already mentioned here, in September 2015 the United Nations adopted the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in the form of just seventeen goals. The Commission Communication provides a framework for regularly monitoring progress towards these objectives in the context of the European Union. On the basis of this communication, Eurostat is due to issue an annual report and, as my predecessor said, it has issued a report on the fulfillment of these seventeen objectives in May this year. The data collected shows that the European Union has made progress towards all these goals over the last five years. Significant progress has been made on Objective seven "Affordable and Clean Energy", Objective Twelve "Responsible Consumption and Production", Objective Fifteen "Rural Life" and Objective Eleven "Sustainable Cities, Towns and Good Health and Well-being". Weaker progress has been made on the goals that my predecessor has spoken about, I will not repeat, but there is a lack of sufficient information to evaluate four areas: clean water, I am really surprised, also climate action, underwater life and peace, justice and strong institutions. I would like to ask the Commissioner: how can we evaluate areas where we do not have enough information? I think it would be worth considering how to proceed in meeting these indicators in this case.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the publication of the Eurostat report on monitoring progress on the Sustainable Development Goals is good news, but we are still a long way from the monitoring and review mechanisms that we need for the effective implementation of the SDGs. We are still waiting for the Union to adopt a global strategy for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, a strategy that looks to the future, not to the trend of the last fifteen years, a strategy based on a careful analysis of gaps. Red and green traffic lights and arrows are not enough, we need deadlines, targets and effective indicators. Two examples: to welcome a 0.09% increase in public development aid at European level since 2011 as positive is a joke. We are talking about resources that are needed now, not after 2030, as well as using GDP as the only indicator for sustainable economic growth, and I could go on. Progress in one area does not necessarily mean being on the right track, and in some cases reasoning without quantitative targets based on mere percentage increases can be very deceptive. We have set ourselves a deadline, 2030, unfortunately few politicians work on time horizons that go beyond the next elections, but here we need to make an effort. The 2030 Agenda is unique in its kind, it is universal and the objectives are deeply interconnected, this requires us to respond to new challenges, new challenges that we can only respond to with new data, innovative indicators and new monitoring tools. The report therefore does not allow us to draw conclusions on the actual possibility that the Union will be able to keep the commitments it has made with the 2030 Agenda. There is no careful analysis of the impact of Union policies on sustainable development, which is essential for developing a comprehensive implementation strategy at European level. Finally one thing should make us think: the report shows that on issues such as the fight against poverty, hunger and inequality, the European Union is struggling, it is far behind, let us not forget that we are all developing countries on these new objectives.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mister President! Yes, the Eurostat report is certainly useful for identifying successes and failures. However, we need three other instruments: firstly, mainstreaming all policies towards the SDG goals, secondly, sufficient and coherent funding, and thirdly, political leaders so that the SDGs remain a priority on the agenda. I ask the Commission: is there a governance structure for the SDG checks? What is conceivable in the Commission? The same applies, of course, to the Council and, as colleagues have said, to us too. In Parliament too, we need a structure for monitoring, as Mr Goerens said, and for accompanying the SDGs. Then the question for the Commission: will the new multilateral framework respect what we spend our money on? This is a test at the next MFR. And last but not least, we also need partners in the world. We're talking about climate diplomacy, actually we also need SDG diplomacy so that we don't just do it in Europe, but others too.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the Eurostat assessment of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) progress in Europe shows that good progress has been registered on the sustainability of cities, cleaner energy and responsible consumption. This proves that when the EU has a strong collective strategy, progress is possible. However, at the other end of the spectrum, we find the reduction of inequalities and the elimination of poverty, plus gender equality, remaining at moderate progress only.  So what does this say about our societies? These results show that Europe must focus on improving the lives and well—being of the most vulnerable. Growing inequalities are not only a lost economic potential, as this report demonstrates, but they are also at the root of rising populism and extremism, which sows division in our communities and threatens European values.  Years of austerity politics have only made things worse, in particular in my country, as well as in Greece, Portugal and Spain. I want to reaffirm that the number of children living in, or at risk of, poverty in our societies in 2017 is simply shameful. We need to adopt the EU Child Guarantee now.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome as well the Eurostat report, but at the same time I stress the importance of regularly revising the EU SDG indicators set, so that the latest remain in line with future policy developments and progress. According to the findings, overall the EU made progress towards the 17 SDGs over the past five years, with progress for some goals having been faster than for others. However, we have to remain cautious because advancement towards a given goal does not entail per se that the status of the respective goal is satisfactory for the European Union.  Moreover, I would like to put forward some remarks. The report does not provide enough information to develop conclusions on whether the European Union’s efforts will be successful in attaining the SDG targets by 2030, and fell short on measuring the EU’s impact on sustainable development from a global perspective. Therefore, this shortcoming sends a strong signal on the need to revise the indicator set, to fill the existing gaps and to put in place a more ambitious and comprehensive monitoring system.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! A little over two years have passed since the proclamation of the goals. It is therefore glad that in five of the seventeen of them significant progress has already been recorded. This is a good sign that gives hope that by 2030 the assumed goals will be achieved. The first positive signals, however, cannot be an impulse to become complacent. First of all, the Eurostat report indicated that in almost each of the individual objectives there are indicators that have remained unchanged or even deteriorated in recent years. In particular, the lack of progress in reducing inequality and poverty is of particular concern. The Union is presented to other countries as a model of a well-conducted social policy. It can be seen, however, that we still have room for improvement in this area. Moreover, the European Union should focus not only on achieving its own goals, but also working with the United Nations and other countries to achieve sustainable development in developing countries.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I was at the United Nations in 2015 with Commissioners Timmermans and Mimica and Ms Mogherini when the development goals for 2030 were declared, and at the same time it was announced that there would be a strategy. Unfortunately, this is not yet available, which is very regrettable. It is high time we developed a European roadmap as Europe has to present its results in New York in 2019. The Eurostat monitoring that is under discussion today is far too short-sighted. For example, I will fix this to goal 12 of sustainable consumption and production - very sketchy and not yet fully developed. The global importance and impact of supply chains, especially the textile supply chains, would offer the opportunity, among other things, to address and improve aspects of consumer protection for EU citizens, working conditions in Europe, and in particular working and environmental conditions in the producing countries. When I was in New York again this year on the subject of SDGs at the United Nations, Denmark and Estonia presented their SDGs and their work on them using the textile supply chain. I ask the Commission to finally make the progress originally announced in this urgently needed area and finally to develop activities here.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the European Union is committed to meeting the 17 goals of sustainable development and eradicating poverty around the world, at a time when even now the Troika is imposing harsh policies on the Greek people, policies that have reduced pensions at least 40%, policies that have slashed wages, policies that have led 40% of the Greek people to live below the poverty line. The European Union must therefore end bilingualism. The indicators show that in Greece and in Europe the people are unhappy. They show that in Europe of 28 at least 123 million Europeans are at risk of poverty, while 9.6% of the population is severely disadvantaged. Achieving the goals of sustainable development requires a change of policy in Europe, requires funds for social Europe, requires the activation of European funds and the European Central Bank, which must direct the billions of euros of quantitative easing to strengthen the real economy and not the casino economy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, the European Commission has presented us here with an over-optimistic view of the situation in terms of achieving the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. Unfortunately, the reality does not meet this view. Poverty and social inequality are deteriorating, the destruction of biodiversity continues, man is constantly deteriorating his natural environment in the European Union but of course outside the European Union and - you know - in today's globalized economic space what is happening in our neighborhood is having an impact and to us. We therefore need a stronger mechanism for monitoring progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and, of course, a funding mechanism for the Member States to achieve these goals by redistributing them from the strongest to the weakest Member States, and we also need a reorientation. in our foreign economic policy, so that free trade takes place only within the goals and constraints set by the need to achieve sustainable development.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the analysis of Eurostat data on the current situation of Europe in relation to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals reveals a not exactly encouraging picture. Some steps forward, actually few, have been made in the area of ​​sustainability, especially with reference to the environment, clean energy, responsible consumption and production, health and well-being, but too little social progress has been made. The quality of education, employment and the fight against poverty, hunger and inequality have not made significant progress, and this means that we are leaving behind large and too many sections of the European Union. The initiative of the social pillar is therefore welcome, as long as it is not limited to being a declaration of intent. Unfortunately, due to lack of data, we are unable to assess some of the most important sustainable development goals: the fight against climate change, peace and justice. As I have already mentioned elsewhere, our monitoring systems must be improved to avoid that poorly set policies cannot be revised due to the impossibility of fact checking.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members of Parliament for their engagement in this important debate. I would like to stress that for the Commission the importance of achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is beyond dispute. The Council has invited the Commission to prepare for the first EU report on the internal and external implementation of the 2030 Agenda by the EU at the United Nations High-Level Political Forum by 2019. We are starting to prepare for this report with the Reflection Paper due in the second half of 2018. The Reflection Paper is part of the discussion on the future of Europe. It will include the reflection on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change as well as the reflection on economic and societal changes. I repeat that this Reflection Paper will be accompanied by a ‘distance-to-SDGs’ analysis to provide, besides the trends, also an understanding of the distance we still need to cover.  The Commission also established, as you know, the SDG multi-stakeholder platform, and there the European Parliament and the Council will be closely associated with the work. You will be engaged via the relevant institutional fora. Moreover, in relation to development policy, the Commission will produce a joint synthesis report with Member States on our implementation of the consensus, including the impact of their actions in support of the 2030 Agenda in developing countries, as a contribution to the EU reporting to the High-Level Political Forum. Some honourable Members mentioned that there are no data for four indicators. It is true that those data are missing. Eurostat is working on it, together with the United Nations, to define those missing indicators. I can tell you that in Europe we have much more data than is available at the United Nations. However, in some cases, data series do not exist and therefore we cannot now show progress in the last five years – I hope it will be progress we can show and not regress, of course. I can tell you that in the future this will be possible, and it will also be possible – I say it again, also possible – to look at the distance from goal. Let me tell you also that the current list of indicators is not fixed in stone; indicator development will continue and the EU framework will be adapted accordingly.  Mr President, dear Members of Parliament, Mr Minister, having said this, the SDGs are sharply formulated goals, and those goals address the main questions of our time. We all know that. Making progress on them is not easy and does not come quickly. That should not be a surprise to any of us. But we also know that we have to measure to know, and indeed monitoring our performance is the first step to knowing where we stand, which in turn is the first step to making progress, and that first step is now taken. I am looking forward to continuing to work together with all of you on the many, many next steps on our way.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the debate today shows the key importance of coherent and objective monitoring if we want to be serious about implementation of this transformative 2030 Agenda. But we need to have a truthful and objective measure and assessment of our performance and progress in line with the United Nations requirements. To that end, future reports should provide indications about the gaps to targets and not just about trends. This is key. I can assure Mr Leinen that the new dedicated working party in the Council will also look at the issue of accountability. I am very happy to hear the Commission being responsive to the Council’s call to prepare a fully-fledged strategy outlining timelines, objectives and concrete measures to reflect the implementation of the 2030 Agenda in all relevant EU internal and external policies.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The discussion is over.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: in writing. - The Eurostat report on the progress towards the EU SDGs shows that we have achieved a lot in this regard, but a lot remains to be done. Progress under Objective 3, which includes an increase in life expectancy and a decrease in deaths from chronic diseases, is to be welcomed. The increasingly better implementation of Goal 7, related to lower energy consumption and increased use of renewable sources, is also a good forecast for the future. On the other hand, the report shows that we need to do more to achieve Goal 1, in particular to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty. I hope that the present improvement in the economic situation will allow us to deal with the effects of the financial crisis that we are still feeling. The unsatisfactory result in this and other spheres proves that the European Union and its countries must make every effort to achieve the goals of sustainable development by 2030, not forgetting to support partner countries in this respect. Research carried out by NGOs shows that almost 40% of the Member States do not plan to adopt national strategies to implement the SDGs. That is why I would like to ask the governments of the EU Member States to create plans and coordination structures for the implementation of goals, which will allow progress to be achieved where it has been insufficient so far.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next point is the Council and Commission statements on the EU Civil Protection Mechanism with the same operational capabilities (2017/2975 (RSP)).

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, only in October we had a debate here in this very Chamber on the tragic forest fires in Portugal and Spain. Therefore, I would like to start by thanking the European Commission for having very quickly delivered a legislative proposal to amend the Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism. The Civil Protection Mechanism is a good mechanism. It is a very concrete expression of European solidarity, focusing both on the response and on supporting the Member States in preparing for disaster. But the context in which we operate today is evolving rapidly, as we discussed in October. We are faced with an increased number of disasters with a high impact on lives and infrastructure. Forest fires, which hit several Member States in recent months, have shown that we have gaps which affect our capacity to respond effectively to disasters and that we need to prevent and prepare better. I will not go into the details of the Commission’s proposal, which by now is well known to you. Let me just say that this is a very ambitious proposal. It merits a thorough examination by the Council as a matter of urgency, bearing in mind the importance of European solidarity, but also of national responsibility. Discussions will start in the Council as early as next week. In parallel, the Presidency would encourage the Commission to work together with the Member States on all possible intermediary measures which do not require a change in the current legislation. These can bring immediate, concrete improvements, allowing for faster deployments of Member States’ capacities, especially in view of the next forest fire season. The Council looks forward to working closely with the European Parliament and, indeed, the European Commission on these matters.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Estonian Presidency for its support in these ambitious proposals and I am sure that we are working together in order to reach our common goal.  I am grateful for your initiative to debate our proposals to strengthen the Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism and create Rescue, the new structure for our mechanism regarding civil protection. In 2017 we witnessed intense forest fires, floods, hurricanes and earthquakes, disasters that claimed human lives, damaged properties, livelihoods and of course the environment, not only inside Europe but also across the world, and unfortunately the list is long. As the Minister has already said, devastating forest fires in Portugal, also in Croatia, Spain, France, Italy, Greece – an extended fire season that lasted until the end of October. It is a very unique phenomenon because, of course, of climate change. At the same time, Hurricane Ophelia in the UK and Ireland caused severe floods, deadly storms also in Greece, Germany, Poland, the Czech Republic, storms that are ongoing and that keep producing disastrous floods. Albania is the most recent victim. Natural disasters have become more frequent and more intense. Their effects are more unpredictable, all the more for emergencies that can completely overwhelm the national capacities and national resources.  I am proud, as Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management, of the support we could provide for such crises through our current system, our current voluntary pool Civil Protection Mechanism. I would like once more to thank all our Member States that have actively contributed to help countries that are victims of disasters and emergencies. But the reality on the ground is different today. Climate change has changed the game, and unfortunately this is our new reality. Maybe this is our new normal and we must adapt and be prepared to face this new reality. I strongly believe that European support in disasters and emergencies is strongly needed. As you know, this European support is based on voluntary contributions by our Member States. But it is very hard, and I saw on the ground – it was a very painful experience even to me and other ministers – it is very hard for any of our Member States to help one another if they both face disasters or risks at the same time, simultaneously. What happened recently in Portugal is the most painful example. Countries with strong records of solidarity could not help Portugal this time because they were also facing forest fires at the same time. It is clear that the current voluntary system has reached its limits.  Three weeks ago you know that the College of Commissioners adopted my proposal with the strong support of our President, Jean-Claude Juncker, to upgrade the current system of the Civil Protection Mechanism and create Rescue. Rescue? What is Rescue? Rescue is a structure based on two pillars.  Firstly with Rescue our Union will have its own capacity with command and control to respond to disasters. You can think of Rescue as a safety net when national capacities and national resources are not enough. In essence, Rescue means that no European country will stand alone when facing forest fires, floods, hurricanes, earthquakes or epidemics.  Let me stress one critical point. Rescue will not replace national capacities. I would like to repeat, it will not replace national capacities. It will support and complement national capacities and resources. I am very firm on this point. The primary responsibility to prepare for and respond to disasters remains with our Member States. Through Rescue we will also increase financial incentives for our Member States to make their own capacities available to others. This will be the European Civil Protection Pool.  The second pillar of these proposals means prevention and preparedness. I want to be frank on this. Solidarity comes with responsibility. Prevention and preparedness are at the heart of a comprehensive response to natural disasters and emergencies. Member States have to improve their risk assessment, their risk management plans. We are here to help them and we will also help establish a common cultural prevention and preparedness. It is quite important to see and to improve this culture of prevention.
