For this to be done, Member States need to be supported through the Structural and Investment Funds, and they also need to be supported through all related Union policies and instruments. I am thinking of environment, climate, health, research and others.  Dear colleagues, Rescue demonstrates the Commission’s commitment to strengthen the EU support to our citizens when natural disasters or emergencies threaten their lives and their properties. Today, I am here to ask for your support for these proposals. I know many of you have already expressed your interim support, and thank you so much for this. I am sure that through our exchange of views we can do more to cultivate all aspects of these proposals. I am looking forward to listening to your remarks and thoughts.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commissioner for his words and I also thank the Council. I'm sure we'll do a great job this time too. In particular, I share 100% of the words spoken by the Commissioner, when he said that perhaps this in which we live is the new normal. It is no coincidence that every time, Commissioner, that we have been in this House debating these issues, a natural disaster had just happened or was underway. Fortunately, less serious than the others, but even in recent days a wave of bad weather has hit our Europe, and Italy in particular. We still have, for example, in Emilia Romagna and other regions thousands of displaced people, interrupted connections, enormous damage. Then it is not enough, we have seen, even if effective, what the European Union has put in place is not enough, above all, as you said, when several countries are simultaneously having to face the same catastrophe, the same disaster. Well, we need this review. We need to increase the ability to act quickly and effectively, but above all we need to strengthen prevention and preparedness, which are the basis, as you said, but are also the best way to prevent the loss of life and the huge losses, including economic ones. So we need to work on this and improve access to structural funds, all the support possible. Let's not forget that securing our territories is also a huge economic driver, therefore an absolutely win-win thing for us. I therefore thank the Commissioner's proposal: let us remember that the citizens want this thing.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, I would like to start by saying that I welcome this initiative by the Commission, an initiative that means doing more Europe because it means fighting common challenges from unity and solidarity. First of all, my congratulations. The catastrophes of 2017 have shown that our resources are insufficient: more than two hundred fatalities - one hundred in Portugal in the last fires - and one million hectares burned in the last year, which is three times more than what was burned in the last five years in the European Union. In short, consequences of climate change that are devastating and that need a more coordinated and stronger action. But it is not only climate change, it is also earthquakes or health threats such as Ebola or Zika. Ultimately, the resources are insufficient, which shows us - as the Commission stresses - that we need a permanent mechanism with its own resources and also one that has comprehensive action, from prevention to reparation. And, focusing specifically on the Commission proposal, I would of course like to underline the specific area of ​​climate change and four aspects. Anticipation: in order to prevent, we need to evaluate the risks well and for that a risk map of the different regions that also includes the water resources that we have in the different regions. Complementarity: we need a sum of efforts, as the Commissioner has well said, not substitution of resources from the Member States. Coherence: coherence between all the political and financial instruments of the European Union and especially on climate change. It is a global challenge that requires coordination and transversal actions. We would need a specific body for climate change, capable of facing - as I say, in this coordinated way - this great challenge. Y reparation: specifically, the Solidarity Fund.We have to modify the Solidarity Fund.We have seen in recent catastrophes that it is insufficient, that it penalizes those regions that are large when evaluating global GDP and not real wealth by GDP per capita.We need to modify it and also introduce the environment as a criterion for repair.In short, despite everything I have said, I think this initiative is a great success and I offer all our support so that it sees the light.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, in recent years, due to climate change, we have witnessed enormous natural disasters. Fires are burning the forests of southern Europe. Floods are hitting our cities and villages. Recently in Greece we mourned 24 victims of the deadly floods in the city of Mandra, in Western Attica. In addition, Egelados visits more and more often Greece and Italy, which are affected by catastrophic earthquakes. It is therefore clear that, in addition to the national civil protection mechanisms, the European Union must build an ancillary civil protection mechanism, which will act as an aid to national authorities in complementary dealing with the consequences of natural disasters. At the same time, the European Union must allocate increased resources through the European Solidarity Fund and the European Regional Development Fund to compensate the victims, to repair the damage and to strengthen the logistical infrastructure of the national civil protection mechanisms.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Civil Protection Mechanism cannot be effective, as its role is undermined by the European Union's general policy, namely the policy of austerity and memoranda, which deprives the mechanisms of the necessary operational means. But there is a question of responsibilities in disaster prevention. I am referring to the recent tragic disaster that occurred a month ago from the floods in Mandra and Nea Peramos, near Athens, where 24 people drowned. The risk of flooding in this area was known on the basis of the preliminary flood risk assessment studies defined by Directive 60/2007. There are responsibilities for inadequacy and indifference of the governments, which did nothing, because the directive provided that for those areas where the preliminary studies showed that there is a risk, final flood risk management plans should be prepared by the competent Ministry of Environment by December 12, 2015. Here, Commissioner, everyone has to take responsibility, and I want to ask you: When it became clear that the December deadline had passed and the Greek authorities had not implemented the required flood risk management plans, what did your services do? Did they inform the Greek authorities? Did they push and how? Which authorities did they contact? What excuses did they finally receive for the unacceptable delay, which ultimately cost the lives of 24 of our fellow citizens?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the Union financial framework for aid to affected areas helps rebuild and alleviate but does not prevent or deal with forest fires, landslides, landslides, floods, heavy snowfalls, frosts, earthquakes and radiobiological chemical warfare. The Union has adequately planned civil protection through the open partial agreement on major disasters and the Evita and Prometheus projects; but also the Member States, individually, are participating in bilateral and multilateral agreements. The optimization of joint operational procedures and the strengthening of the preventive and repressive capacity of civil protection must be updated and upgraded to the level of a transnational business center and the creation of a mechanism for immediate intervention and assistance to persons and means. I therefore call on all parties to plan and support the creation of joint intervention units with immediate transport and development capabilities, properly equipped and trained, to deal with natural or man-made disasters.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – I hope you will agree with me that we should all congratulate you on your new position as a Vice-President here. It is the first time such a small party has been able to do it. Well done. I wish you all the best in this debate.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you colleague, thank you for these congratulations and I remind you, of course, that you have to use the "blue cards" to ask the current speaker questions, but I understand the exception of the moment.Thanks again.The floor to Mr van Nistelrooij.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - Commissioner and Minister, it is good that you persisted. You were here several times, and this time also the Council, to discuss your approach to the concrete problems. We often noticed that we had some problems to be on time, to respond quickly. You have deposited a good package. But in the EPP we also discussed a follow-up step during the preparation and the Council plays a major role in this. Namely, if you don't pay attention to the province at the same time, then what happened in Attica will happen. If you don't manage your river basins properly - and we have resources for that too - you will get flooded, people will be in danger, you have to act. So start with prevention and use the structural funds. We can do that: use the solidarity fund and other funds up to 95% to do that. So today a compliment, but at the same time an invitation to keep each other on their toes. The Member States in particular, especially the Council, must ensure that we are at the forefront of fighting climate change. We have now discussed with the Commissioner here six or seven times this year. But the problem is largely that we don't have our affairs in order, that we don't have proper risk prevention. That must change.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, throughout this year in this Parliament we have had a number of debates on disasters that have taken on a large dimension due to the new climate change context. It is a dimension and a reality that is new and, therefore, the answers must also be new. In all these debates, after the diagnosis, we concluded that it was necessary to take action. Improving and optimizing response mechanisms at all levels and betting on cooperation at Union level. It is therefore very important, Commissioner, that we are here today to appreciate a concrete initiative capable of giving immediate answers to citizens. Congratulations! This is what the Union needs. It is measures that translate into direct benefits for people, their safety and their quality of life. Measures that mean an increase in European funds and resources and are part of a common strategy. That said, Commissioner, we must not lose the ambition to one day build a Civil Protection Union, but that ambition should further motivate us to achieve rescUE and to take advantage of the increased financial resources and available means. Three ways to do this. In a top down logic, reinforce common means, streamline processes, combine information and share knowledge. Supporting the strengthening of Member States' resources and indirectly creating harmonization and interoperability that will help to improve national prevention and response systems. Finally, promoting cooperation and synergies between the available means, a practice that has occurred on several occasions, but, as I said, with phenomena that are endemic, systemic and transnational, there is often no possible answer for all needs. The amplification of catastrophes is not a theory. It lives with the daily lives of people in general and Europeans in particular. Therefore, the amplification of the response capacity has also ceased to be a theory and this is a good news.Let us put it into practice as soon as possible.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Mr President, Europe's preparedness for natural disasters is an urgent need and can be seen as a complement to the common security and defense policy. Fires, floods, earthquakes and other catastrophes in which people and material goods are killed require from us concrete actions to help citizens, concrete plans and forces for use in such cases. The compassion and solidarity most often expressed by the institutions, including this Parliament, is good and desirable, but we need concrete action and concrete help for the people. Help and action that will strengthen Europe more than all declarations, summits and expressions of sympathy. The establishment of the rescEU civil protection force at European level is therefore an encouraging message and a proposal that simply must be supported. I believe that we are able to implement this proposal, provide good equipment, make a good plan for the use of forces and I sincerely hope, simple procedures for activating forces. Operational forces, if well organized, will significantly improve the ability to respond to crises at European level or as a complement to forces at national level. Of course, as in all other situations, the question of the justification of the investment will arise and if we only analyze the damage from the fires last summer in the member states of the European Union, we will see that investing in civil protection is necessary and justified.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mister President! Commissioner, I think that a Commission proposal has seldom met with such unanimous approval in this House as yours, and you have the people behind you too. According to the latest Eurobarometer survey, 90% of Europeans believe that the European Union and the Member States need to work together on civil protection and disaster relief. They are convinced that civil protection can only really work if the Member States show solidarity. Your proposal contains just that. You made it clear today that we must do two things: in the event of a disaster, be well equipped to be able to provide immediate help. But what is very important, wherever disasters are to be prevented or mitigated, in prevention and preparedness to be really strengthened. Your plan contains that. I believe that it is important to make these funds available as quickly as possible, so that while the Member States are still responsible for civil protection, a functioning civil protection in the European Union can only take place if if we are ready to take European funds into our hands and, in this case, place the operational tasks with the Commission. I wish you much success. I think you already have the approval of this House.

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Mr President, Portugal is a tragic example of the need and importance of a capable European Civil Protection Mechanism. Our concerted and committed effort can save companies, villages, forests, and above all, it can save lives. This year Portugal lost more than one hundred lives which, had this mechanism been operating as we wish and as we are discussing it today, perhaps they could have been saved. We must commit our resources to what matters most, and I emphasize again, what matters most in this Europe that must be supportive, are lives, are people. Fires, earthquakes, floods will always be inevitable. The difference will only be in the way we can predict them, how we can avoid them and, if they happen, how we can face and fight them. This strength will mean the possibility of even joining means that are often dispersed and are not used in favor of all Europeans in the future. Do it yourself, then! It will certainly have the support of all MEPs.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Mr President, I would also like to greet the Commissioner and the Minister representing the Council. Commissioner, congratulations on your proposal and the work you have done. We all know the number of lives lost this year in the European Union and in my country, more than 100 people lost their lives as a result of the fires. This proves that the solidarity of the European Union must be materialized in concrete actions and this materialization is also done with this new initiative. We cannot, however, deceive ourselves. It is true that it is essential to strengthen the European Civil Protection Mechanism, but more important is the need to strengthen prevention. And that has to be the bet. And this is not the only fund that exists or will exist for solidarity, structural funds also serve for solidarity and must be used, first hand, for prevention. And that responsibility is in the hands of the Member States and it is the Member States that have to assume and embody the saying that prevention is better than cure. I also want to end by saying that for new priorities we need new resources, additional resources, and therefore I congratulate you on the fact that in this proposal you use the flexibility instrument. I hope that the Council, too, realizes this simple thing that for new priorities, additional money, new resources and, therefore, our proposal will always be that we do not accept reallocations and that we use the margins and the flexibility instrument.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, natural disasters and risks know no borders. Too often we have been in the reaction and not in the anticipation. European solidarity in the face of disasters must go through strong actions. This is what is being undertaken today, under your leadership, Commissioner, and I congratulate you on it, with the 280 million euros committed until 2020 and the implementation of an independent capacity reserve. I was going to say "finally!", Because I am one of those who have been calling, and for several years, for the pooling of capacities and the strengthening of resources for enhanced European civil protection. I am thinking here, precisely, of a European fleet of Canadair, a project that I also fervently defend, with my colleague Renaud Muselier, president of the Provence-Alpes-Côte d´Azur region. Water bombers in the colors of Europe would be a strong symbol of a concrete Europe, to the aid of the populations. I am also thinking of the European network of hubs for civil protection and risk management, the result of the preparatory action that I brought to the European Parliament and which was approved in the 2018 budget of the European Union. Precisely, Commissioner, the Nîmes-Garons air base, in France, which you know well because you inaugurated it, the flagship of French civil security, could serve here as the first pilot base at European level to accommodate new capabilities. It is now up to - as has already been said - the Member States to say in concrete terms how they intend to contribute to the efforts that we are undertaking. This is why I called on the President of the French Republic on this subject, so that France can concretely defend, at European level, the need to better prevent risks and, above all, to protect reactively thanks to to renewed means.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, congratulations on your election as Vice-President. Disasters are becoming more frequent and complex across Europe. The effects of climate change have hit many Member States hard in recent years. Just a few months ago, Portugal and Italy in particular faced a number of summer fires that had never occurred before. Against this, the current disaster response tools are limited and often unable to provide rapid assistance to Member States during a crisis, because the current production mechanism is based on a voluntary system and on additional capabilities that Member states can offer to another country in need. The creation of a system capable of increasing disaster response capacities in the European Union is undoubtedly going in the right direction, increasing integration and solidarity between member countries. However, prevention and preparedness remain the cornerstones of an effective response to natural disasters. By concentrating funding on these two activities we will be able to increase our risk management capabilities, minimizing the economic damage, but above all avoiding precious loss of life.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, saving lives must be the concern of national authorities, but also of those at European level, and I congratulate you on thinking and wanting to introduce a new mechanism. We need to strengthen civil protection, the ability of the population to react. Prevention is also needed in terms of fire prevention, but in order to prevent it, we need education, we need to understand and know the risks. Unfortunately, climate change leads to natural disasters, fires, floods, landslides. They are loss of life and I strongly believe that we cannot leave it to the national authorities alone. That is why I strongly believe in a European mechanism, in solidarity, in mutual support, in sharing positive experiences from one state to another, and, ultimately, we also need a budget, because we need certain specific endowments. for interventions. We need to take this into account in the future, as well as the need to have adequate funding.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister and colleagues for their support, first of all because I realise, for these very constructive discussions, that we are in the same boat and we can work together in order to proceed for these proposals to be legislation in our institutions. I took careful note of your remarks and ideas. As I said in the beginning of my intervention, this demonstrates this Parliament’s active interest in and commitment to these proposals.  Recent disasters were damaging but they taught us several lessons. Firstly, they showed that our collective combined capacities to respond to disasters are not enough when large-scale disasters happen; we have to be frank. Secondly, they showed the limitation of the current purely voluntary system. This is the hard reality. Finally, of course, they showed that the negative impact of disasters would have been reduced if effective preventive actions had been in place. As you said, prevention is better than cure. It is as simple as that.  We have to focus on prevention and preparedness in order, of course, to save lives, but also to reduce our costs. At the same time, there is also some good news. We are not starting from scratch. We have a lot of accumulated knowledge and experience because of the current system, and through Rescue we work towards maximum efficiency with minimum bureaucracy. We don’t need more bureaucracy. We have to find ways to reach maximum efficiency with minimum bureaucracy; this is very important for all of us and this is why I strongly believe that Rescue is a cost-effective and cost-efficient system. Through Rescue we can provide tangible European solidarity to our citizens, not in theory but in action. Action that helps save lives, livelihoods and of course our environment. Remember that Rescue is first of all about economies of scale. It is very simple to understand this. Secondly, it is a tool to directly help our citizens in very critical times of floods, forest fires, epidemics and earthquakes and, as I have already highlighted, a cost-effective way to ensure coordination and a harmonised approach to prevention and preparedness.  Some of you raised the issue about the national risk management plans and the risk reduction plan. At present our European Union Civil Protection Mechanism is not responsible for the national risk reduction plan. It is a national competence. Now, through Rescue, we can find ways to fund this cooperation between our services and national services in order to increase and to improve the national plans for management and risk reduction. Through Rescue we can improve ourselves across Europe.  During the terrible forest fires in Portugal last October – and our colleagues from Portugal know well the situation in Portugal at that time – Jean-Claude Juncker said that Europe must and should offer more than condolences during natural disasters. He asked all of us for immediate and concrete action. I strongly believe that we can provide our citizens with more than condolences. We are all aware that the next disasters can happen at any time in any country, because no country is immune and self-reliance should not be taken for granted. It is an illusion for anyone to believe that any country can face alone the size of the current natural disasters because of climate change.  Thank you again for your support. I am sure you understand the importance and the urgency of adopting the proposal. It is for this reason that I count on your swift action. I strongly believe that we can work together in order to persuade anyone who, until now, may show some reluctance, but we have powerful arguments in order to convince them that this is very important for Europe, for our citizens, to save lives and livelihoods.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the civil protection mechanism is a concrete expression of European solidarity, and it is a priority for us. Happy to hear that this is the case for the Council, for the Commission and indeed for the European Parliament. I didn’t expect it to be any other way. We in the Council will look at the Commission’s proposal with great attention. We will work swiftly, but we are taking the necessary time to deliver a rock solid mechanism – better than the current one. In the meantime, nevertheless, we owe it to our citizens that no effort is spared to improve our Member States’ capacities, as well as our collective capacities, to better prevent and to quickly react within the current framework.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the discussion on the Council and Commission statements on the EU-wide ban on Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans (2017/3007 (RSP)).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, you have invited the Presidency to speak on behalf of the Council on the topic of an EU-wide ban on Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans. I am grateful for the opportunity to be here and to present our views on this topic.  This discussion is important for several reasons. First of all, reports from the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe confirm an alarming increase of intolerance and hatred in Europe. There might be several reasons explaining this worrying phenomenon, but let me be clear on this, there is no justification for it.  Secondly, we notice an increasing use of Nazi and fascist symbols on social media platforms but also in public, both online and offline. This shows that some of our citizens have not learnt from history. As we know, this can be very dangerous. Those who forget mistakes of their own history risk repeating them.  We are therefore obliged to take all incidents of that kind seriously and never ignore them. On a positive note, the EU has adopted specific legislation on combating intolerance and hatred. I refer in particular to the 2008 Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia. In June 2016 the Council invited Member States to ensure the effective transposition and implementation of the framework decision and other relevant hate crime laws at national level. In addition, it asked Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes. According to this legislation specific offences exist when directed against a group of persons, or a member of such a group, defined by reference to race, colour, religion, descent or national or ethnic origin. They include, among others, public incitement to violence or hatred, public dissemination or distribution of propaganda material and images.  I have already mentioned that social media is one of the main vehicles enabling hate speech to go viral. One possible remedy against this epidemic is a harmonised and determined European response. As for the steps taken in the Council, the Estonian Presidency and the previous Maltese and Slovak Presidencies have done important work to tackle these issues. In October the Council conclusions on the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights in 2016 were adopted, where the Council welcomes the measures coordinated by the Commission High-Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. We also welcome and support the ongoing EU-level dialogue with major IT companies to address hate speech online, also through the implementation of the code of conduct launched by the Commission for this purpose. Last but not least, we should remember and commend the remarkable work done by the Fundamental Rights Agency in this field. But all these countermeasures would be in vain if we forget the important role of education and youth work, and more precisely the need to develop democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance, critical thinking and conflict resolution skills in the learning process.  To sum up, we have different tools: we have knowledge, education, counter-narratives, but also condemnation of any form of anti-Semitic or anti-Muslim violence, hate speech or discrimination. Accordingly the responsibility rests with all of us: politicians, teachers, civil servants, students, parents, and if needed also judges and prosecutors. No one can close their eyes or ears and pretend not to see injustice, discrimination or hatred.  I would like to conclude by stressing how important it is to prevent our societies from becoming dominated by hatred. Our role, and on this I know I can count on your support, is to remind ourselves of our responsibility for what we say. Words and symbols have power, including the power to harm. For this reason, freedom of expression has its limits. It is our common responsibility to find the right balance, and this is never an easy task.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we all know, and we are proud of it, that the European Union is built upon common values of human dignity, fundamental rights, equality, rule of law and democracy.  The Commission shares the concerns of Parliament over the worrying trends in the rise of racist and xenophobic attitudes, which sadly have found their way into mainstream politics and mainstream media.  Under the Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia by means of criminal law the Member States must ensure that public incitement to violence or hatred, including through the use of Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans, is criminalised under national law. National law enforcement and judicial authorities are responsible for investigating and prosecuting any such instance. The Commission rigorously monitors the application of this legislation.  In the past couple of years nine Member States have made amendments to their respective criminal laws in order to bring them in line. The Commission will continue to work on reducing the remaining gaps in national legislation, but laws are only as good as they are effectively implemented in practice. This is why the Commission has been stepping up its efforts to assist Member States to build the capacity to ensure the effective implementation of the law, but also to support targeted measures to prevent and tackle intolerance in practice. This includes the work of the EU High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance.  The EU High Level Group was set up in 2016 to foster discussions and synergies between Member States, civil society and other key stakeholders with a view to improving responses, including guidance on how to train police and judicial authorities on hate speech and hate crime, and guidance on how to ensure adequate support and protection for hate crime victims.  The Commission has been leading major initiatives such as the Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online. The recent guidance Communication on Tackling Illegal Content Online adopted by the Commission in September also provides key impetus for further progress in this area. Continued efforts are also being devoted to initiatives on remembrance. As the Commission remarked in its statement on the Europe-wide Day of Remembrance for the victims of all totalitarian and authoritarian regimes on 23 August, it is essential not only to remember the victims of these regimes but also to use remembrance as a guide for the future so as not to repeat mistakes and let discrimination and hatred spread again. I used to say that history does not really repeat itself; men repeat history very simply because they do not read it and they do not draw lessons from what has happened in the past. This is why the Commission strongly reaffirmed on that occasion the rejection of totalitarian and authoritarian ideologies such as Nazism and fascism. It is crucial to remember past horrors in order to give us the knowledge and strength to reject those who seek to revive these heinous ideologies.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commission and the Council for their maximum commitment to the fight against all totalitarian systems and corruption. Also, I thank you for making this item on the agenda, so that we can talk about this in the European Parliament, but unlike our colleagues from Western Europe, we in Croatia still have fresh memories of a totalitarian regime that was neither fascist nor Nazi, but he very much dealt with dissidents, individuals and groups whom he considered a threat to himself. The recent history of the world speaks of millions of deaths directly or indirectly connected precisely with communist regimes and their symbols are equally unacceptable in 21st century Europe as fascist and Nazi. I therefore regret that in today's title of the agenda item, you proponents have not included communism. Of course I oppose all totalitarian symbols and slogans. I will try to illustrate the situation for you. There are different interpretations of the past in the Croatian public space, and fostering a culture of remembering human rights violations and resisting undemocratic regimes is not systematic and comprehensive. Neither the current administrative nor judicial practice regarding the display of symbols is uniform. That is why the Government, headed by Andrej Plenković, established the Council for Dealing with the Past, whose task is to propose recommendations to the Government and legally regulate the display of content that glorifies undemocratic regimes. There is no totalitarian regime that deserves to be amnestied just because the victors write history. Europe, including European Croatia, should look with equal condemnation on all regimes that have perpetrated or continue to discriminate on any grounds, which are responsible for political persecution, individual or mass killings, and repression of fundamental rights and freedoms. In any case, I welcome the fact that we are discussing this, and I am also pleased that the representative of the Commission, Mr Avramopoulos, and the representative of the Council today expressed the position of the Commission which opposes any totalitarianism.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the sixty years since the Treaties of Rome, Europe has made the path to peace possible. We have ensured that our differences are no longer the cause of divisions, but the foundation of our being together according to common values, built over the centuries. Values ​​such as democracy, human rights, freedom of thought and the principles of the rule of law. Values ​​that we have come to deny in history, through the devastating experience of dictatorships and Nazi-fascism. This is why our Union today represents the exact opposite of what fascisms have meant in history. For this reason, Nazi-Fascism is not an opinion, it is not a normal exercise of freedom of expression, but rather its opposite: it is the denial of freedom, it is a crime, a crime that cannot be limited to a specific historical moment. As Primo Levi said, Mr. President, every time has its fascism: it begins by spreading in many subtle ways the nostalgia for a world in which order reigned supreme and in which the safety of the privileged few rested on forced labor and the forced silence of lot of. Order and cleanliness: fascism also begins like this. From the rehabilitation of a language capable of arousing deep divisions in society, propagating ideas that incite the suppression of democracy, the criminalization of diversity and oppression, Mr President, it can never be considered as a simple exercise of freedom of expression. We are free to express our thoughts, precisely because we have put an end to Nazi-Fascism, which was and still is an extraction of violence. There are those who believe that all this is limited to the folklore of the distant past. However, it is necessary to have a solid historical memory to be able to look to the future without making the mistakes of the past, and to ban Nazi-fascism, to condemn its apology, to relegate its symbols to museums and to history, is not to deny another's freedom, but to guarantee that of all of us.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I think it is very childish to try and ban symbols, even if they represent repulsive ideologies such as National Socialism, or Communism for that matter.  First, it is difficult to define what exactly is banned and in what context. Symbols such the swastika or the red star are universal motifs and have different meanings in different cultures. It is even more difficult to define expressions.  Second, we would never reach an agreement on which destructive ideologies are bad enough for the symbols to be banned. The criteria would be political not objective.  Third, if you ban a symbol representing a certain ideology, the proponents of that ideology will just invent a new symbol which resembles the old one just enough to be understood, but not enough to meet the definition.  I must say I disagree with Mr Maasikas, symbols alone have no power: they are ink on paper. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, you said that it is childish to ban certain symbols.Of course, we are not talking about certain symbols here, but we specify which.Do you think that Nazi, fascist symbols, demonstrated by historians, specialists, can influence children, young people to be extremists, to reach acts of violence?Do you think that these symbols can influence children?

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: blue-card answer. – I don’t believe extremism stems from symbols of extremism. What I wanted to point out is it would be very difficult to make a definition which would ban the Nazi swastika but not the swastika in other contexts, used in different cultures in different times and places.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, I found the impetus for this item on the agenda of our Parliament in the sad but also dangerous fact that today on the streets of European cities, more than in previous decades, gather people who glorify Nazism, fascism and their derivatives in various countries. We have seen recently what was happening in Warsaw, Madrid, Rome, Sofia, Zagreb, Belgrade, and unfortunately in many other larger or smaller places. There are too many manifestations of hatred around us for us to be silent. Nazism originated in Germany, but it was Germany that was the first and best of all to decide to punish all those who glorify Nazism or use its symbols or slogans. Italy did so in a similar way to fascism. Unfortunately, there are still countries and authorities in the European Union that treat the symbols and slogans of Nazism, Fascism or Ustashaism and Chetnikism without serious sanctions and strong reactions. The European Union was created with the desire that the war in Europe would never happen again. The evil of Nazism that originated on European soil and spread to many other countries has been defeated, but clearly not eradicated. That is why we need to act. Right here. That is why not only the Member States, but also the European Union itself, this Parliament, this Commission must propose concrete legal solutions at European level. I ask the Commission and all of us here in this House for this Parliament to adopt a special resolution and other necessary acts that will sharply oppose all those who glorify and use the symbols and slogans of defeated criminal regimes.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, it is a good thing that we are going to ban Nazi and far-right symbols in Europe, but it is a symbolic act. To do more, we must look at the roots of the rise of the Far Right and Nazism in today's Europe. We saw it in Greece a few years ago. We last saw it in Germany with the rise of the far-right party. We see it everywhere. In order to be able to deal with this political phenomenon, we must address the causes that cause it, namely the austerity policies that have been implemented, the growing social injustices, things that cause anger among the population and great insecurity, and turn people, workers from popular strata, - we have seen it in France - to the Far Right. We must change our policy and move towards a social, just Europe that ensures stability and security for its citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card, pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I welcome the efforts of the Commission and the Council to ban Nazi symbols and slogans, and I would like to ask you: How is a swastika different from a sickle and a hammer?How is totalitarian Nazism different from totalitarian communism?After all, communism is also to blame for millions of people.Isn't it time to include communist symbols along with Nazi symbols in the ban on prohibition?

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: answer to a question with a blue card. - You can see the difference between Nazi symbols and communist symbols in one photo only. In the photo of the liberation of Berlin in 1945 from Nazi troops, these troops who had executed tens of millions and sent millions to the crematoria, a flag, a different flag, held by soldiers liberated Berlin and threw down Hitler, and that flag had the hammer and sickle. You can not put one thing next to another.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! A strong democracy must also accept symbols, songs and flags from the historical past. If a democracy forbids symbolism, then this democracy is weak and no longer believes in its own powers of persuasion. If you now unilaterally exclude the 60 million murdered people, the traces of violence and blood from the communists, whose symbols do not touch, you are damaging the values ​​of the European Union, which must apply equally to everyone - to everyone, regardless of their race, religion, ideology or political conviction. They thus create new totalitarian structures with bans. Do you still believe in your so-called values ​​of the European Union, which are constantly enumerated like a prayer wheel? Today, these values ​​often stand for anti-family, anti-fatherland, anti-religion, anti-normal relations between the sexes, and now there are also anti-freedom of conscience and anti-freedom of expression. Freedom of expression is either entirely or not at all.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - Mr Chairman! We cannot pretend that we do not see, and cannot allow, in our elected countries to allow barbaric behavior of a fascist nature - zero tolerance. Today it is 36 years since the introduction of martial law by the communist government in Poland, and today the parliament in Warsaw is again fenced off with metal barriers and police cordons, so that those who demonstrate support for free courts and for democracy may not approach it. The same police also protect the marches organized by the National-Radical Camp and on these marches banners with fascist slogans such as "Only white Europe" or "Pure blood" are carried. And this logo that I am showing you now reminds you of the nightmarish anti-Semitism of the 1930s, in which the National-Radical Camp actively participated; for example, he organized bench ghettos at universities for students of Jewish origin; and this logo is still used today. Many of you have heard and commented with concern about the symbolic hanging on gallows of photos of six of us - MEPs from Poland. The police stood around, watched and did not intervene. Is it possible to talk about it calmly? I appeal for measures leading to the ban on neo-fascist organizations and for a pan-European ban on promoting Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans. It really isn't far from words and signs to deeds.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, this is a timely debate given that across the EU we have seen a resurgence of Nazi and fascist symbols as the memory declines about how, under these symbols and slogans, millions of people were killed in Europe. The ideology underlying these symbols is hatred of democracy and the idea that force is a legitimate means to achieve power, encouraging conflict in our society. This stands in a stark contrast to the values of the European Union, yet how easily do we tolerate fascists in this House! They can comfortably use the funds of an organisation whose destruction they seek and whose values they sneer at. Now, in my country and in my region of West Midlands, hate crimes have spiked as a result of the referendum, the Brexit referendum. They have increased by a shocking 30%. It has become a norm now across the EU to attack migrants and the places of their worship, yet it still remains not very well reported, and only one in five people actually report the incident or get any conviction.  I do not believe that we can win this fight by just banning Nazi or fascist symbols, important though that is. We also need to really work at changing the mindsets, at having more integrationist policies; and this is not just confined to the Member States, it is also important that we really set an example here. If you look around this House there are very few people who are symbols of diversity. I think it is important if we are going to change that mindset that we try and address that within the EU institutions.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! It has already been mentioned in this Chamber - and I am addressing it to President Avramopoulos - on December 13, the day when the communist authorities threw thousands of people in Poland into prison. I didn't sleep in my house that night, and that's the only reason why I wasn't there. They were with my parents, the former communist police, they were in the dormitory where I lived, even in the apartment I had moved out of the year before. But that's not what I want to talk about. I recall this date, because this board should include communism and Bolshevism against other forms of totalitarianism, their omission does not honor our Parliament. And I say this because, Mr President, I appealed to the European Commission for a clear, clear condemnation of the extremist demonstration that took place a month ago in Paris, in the Paris hotel. In the presence of the current mayor of Paris, in the presence of the previous prime minister and leading socialist party activists, Inna Shevchenko was honored, a woman who sawed a cross at the site commemorating the thousands of victims murdered by the NKVD. Mr. Chairman! If we take this debate seriously, this gloomy demonstration must be condemned because it was not a group of young people. There was the former prime minister of France and there was the current mayor of the French capital. Please condemn it clearly, no condemnation here will be a form of allowing. It is not allowed to be silent! (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think that ‘Nazi’ is a symbol, exactly like the swastika, so it should also be forbidden? You should name it National Socialism, as socialism is the essence of the Hitlerist doctrine, and as Stalin, Hitler and Mao Zedong and others killed ten times more people than Adolf Hitler, then a red flag, hammer and sickle and a red star should also be forbidden if the swastika is to be forbidden. Moreover, don’t you think that forbidden fruit is very attractive? Moreover, I think that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Marek JUREK
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mister!I focused on this gloomy demonstration in Paris, because it was attended by the former prime minister of France and the current mayor of Paris (leading politicians of the Socialist Party), but of course I find it completely bizarre that we are talking here, and we have seen a month in the corridors of this Parliament.ago, hammer and sickle posters, the communist equivalent of the swastika.We have seen the image of Che Guevara, the executioner of the Cuban counter-revolution, the man who was responsible for exporting the revolution and planting it in other countries.This is not a normal situation, and it does not mean that the debate we are having is frank.I am counting on the decisive voice of the President on this gloomy demonstration in Paris.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - I will return to the title of today's debate. They are countries where the exposure of Nazi, fascist, anti-Semitic, racist, xenophobic and other extreme symbols no longer surprises us. So what happened that we need to talk about in the European Parliament? One of the leading politicians of the German AFD, Bjoern Hoecke, called the Holocaust Memorial a monument to shame. The neo-Nazi organization White Rex in Russia, under the guise of business, is opening a gap in neo-Nazi ideology. In Italy, a few days ago, a group of masked members of the fascist Forza Nuova declared war on La Repubblica and the weekly L’espresso, US President Trump retweeted messages from British neo-Nazis and apologized to participants in neo-Nazi demonstrations in Charlottesville. Serbs and Croats have been declared war criminals convicted in The Hague. One of them, Vojislav Seselj, is sitting in the Serbian parliament, while Croatian extremists are erecting a monument to the fascist state formation in the Jasenovac concentration camp. Hungarian neo-Nazis are an inviolable part of the political scene in their country, equally Ukrainian, also Polish. The phenomenon of the far right, more or less aggressive, was known years ago mainly in the European East, in post-communist transition countries, but today it has spread to Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Greece and Spain and elsewhere. The iconography can be new or old, but the message is the same and is dangerous if not read in time. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Dear colleague, why did you state that a monument to the Independent State of Croatia has been erected in Croatia when it comes to erecting a monument to a regular unit of the Croatian Army from the Homeland War, which has nothing to do with the Nazi and fascist regime?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- We are close neighbors, Mr. colleague, and I know very well what kind of monument was erected in Jasenovac and, fortunately, thanks to the intelligence of some responsible people, it was removed.So we don’t need to play little games there about that.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, best wishes President, Italy, the country I come from, has one of the most beautiful constitutions in the world. The Constitution born from the resistance to Nazi-fascism and signed by a Communist, Umberto Terracini. In Italy the reconstitution of the fascist party is explicitly forbidden. Yet in recent weeks we have witnessed reprehensible episodes, such as the attack by skinheads in Como against an association that deals with migrants, the very existence of Casa Pound, the consensus found by the neo-fascists of a Roman neighborhood like that of Host. Here, we have always said that anti-fascism is a current problem, we also said it when you accused us of using anti-fascism as an old iron, as a simply ideological weapon. Anti-fascism is current and has always been for us; regret that the majority that governs the European Union, the neoliberal majority did not notice, favoring the growth of Nazi-fascism, favoring it with connivance with the Ukrainian government of Poroshenko and its presence and connections with the banderists, with the shameful equation , and I close, between communism and fascism. The Red Army contributed to the liberation of Europe from Nazi-fascism. And again, re-proposing with the Libyan concentration camps episodes that truly bring to mind Nazism.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Mr. president.In the Spanish state there are still one hundred thirty-five monuments in honor of the fascist dictator Francisco Franco, including his tomb in the Valley of the Fallen, and for which the public budgets allocate 750,000 euros annually in maintenance.In turn, in the last three months in Catalonia dozens of actions by far-right Spanish groups have been recorded, many of them with violence that usually goes unpunished, and also with public and notorious use of fascist symbols.In fact, we are experiencing a worrying rebound in these types of actions.Since the Spanish Government, like other governments of the European Union, has no interest in prohibiting the exaltation of fascist ideology and symbolism, a determined action on a European scale would be very welcome.It would not be the way to end hatred and intolerance, but it would be a step forward.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, we are talking about this because we are witnessing a disturbing trend in Europe in the rise of extremist parties, which do not hesitate to use Nazi symbols for their purposes. The symbols are visible, but it is necessary to fight especially against hateful ideologies as such, especially if they are still so alive. Education and the media are essential. Young people no longer have personal experience and therefore no knowledge of the horrors that totalitarian ideologies committed in the 20th century. Therefore, it is necessary to educate them in this and provide them with direct testimonies of witnesses. More than words are experience. That is why I appreciate the activities of such organizations as the Memory of the Nation in the Czech Republic and the Platform of European Memory and Conscience at the level of the European Union. The European Union is a common space for disseminating information, including social media, and therefore a European response is needed, which should include and also help Member States to help combat extremism, especially on the Internet, and to punish hate speech, including the use of prohibited symbols, with criminal law. We should be more reminiscent of the facts surrounding Nazism and the Holocaust. It is no coincidence that many victims of Nazism suffered under communist regimes in Central and Eastern Europe. Therefore, when we talk about banning fascist and Nazi symbols, we should think similarly about communist symbols. The sickle and hammer are symbols of parties under whose rule more than fifty million people have been killed. It is our debt that we must repay to the victims of red totalitarianism.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good work President, in the last period we have been witnessing a dangerous fascist resurgence in Europe, a worrying escalation of episodes which should not be underestimated. It is not a question of isolated incidents and gangsters, as someone in this House wants us to believe by minimizing their extent. Only in Italy, within a few days, there were very serious episodes: the raid in Como of a group of skinheads in a meeting between volunteers who help refugees, we had a fascist blitz in Rome under the headquarters of the national newspaper La Repubblica , and in Bologna, city symbol of the anti-fascist resistance, the burning of the plaque commemorating the shot partisans. As in Italy, the spread of hatred, xenophobia and fascism is reaching worrying levels in the rest of Europe. More decisive and firm action by the European Union is needed, including on social media. The EU Charter of Rights must also apply to all social networks, regardless of their location. The apology for fascism is a crime in Italy, but not on Facebook: it is necessary to block the pages that incite hatred and fascism: in Italy alone there are more than 300 according to the data of the National Partisans Association. Here, the Union arose from the ashes of the tragedies of the world wars and from the horrors of Nazi and Fascist ideology. The Union must therefore react, not only the institutions, parties, associations, but all citizens, we must all mobilize. The future of democracy and the future that we want to leave to the next generations is at stake. We strongly reject any fascist upsurge.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, Nazi and fascist symbols must not be welcome in public space and we must do everything in our power to make citizens fully aware of the atrocities that this ideology represents and give up its legacy. We must do the same with the communist legacy, which, unfortunately, is often celebrated and propagated in this home as well. But in order to successfully guide citizens to all the benefits of democracy, we must believe in it ourselves. The European Union has repeatedly shown in the last 20 years that it recognizes democratic processes only when it likes the outcome. Trying to change something from the European level that has not passed through national parliaments is also a manipulation of democracy. Despite noble intentions, it is dangerous to send a message to citizens that it is okay to circumvent procedures and impose their will without democratic legitimacy. It is, believe it or not, the first step towards a new totalitarianism. And Mr. Ambassador, seventeen million people were killed under fascism and Nazism, and ninety million under communism. That you did not include communism in this debate is frightening to me.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I followed your remarks on the Europe-wide ban on fascist symbols and slogans discussed here with great interest, and I would like to encourage the Commission and Council, but also Parliament, to continue this discussion intensively. After all, it is a practice that is already in use in Germany. But I also want to say that for us the political confrontation with neo-Nazism and fascism is more important than mere symbolic politics, and this politics must be based on social justice, solidarity and the equality of life. It is in contrast to the austerity and austerity policies of recent years, which have increased inequality in society and which have strengthened the fascist movement. Here in Parliament, too, there are now far too many representatives of right-wing populist and openly fascist parties. We had to endure it with great pain in the course of this debate. Europe doesn't need Nazi symbols, Europe doesn't need Nazi slogans, but even less does it need Nazis. Their policies do not belong here in Parliament and nowhere. Fascism is not an opinion, but a crime.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, representative of the Council! On behalf of the European People's Party, I call for a ban across Europe and in all 28 Member States of all symbols and slogans of the greatest and most murderous wrong path in our history, the National Socialist and Fascist regimes. This must be followed up immediately and consistently without exception. It has nothing to do with freedom of expression. As chairman of the parliamentary working group against anti-Semitism, with many convinced members of this House, we stand by the fact that anti-Semitism must be combated. It is increasing and this development must be countered with determination. The governments of all EU member states are now called upon to finally anchor these bans in national legislation. As with the hate postings and the anti-Semitic racist crimes on the Internet, measures must be taken, which I would best describe as submitting the Internet platforms to media laws in order to be able to prosecute. I also thank colleague Jakovčić for his initiative for a resolution. The urgent demand must be raised: Get rid of Nazi and fascism symbols and ideologies from our European society! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Mr. Becker, thank you for accepting my blue card.I listened carefully to what you were saying.Do you agree with me that in addition to the Member States and the European Union, the European Commission, this Parliament must pass its own acts, its own legislation when it comes to banning Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans?So not only Member States, but we at European level?Do you agree with me on that?

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I absolutely agree with you.I think that's the only way to go about it.I am therefore delighted with the unity that the Commission and the Council are showing today.But I ask both institutions to do what is now necessary.There are examples: Germany, France, also my home country Austria show a very clear criminal prosecution.Please pave the way now!

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, no matter how many ideological and other differences we have between ourselves in this Chamber, no matter how different we read History, we must be able to agree on a fundamental point, exactly what all the peoples of the world identified in 1945: that fascism, the ideology that wants to classify people and nations into superior and inferior, is foreign and hostile to human civilization; that this ideology is not another view within democracy that we should tolerate; on the contrary, it is the ideological one. mantle of concentration camps, gas chambers, Holocausts and doom. It is not only the history of these symbols that is criminal; it is their ideology that is the crime. Fascist and Nazi symbols have no place in European societies. Only in museums and history books is their place, for the new generations of Europe to learn how much pain, hatred and blood they bring with them, to envision and build their future with the non-negotiable common denominator of democracy, freedom and peace. That is why we must put these symbols where they belong, in memory of the dead, in defense of the living.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the debate on the banning of Nazi and fascist symbols and slogans throughout the European Union seems to me a bit out of place today. It is known, namely, that the mentioned regimes were militarily defeated and convicted in numerous trials, declarations and laws at the national level. With the collapse of Nazism and Fascism, only one half of Europe, unfortunately, experienced freedom. In the second half, the communist system remained in power and the other half reached its freedom only 45 years later. Pressed by numerous and important European topics such as better education and employment of young people, stable economic growth, solving social issues of European citizens, the problems of migrants and many others, not to mention them all, we are discussing today the ban on symbols. It really seems like a ride in the opposite direction to me. It is as if we ourselves are encouraging people to do out of revolt what they would not otherwise do. This debate is counterproductive because prohibition and repression have never brought solutions to anyone. Quite the opposite. They have provoked revolt and revolt among young people for whom such debates are at the bottom of their priorities in today's democratic Europe. I wonder, who needs that?

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr President, I join in the concern that this House is showing about the reappearance of fascism and its symbolism.However, it surprises me that almost no one has mentioned that most of the historical expressions of fascism have been related to the exaltation of the country more than anything else, and always with the ignorance of the other.You have to combat this feeling, this human subculture.And it must be done - as the Estonian minister very well said - keeping society alert, that is, establishing a general culture of combat of this subculture, of this human temptation;and do it educating in the values of citizenship, in the knowledge of history;and to do so also by sanctioning when the behaviors deserve even criminal sanction.This whole culture must be articulated and I join the efforts for us to wage a real battle against this.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, thank you and good luck in your new duties! Mr Avramopoulos, as you said, we must not forget the victims of Nazism. We must not forget the Nazi concentration camps and crematoria. We in Greece do not forget, Mr. President, the millions of our compatriots who were executed by the Nazi occupation troops in Greece in the period 1941-1944. For this reason, our request for the justification of the victims, for the payment of German compensation to the relatives of the victims of the Nazi occupation in Greece, for the payment of the German war reparations, for the repayment of the occupation loan is topical. But here in the European Parliament, in the Committee on Petitions, the European People's Party, the Socialist Group and the Liberals have been rejecting for three consecutive years my proposal for a Committee on Petitions to hold a public hearing on German reparations. The same groups deleted from my report, which is being discussed tomorrow, any reference to German compensation. The same groups at the same time decided that the report of the National Resistance fighters for the German compensations does not allegedly fall within the scope of the European Union. Shame!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, for many decades the communists, the leftists of all kinds and their companions characterized as a fascist and a Nazi every patriot who declared that he loved his homeland and his nation and was anxious for their future. Today they demand the abolition of the use, in general and indefinitely, of Nazi and fascist symbols. Of course, they do not do the same for communist symbols. We are neither Nazis nor fascists, neither I, nor my colleagues in the European Parliament, nor the party to which we belong. We are nationalists, ie active patriots, who are fighting against the genocide that has been imposed on our country, Greece, through the memoranda, which is why I believe that the proposed bans are intended to abolish freedom of thought, political will. and political action. Today they are calling for these freedoms to be abolished. Tomorrow they will ask for the abolition of some others, the day after tomorrow they will not allow us to say good morning either. We hear the ringing of the bell announcing the death of civil liberties in Europe, but, as Hemingway said, when you hear the bell ring, do not ask who it is; it may be for you.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear colleagues, thank you for this unfortunately still very topical debate. We have recently celebrated the 60th anniversary of the Rome Treaty. 60 years of a Union of peace and prosperity, built on the ruins and ashes of war and division, 60 years of democracy and freedom. We would, however, be mistaken to take for granted that the divisions, the xenophobia, the nationalism, the populism of 60 years ago are entirely gone. Our debate today shows that we continue to fight them every day and that the ghosts of the past are still lingering. In 21st century Europe there should be no place for fascism, for racism, for anti-Semitism, for any type of exclusion or discrimination, for any sort of totalitarian regime. We have the laws at European and national level to protect our fundamental rights, but we must also practice the spirit of this law in our everyday language and actions. To defeat xenophobia, racism and discrimination takes not only legislation. It is not all about laws. It’s about efforts and justice. Democratic Europe stands for these principles and does not forget. It also takes leadership, responsibility, democratic duty, citizens’ vigilance. Honourable Members, I count on you to carry the words and intentions of our debate today further in your actions and interventions, here and in your countries. Our fight is not over. Stay vigilant, the threat is still there.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, let me assure you once again that the Estonian Presidency, and of course the Council as a whole, rejects all forms of racism, xenophobia, intolerance and extreme nationalism. We have a legal framework in place which needs to be effectively implemented in practice, but we need to support the laws with targeted measures to prevent and tackle intolerance, such as education, public debate and counter-narratives.  Honourable Member Halla-aho disagreed with me, saying that the symbols are just ink on paper and are not dangerous as such. It just happens to be so and that those nations who have experienced a more direct impact of totalitarian regimes tend to be more inclined to banning these symbols. I think they know better.  The Council will continue to follow this issue very closely and I can assure you that I paid particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. –High House! I represent Polish citizens in the European Parliament. Some of them still have blood-curdling images before their eyes when Nazi Germany occupied Poland. For this reason, I am categorically in favor of banning the use of fascist and Nazi symbols at all possible levels. Historical education of young generations plays an important role here and they should be reliably conveyed the historical truth. This is the only way to make the younger generations aware of the great suffering associated with fascist symbols. This is the only way to effectively prevent radicalism and extremism. The European Commission must better monitor the implementation by Member States of EU legislation obliging them to criminalize, inter alia, fascist and Nazi behavior. For this reason, I demand an immediate ban on the use of fascist and Nazi symbols at European level.

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. - History teaches that the consequence of all crises is the liberation of radical attitudes. This is because for some politicians the time of crisis is the only chance to build their own position. Their irresponsible rhetoric evokes negative emotions that provide fertile ground for any radical attitudes. They intimidate those who, feeling unfulfilled, rejected or not accepted, unreflectively accept the arguments of the most radical populists in order to easily identify those who are to blame for their own failures. We know these mechanisms well from history. And paradoxically, it is history that once again offers populists the already proven models of the worst attitudes as a model. There is an ongoing debate on how to deal with hateful, xenophobic attitudes to prevent contamination on a large scale. Especially since - which is another paradox - the greatest achievements of democracy, such as freedom of assembly or freedom of speech, become arguments for radical circles to defend their own status quo. That is why it is so important to carry out an in-depth analysis of all the causes underlying the growing nationalist attitudes in order to develop the principles of effective behavior towards organizations and people contributing to their dissemination and cultivation. Postponing this problem "until later" may lead to dimensions that are difficult to control.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on: - the question with request for an oral answer to the Council on the European Parliament's right of inquiry by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (O-000089/2017 - B8-0613/2017) (2017/2993 (RSP)), and - the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the European Parliament's right of inquiry by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (O-000090/2017 - B8-0614 / 2017) (2017/2993 (RSP)).

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: replacing the author. - Mr. president. Ladies and gentlemen, this is an oral question that we put to the Council and the Commission as an expression of a complaint that Parliament wants to make to both institutions. Modern parliamentarism - for some time now - is characterized not only by legislative capacity but, above all, also by control of the government. And in the control of the government, parliaments have a fundamental tool in the creation of investigation commissions. It is not by chance that the Lisbon Treaty established that the European Parliament had precisely the capacity for legislative initiative - something that we do not have in any other matter - in the elaboration of a regulation on how they have to function as well as on the powers that the committees of European Parliament inquiry. And this was established in the European Constitution, in the Treaties, to replace an old norm, an institutional agreement that regulated, since 1995, the functions of Parliament in matters of investigation. The European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, approved your proposal for a Regulation in 2014. It was the so-called David Martin report. And it is true that it did so without an agreement with the Commission and without an agreement with the Council and, therefore, it was not possible for it to be approved, but we did it - the Parliament of 2014 - so that the initiative would not die at the end of the previous legislature. Since the person speaking to you was appointed rapporteur for this matter by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, that is, since September 2014, I have been trying to negotiate with the Commission and the Council and I have met with all the presidencies that have There have been since then: with the Latvian Presidency, with the Luxembourgish, with the Dutch, with the Slovak, also, of course, with the Maltese, and with all of them we have had different conversations, always well-intentioned, to solve this problem. But we never got start some serious talks, formally, to resolve the differences, the concerns that the Commission and the Council expressed in their day about that old text. In October 2016, the Slovak Presidency proposed to us a formula for solving the problem and raised the possibility that the legal services of the Commission, Parliament and the Council would meet discreetly, informally - we could say it that way - to draw up a common text, if they were able to resolve the technical differences that existed around the previous text. And I want to tell you that these meetings of the legal services of the three institutions have been taking place from October 2016 to May 2017. And during nine very serious meetings the legal services of the three institutions have reached a certain approximation. They have not solved everything, because they are not responsible for doing it either, but they have - let us say - delimited the differences and established a text that could solve this problem. But from May 2017 until today the situation has stagnated again, because the legal services have raised their agreements with their political leaderships in the Council and the Commission and the political resolutions of the Commission and the Council have not been produced. So, ladies and gentlemen, the facts are that three long years have passed and we have not been able to initiate conversations with the institutions. Despite our willingness to do so; despite the multiple forms of dialogue that we have proposed; despite the multiple alternatives that we have proposed to make our texts more flexible. And here are my assessments, ladies and gentlemen, because until now they were the facts. My first assessment, ladies and gentlemen, is that I want to denounce that, in my opinion, both in the Commission, as well as in the Member States, as well as in the Council, there is strong resistance to the European Parliament drawing up a rule with powers to that the investigation commissions investigate what is produced throughout the parliamentary life. Secondly, what is happening is that reality is adding more and more research experiences. Only in the last two years we have had two very important investigative commissions. Today we have approved here, in Plenary, the report on the Panama Papers, which presents a set of extremely important resolutions on an issue that caused social alarm throughout Europe, which is flight, tax evasion or unfair competition between states in the European Union itself. And we have had the Commission on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automobile Sector. And every time there will be more. And the question is whether or not this Parliament will have a provision, a capacity to have its own regulation. I would like to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that the European Parliament is ready to dialogue, to negotiate and to reform if necessary. To dialogue and reform if necessary. If the Commission and the Council inform us - albeit informally - that they accept the text that the legal services have prepared and we can start this negotiation, I undertake to bring to the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, if necessary, a text that can be negotiable with the institutions. If this is not the case, ladies and gentlemen, let me end by saying on behalf of Parliament - and I think I express the opinion of all my colleagues, fellow shadow rapporteurs from the different political groups - that your silence is a contempt for the European Parliament. That your refusal to negotiate offends the European Parliament and that your behavior so far does not correspond to the institutional loyalty that we owe to each other.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me start by assuring the House that the Council shares the view that committees of inquiry are important instruments for this Parliament to exercise its political control. In this spirit, and in respect of its duty of sincere cooperation, the Council is therefore prepared to examine constructively proposals for a revision of the current rules on the exercise of Parliament’s right of inquiry.
