As you know the first proposal for a regulation on the exercise of the Parliament’s right of inquiry, the so-called Martin Report from 2011, raised serious legal and institutional concerns in the Council and in the Commission. Indeed it foresaw a far-reaching extension of the rights of committees of inquiry, which was considered contrary to Article 226 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Also a more moderate revised proposal from 2014 did not resolve the fundamental legal and institutional issues with regard to the limits imposed by the above-mentioned Article.  Following informal contacts between our institutions it was thus agreed in October 2016 to mandate the Legal Services of the three institutions to further spell out the legal and institutional issues, with a view to helping Parliament clarify the content of its proposal. On the basis of this mandate the experts of the three Legal Services had nine meetings at a technical level between December 2016 and May 2017. In May they submitted the result of their work to their respective hierarchies. We have been waiting for a meeting at directors-general level to take place in order to finalise the joint paper before its submission to the political authorities of the three institutions.  The Council stands ready to continue the work once we have the outcome of the three Legal Services on the table. I would not however expect that the Legal Services will come up with a ready-made solution, or ready-made solutions, to all the thorny legal and institutional issues raised by this file, and indeed laid out by the previous speaker, but their input will facilitate finding a common way forward, including helping Parliament to elaborate on a new text which will have a chance to obtain the consent of the Council and the Commission.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Member of the Commission. –Mr President, dear colleagues, let me first welcome the opportunity offered by this oral question to set out the Commission’s position regarding the important right of inquiry of the European Parliament.  Article 226 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union sets forth Parliament’s right to investigate alleged contraventions or maladministration in the implementation of Union law, without prejudice to the powers conferred by the Treaties to the other institutions and bodies. This tool represents, in the European Union Treaties, the traditional control functions of the Parliament over the activities of the executive branch, a key component of every functioning democracy. With the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the current rule from 1995 needs to be replaced by a new regulation proposed by the European Parliament. However, it needs the consent of the Council and the Commission before it can enter into force. As we all know, this has been a complicated and politically sensitive file ever since the Parliament presented its proposal for a regulation in 2012. To be sure, the Commission has engaged in constructive dialogue, at technical and political level, honouring the principle of sincere cooperation between the institutions. At the same time, the Commission has always been very clear about the points that raised concerns while offering constructive solutions.  The Commission takes good note of the solution-oriented attitude the Parliament has taken so far, and I would like to thank in particular the current rapporteur, Mr Jáuregui Atondo, for his continued commitment and constructive approach with regard to the trilateral work.  Let me stress here the Commission’s continued willingness and commitment to engage in constructive trilateral discussions with the Parliament and the Council. Our aim is to find appropriate solutions to the divergences that still exist between the institutions, so that after Parliament’s vote on a final legislative resolution, the Commission can give its consent in accordance with Article 226 of the Treaty, with due regard to its institutional prerogatives. In this respect, I’m pleased to reaffirm that, in the Commission’s view, the constructive cooperation of the representatives of the Legal Services of the three institutions, which was started at the end of 2016, has borne its fruit. It has been overall a useful exercise that allowed for identifying possible agreement on large parts of a common text as well as avenues for possible compromise on other issues. However, although our legal experts have made significant progress on pending legal and institutional issues, important divergences still exist between the institutions. Throughout the process, the Commission has been very transparent about its concerns. To briefly sum up. Firstly, this is particularly the case for the scope and duration of the mandate of the Temporary Committee of Inquiry. Secondly, the incompatibilities between the investigations of the Committee of Inquiry and ongoing legal proceedings established by the Treaty. Thirdly, the rules on specification of document requests and the protection of sensitive documents or testimonies.  Moreover, the Commission believes that there are other issues that merit serious further discussions, including: the investigative means at Parliament’s disposal, the coercive measures which the Parliament asked to be put in place for failure to cooperate or for unsatisfactory testimony by natural and legal persons and political sanctions and legal remedies. The Commission also believes that the future legal framework for Parliament’s right of inquiry must be discussed in the light of the practical experience of the recent EMIS and PANA Committees of Inquiry. Earlier today this plenary presented its recommendations to the Council and Commission following the work of the PANA Committee, which includes recommendations on the implementation of Parliament’s right of inquiry. With this valuable, practical experience now fully available, the inter-institutional work in view of the update of the legal framework for the exercise of Parliament’s right to inquiry could usefully be resumed. Let me emphasise again the Commission is standing ready to resume trilateral work at the appropriate level, I now look forward to hearing the views of all Members and of the Council.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is true that I am a member of the European People’s Party but I speak here today as Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs under whose responsibility and competence this dossier falls. I would like to start by saying that we have been insisting, without success, for more than three years and five Council Presidencies now, on an interinstitutional process of dialogue being opened with the Council and the Commission on the regulation of the European Parliament on the right of inquiry.  Recent events and the work of our two latest inquiry committees – which the Commissioner mentioned, Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) and Money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (PANA) – have shown that we need new and more efficient rules on the role and powers of European Parliament committees of inquiry if we want to have effective public inquiries on matters that, by their very nature, go beyond the competence of national institutions.  Parliament voted today with a sweeping majority on establishing a permanent Committee of Inquiry. Public opinion requires those inquiries. This means that it is indeed politically important, not only politically difficult. To have clear rules is also in the interest of other institutions and also people who are called to testify in general in this Parliament. It will bring transparency and legal certainty to the procedures of inquiry, and yet we have been waiting now for more than three years, not to conclude the procedure but just to sit at the table and discuss whether an agreement is at all possible.  That is why we drafted this oral question. We are not asking the Council and the Commission to agree with us. We are asking them to sit at the table and negotiate. That is how problems are solved in the European Union and we have a duty to try at least to do so. On this we count on the Bulgarian Presidency.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The question of trust has been raised many times in this debate, and I too am a great supporter of that. The European Union needs trust between institutions, between the EU level and states. This should dictate restraint rather than radicalism. Unfortunately, the first submission on this issue is burdened with radicalism. Commissioner Avramopoulos mentioned these dilemmas and problems. I will mention one more thing, namely the European Parliament has the right to control the EU institutions, but there is no treaty basis for it to perform control and investigative functions over national institutions. It would be a mess of order. Nor does it have powers as strong as those of national parliaments' committees of inquiry. So I strongly believe that restraint and withdrawing from certain proposals will allow for a rational conversation and adopting a good solution, but the ball is rather on the side of the European Parliament.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I still remember the first time I read about this provision when I was analysing the EU Constitution back in the autumn of 2003. Then I read the text that has now become Article 226 of the Lisbon Treaty and I thought, yes, this is a really good thing. It could be really useful. And yet we are still here, almost a whole political life later, and we have still not managed to get this made a reality.  A committee of inquiry is a key feature of parliamentarianism. This is a fundamental right for Parliament, and without an effective tool for committees of inquiry the European Parliament will have difficulties in fulfilling its role as an effective control of the executive, of the implementation and enforcement of regulations, etc. It is long overdue.  As a Parliament we have repeatedly proposed such regulations and we have repeatedly, formally and informally, explained our openness and willingness to negotiate. Nothing helped! The Council stubbornly refuses to negotiate with Parliament and to grant it only a part of its natural and necessary rights. This is problematic. The experiences of the recent Committees of Inquiry on Money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (PANA) and on Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) show the true value of committees of inquiry and they also show that this system can be improved. Let’s start to negotiate for real.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: - Mister President! The repeatedly expressed willingness to participate in noble goals is thwarted. This is a tragedy. This has not only been possible since 2014, but since 2011, not five council presidencies, but eleven council presidencies. And the right to investigate matters is one of the most important rights of a modern parliament. It's not just about controlling governments, it's about controlling matters in which governments are sometimes involved. This right is insufficiently developed for the European Parliament. It is a right from the last millennium and it is urgently necessary to change that right. The Lisbon Treaty offers these possibilities. But if you read the text, it also contains an obligation for the Council and the Commission to participate. And it is precisely this participation that is massively refused. Mr Maasikas stated here: The legal services came to an understanding in May. Since then, they have obviously been waiting for an appointment with their bosses, biting their nails, so that they can have an appointment with the general managers at some point. Don't think that we don't know what's wrong! The point is that we want to bring evidence. The point is that we want to summon witnesses and also have to justify the witnesses if they do not come. And the point is that if someone tells the untruth before this committee of inquiry, he will then also be punished according to his national law and sanctions can be expected. In my opinion, this is perjury if you say so under oath. Ladies and gentlemen in the Council and the Commission: move! Tell them where you see your rights violated, then people can talk about them. Or at least say you don't want it. That would be more honest.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I will more or less support the position of my colleagues. It is quite clear that the power of inquiry is a key power of the modern legislature, and at a time when detailed rules are not laid down for how investigative bodies can operate, we discredit ourselves. Unfortunately, today the Commission and the Council show in their statements that there is not much will on their part to solve practical specific problems. My colleagues said that here. At a time when there are no clear rules for obtaining documents, for the handling of documents, when there are no clear rules for summoning persons who are to give notice for a specific investigation, then we are trying to have a power that is actually becoming empty. That is, in my opinion, very bad. So I will join my colleagues in calling on the Commission and the Council to realize that, at a time when the power of inquiry cannot be fully exercised, it cannot be fully exercised, we are damaging the European Parliament in the eyes of the public. It is difficult to explain to our citizens how we can exercise this important power if we do not have detailed legislation on it to fulfill this power. Please, also in the context of protecting the good name of the institutions of the European Union, let us move this matter forward.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, under Article 226 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Parliament has the power to set up temporary committees of inquiry to investigate allegations of infringements or misapplications of European Union law. This is a classic right of all national parliaments. After all, it is a cornerstone of parliamentarism that parliaments can set up committees of inquiry, and this simple - if you will - right took so many years to be incorporated into the treaties. But apparently it can not be done. So far we have committees of inquiry on very important issues, for the Panama Papers, for the LuxLeaks, but in the end an important framework must be formed. As you said, Mr Avramopoulos, the means that the European Parliament will have must be clarified. But these should not differ from the powers of national parliaments. It is therefore a matter of will for the other institutions to come to the negotiations and the debate. The fact that five years have passed and nothing has been done proves that there is no will from the other bodies and, above all, it creates a distorted and ugly image in the citizens themselves. Citizens want Parliament to have powers, to be able to set up committees of inquiry, and to have powers within these committees of inquiry.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this important debate which reflected the constructive spirit with which this file needs to be approached. I have taken good note of this discussion and all your remarks, and will not fail to inform my colleague First Vice-President, Mr Timmermans, under whose remit this file falls within this Commission, about its outcome in detail.  Let me reiterate that the Commission attaches great importance to Parliament’s role of scrutiny and political control. The ultimate aim of this control is to guarantee that citizens’ concerns regarding the implementation of European Union law are properly addressed. This is what the Treaty stipulates. However, I have also stated our genuine concerns, that need to be redressed. The trilateral work that has been done so far, including by our legal experts, and the practical experiences with Parliament’s recent committees of inquiry have shown us where common ground exists and where divergences still exist and need to be brought together.  It goes without saying that the Commission stands ready at any time to resume constructive trilateral discussions at the appropriate level with a view to finding solutions that can reconcile the outstanding concerns of the three institutions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this open and frank exchange of views which has allowed us to clarify our respective positions. I trust that we will soon have a joint paper of the legal services on the table, on the basis on which we can continue our discussions.  Let me reaffirm the Council’s willingness and commitment to engage with the European Parliament. After all, it is in our common interest to have clear and up-to-date rules governing the exercise of the European Parliament’s rights of inquiry so that all actors know precisely what are their rights and obligations.  Mr President, since this is my last intervention on behalf of the Estonian Presidency and of the Council, let me say a couple of words in my mother tongue, Estonian.  Euroopa Parlamendil on jäänud sellest meie ühisest toimetamisest siin head mälestused ja hea kogemus. Me oleme võtnud oma tööd, oma eesistujatööd väga tõsiselt. Me oleme töötanud oma parimal pühendunud viisil, nagu laulus öeldakse, et kulmud kuumavad töös, ja ma loodan, et meil on õnnestunud teile sellega ka muljet avaldada. Kuna meil Eestis ei ole nagu kombeks oma tundeid liiga reljeefselt väljendada, siis ütlen lihtsalt aitäh ja – polnudki üldse hull.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much indeed, Minister. That was probably your last speech in our House before the end of your country’s Presidency. Thank you very much indeed – or ‘aitäh’ as you say in your language – for your efforts in our common European interest.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's right of inquiry is currently governed by an interinstitutional decision laying down the "procedures for exercising the European Parliament's right of inquiry" adopted on 19 April 1995. This is an interinstitutional agreement which is binding only on the contracting parties and therefore does not have an erga omnes legal effect. Also for this reason, the approval of a new legislative instrument, in particular a regulation, would be a great step forward that would strengthen the role of the European Parliament, the only European institution to have direct popular legitimacy. The request to strengthen Parliament's investigative powers is also more necessary than ever in the light of recent tax scandals and not only that, in an increasingly globalized world, go beyond the sovereignty of any single state. Unlocking the institutional impasse that has arisen with the Council and the Commission is therefore fundamental. It is unacceptable that, although the rapporteur has tried to find an agreement with as many as six Presidencies of the Council, a common solution has not been found. This is not only not in line with the respect for the principle of loyal cooperation between institutions, but it outlines an irresponsible and profoundly anti-European behavior that benefits those who do not respect the rules.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Anna Corazza Bildt, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the implementation of Directive 2011/93 / EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 December 2011 on combating sexual abuse andsexual exploitation of children and child pornography (2015/2129 (INI)) (A8-0368 / 2017)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank wholeheartedly the Estonian Presidency for the excellent work and cooperation.  Our report is a call of urgent action to join forces to stop child sexual abuse and protect children. The directive to combat child sexual abuse, online and offline is a historic step forward. We have provided a strong legal framework with stricter sanctions and common standards to prevent and prosecute crimes and protect victims. But implementation is far from satisfactory. Member States must do more, better and faster, to ensure zero tolerance against child sexual abuse and exploitation. We are talking about such terrible crimes that police dealing with these cases take turns on duty and need support.  When shown on the Deep web the images, the cheers of enjoyment among perpetrators – I just couldn’t sleep at night. What if it was your child? A missing child? An unaccompanied minor? Any child? This concerns all children in Europe. An entire generation that lives on the net.  With our report we modernise European policies. Since 2011 new forms of crime such as revenge pornography and sex extortion affect many teenagers online – mainly girls – and cyber bullying and grooming have grown. Moreover, thousands of migrant children have disappeared, are sold and sexually exploited by organised crime in Europe, making billions on children’s skin. Trafficking is the slavery of our times against the most vulnerable kids.  Criminal networks and child sexual abuse online are sophisticated, and law enforcement authorities face new challenges. We cannot lag behind for lack of resources and modern means of prosecution. Therefore, we call on the Member States to give adequate resources to police, to child hotlines and helplines, to enforce the directive in a future—proof way, upgrading digital investigation tools to keep pace with technology, to remove illegal material at source and block it when it is not possible to remove, with faster procedures and safeguards, and to increase cooperation with third countries, Interpol and our great American partner NMEC to remove illegal material when the source is outside the EU.  We also urge the internet industry to take their shared responsibility. Much is being done, but it is not enough. The technology to detect, generate alarms, report to the police child sexual abuse material online exists – it should be used by all the IT industry. They should also work on innovative solutions to protect children online.  Migrant children are particularly exposed to child exploitation. Member States must ensure that they enter and remain in the protection system. Minors must be registered with fingerprints and given a guardian to avoid going missing. The time has come for all the Member States to fully enforce the anti-trafficking and protection of victims directive. We need to ensure that there is no impunity for any child sexual offender. Perpetrators must be brought to justice.  Children are right-holders. They must feel it is not their fault, that their voice is heard. Civil society plays a key role, taking children by the hand and assisting them in building trust. Children must be protected throughout the proceedings. Interrogation trials must be child-friendly to avoid double victimisation and victim blaming.  The time has come to break the silence and shift the guilt from child victims to adult perpetrators. Let’s launch a ‘me too’—like movement for children – ‘kids too’. If it is hard for woman to speak up, to share her story, to get justice, how hard can it be for a kid or a teenager? We need to mobilise, raise awareness and make sure children get justice and support. Today we reach out to all children who feel scared, ashamed, lonely and we say you are not alone. We care. We are determined to join forces to ensure that Europe truly means safety for all children

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a long night but I am more than happy to share these thoughts with the House. I would like to thank you for this debate about one of the most abhorrent issues of our times and I would especially like to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Ms Corazza Bildt, for her personal investment on this issue, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs for their work. Anna Maria, you have done an excellent job. Congratulations. Child sexual abuse is an appalling crime that the Commission is committed to eradicating, together with this Parliament. This is a fight that we cannot relinquish or soften until we have entirely eradicated it. The Child Sexual Abuse Directive adopted in 2011 is an ambitious and comprehensive instrument that binds Member States to achieve a number of objectives. We issued two extensive transposition reports in 2016 which assessed the implementation measures adopted by Member States. I welcome Parliament’s report, which builds on our work.  Member States have invested considerable effort to comply with their obligations. They have adopted around 300 legal acts amending criminal codes and procedures, sectoral legislation, increasing their administrative capacity and improving coordination of national actors.  However, this progress needs to be followed up with further efforts. Member States still face challenges related to prevention, intervention programmes for offenders, definition of offences, and assistance and support for victims. I therefore welcome Parliament’s call on Member States to further improve implementation because, for the children that are affected by this atrocious and inhuman crime, legislation on paper does not matter if it is not implemented and enforced properly.  This is why ensuring complete implementation by Member States of the Child Abuse Directive is an utmost priority for the Commission. In the coming months, we will continue to support Member States to achieve conformity of their national implementation measures and we will make use of our enforcement powers under the Treaties, if necessary. We will also support Member States in facilitating the development and exchange of best practices in specific areas, such as prevention and intervention programmes.  Work is already underway in this regard. For example, we recently supported child protection projects such as the Barnhuset, which is mentioned in the resolution, or integrated inter-agency and multidisciplinary support services for child victims of violence. We would like to see more Member States integrate such child rights-based models, building on what has been done in the Daphne Promise project. We will share information with you on these different elements to the maximum extent possible regarding specific data requested by the rapporteur.  While Member States are not legally required to report data regarding follow-up of law enforcement authorities, delays in takedowns and use of stored data by judicial authorities, sharing of information is, of course, key.  However, what matters most are the results, not reporting. Member States have to remove, or block, content online linked to child sexual exploitation and pornography. This is what counts. The Inhope network of hotlines plays a major role in practice in the transposition by Member States of their obligation regarding removal and blocking. We will be launching, at Parliament’s request, a study into the way the Inhope hotlines work, including how they interact with national law enforcement authorities and internet providers, and how they could improve their effectiveness. I will be glad to share the findings with you once they are available.  Finally, we note in Parliament’s report the strong calls on Member States to adopt measures that go beyond their obligations under this Directive. This includes: mandatory criminal background checks for persons working with children, exchange of information about child sex offenders, proactive searches of child sexual abuse material by hotlines and mandatory reporting by internal internet providers of child sexual abuse material detected in their infrastructure. These are very valuable suggestions and we will examine them carefully. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to your valuable comments.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: draftswoman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank my colleague Anna Maria for her report, which sets out many suggestions for improvement. The Committee on Culture and Education has, of course, focused on social networks and prevention. The Internet is becoming a dangerous tool for crimes against children. These attacks are cross-border in nature. We therefore call for the Member States to cooperate more in this regard, and the European Union has the opportunity to agree. So I also welcome the commitment made here by the Commissioner. We call on the Member States to cooperate more in this regard. We must adapt the fight against these crimes to the digital age. A more efficient exchange of information will facilitate the prevention of further crime in other Member States. For example, half of the Member States have taken voluntary action to block child pornography on the Internet. Research shows that blocking is more effective than removing content because it is faster. In general, we should be careful about blocking content on the Internet, because freedom and access to information are threatened. But children are particularly vulnerable victims. Therefore, we should focus on prevention and do not hesitate.

name: Clare MOODY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work. I know how seriously she takes this issue and the report shows that. The sexual abuse and exploitation of children and child pornography is a cross-border crime which requires an international response. It is a sobering fact that every nine minutes the Internet Watch Foundation’s analysts encounter a web page that shows children being sexually abused.  The speedy elimination of these images and the protection of children from abuse and exploitation must be a priority of the EU. It is our responsibility to ensure that the victims of child abuse are not forgotten. To do this, we must use developing technologies for the detection and removal of material and the identification of victims. The gender aspect of abuse and child pornography also must not be forgotten. Research suggests child sexual abuse affects girls at a higher rate than boys, and we should take this into account. What is more, non-consensual distribution of pornographic material, including so-called revenge porn, overwhelmingly affects women and girls, some of whom are under the legal age of consent.  I welcome this report’s focus on the sharing of best practice between Member States. I further welcome the report’s focus on the victims themselves, including the identification, assistance and protection of those victims. Finally, the focus on removal and blocking of images is particularly important. I look forward to following the implementation of this report’s recommendations and the further necessary follow-up work.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank Mrs Corazza Bildt for her efforts on this directive. According to Interpol data, in Europe, it is estimated that 18 million children are victims of sexual abuse: a real emergency. The centrality of the directive is in the exacerbation of penalties and in the criminalization of a wide range of situations of abuse, favored by the use of IT tools, such as the solicitation of children online and the display of child pornography. To stop the distribution of this material, the directive requires Member States to take the necessary measures to ensure the timely removal of web pages containing or disseminating child pornography. States must endeavor to obtain the removal and blocking of these pages. This is not about political ideology, but it is a categorical imperative to protect our children from these criminals. I applaud this provision, which gives greater scope to the protection of victims and identifies the main brake for these offenders in the criminal law common to the Member States. Neil Postman, an American author, says that children are the living message that we can allocate to a future we will not see. So let's protect our children, protect and safeguard our future.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for pointing out this serious and urgent subject. I am proud to have been able to work here. Ladies and gentlemen, children are the rarest and most fragile creatures we have and are worthy of our utmost attention and protection. There is a call for real action across Member States to protect children from the settlements of criminals who want to sexually abuse them and thus destroy their innocence, all for perverted pleasure. This is a horrible sight. What does this say about our society if some people use their skills to profit from filming children, and even babies, in sexual abuse. We are a really sick culture and society if we allow such things to happen. The statistics are threatening. Up to 28,258 people watch porn every second. Porn production has become a huge business in which nudity and human dignity are traded. The report legitimately calls for the prosecution of perpetrators and the protection of victims. I consider it important that we demand an obligation from all Member States to help the victims of these perversions. Many consumers of porn material can very easily, in search of more and more perversity, become guilty of consuming child pornography. A good example is the Pink cross organization, which works with people addicted to pornography and former porn actors. Pornography is a modern drug. It destroys the integrity of individuals, breaks up families and adversely affects society. Safe surfing works in a similar way and needs to be supported. Since 2011, the Directive on Child Sexual Abuse and Child Pornography has shown us to implement programs aimed at re-educating perpetrators of sexual violence and helping to stop them, as well as the harmful criminal habits they develop. We must no longer postpone this, our children deserve the most effective protection.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this evening I am divided: at the same time, I am happy and, at the same time, I am sorry. I am naturally delighted with the result of our work. Tomorrow we will adopt a strong and comprehensive report on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, an area in which we absolutely must move forward and redouble our efforts. I would of course like to thank, really from the bottom of my heart, our rapporteur with whom we fight, on a daily basis, on these themes, particularly within the "Children's Rights" intergroup. I would like to thank her for her work and her strong commitment in all these areas. But, at the same time, I am sorry tonight because, if we are having this debate, it is because the situation is far from satisfactory. Since 2011, we have had a directive which constitutes a real step forward, but we are almost in 2018 and the results are disappointing: late transposition, incomplete transposition on the part of the States, of the Member States which have still not modernized their law criminal in relation to all these new forms of offenses existing in the field of sexual exploitation of children, little has been done in terms of prevention and assistance to victims and a still too slow withdrawal of content presenting sexual abuse. We are told that the directive has not reached its full potential, but how is it possible to be satisfied with such a response? Government and NGO reports are damning, the exploitation figures are alarming, the victims are younger and younger, the content is increasing: there is therefore a need to redouble our efforts against these atrocities. I would like to highlight three points. First, prevention: how to prevent these abuses which often take place in the direct and family environment? How? 'Or' What prevent these rapes?How can we better protect our children before they fall prey to these criminal networks and predators?Secondly, with regard to internet content, Member States must ensure that such content presenting abuse against children is promptly removed at source and they must have functional takedown notification procedures.Third, the training of actors: judicial and police actors must be sufficiently equipped by the Member States to adapt to this evolving and terrible nature of these crimes.The actors of childhood too, to conclude, must be accompanied so that they succeed in detecting the victims, because this is absolutely dramatic for the construction of these children, who risk remaining and too often remain invisible victims.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur for this report. According to data from the Council of Europe, one in five children has suffered some type of sexual abuse and the issue of refugees and what is happening lately are not included here. In about three-quarters of the cases, those who commit the abuses are also people close to the victims. And unfortunately, the internet has served as a channel for new forms of sexual abuse. But, faced with this and despite the adoption of a specific Directive, most of the States have transposed it badly and late, including my country, Spain. Furthermore, the Commission has published its report on the application of the Directive a year late and has received many complaints about its superficiality. Keep it in mind. Given this, it is worth asking if minors and their problems and abuses are a secondary issue for this Commission. It is a doubt that has to assail us. It is you, the Commission and the States, who must put the protection of minors among their priorities and effectively demonstrate that they are working for citizens. Do your homework, please.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur and those who have worked on this report. I also want to pick up the points that have been made in that we would hope that the Commission’s next report will give us fuller details and better data. That is listed throughout the report in front of us today. As others have said, child abuse, whether online or not, is growing. It is big money and it is permutating in the light of new technologies and new opportunities, such as unaccompanied minors left in isolation and thus vulnerable, or children with disabilities. Even children who consider themselves street smart can find their images used or worse.  So I welcome the report’s emphasis on raising awareness and empowering young people to help them stay safe and to report. We learn that boys are less likely to report sexual abuse. I think this is where hotlines become so important because they offer confidentiality, they offer advice and they also bring action. The cross—border dimension is increasingly important and the Commissioner and others have referred to some of the initiatives – some of the things that we stressed in this report – such as tracking known sex offenders, improving cross—border police cooperation through the work of Europol, Eurojust, and the EU’s role in helping to develop and acquire the necessary investigative expertise. Again, I welcome what the Commissioner has said on that. I think many of us are disturbed to discover that many Member States still do not have functional notice and takedown procedures. So again, we welcome what the Commissioner has said in terms of taking action against those Member States in order to facilitate the directive that they should already be implementing.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, crimes involving children, particularly those that are of a sexual nature, are simply abhorrent. The UK has always proudly led the fight to combat the abuse of children, both in terms of strong criminal sanctions and a high level of care for those that are affected. UK legislation includes a very important law which permits British nationals to be prosecuted under UK law for crimes they have committed abroad.  Given the prominent rise in child sex tourism overseas, our citizens must be able to feel the full force of national law when committing these crimes, but more must and can be done by our governments to protect children. In particular, we must do more to tackle the ever-growing issue of illegal content being posted on the Internet.  Whilst this may be more prominent in underground online websites on the so-called ‘Dark Web’, it is also a serious issue in our day-to-day social media outlets. In fact, a BBC investigation this year found that 80% of items reported as child sexual abuse were not actually removed. This is simply not good enough. Only when governments are willing to take zero-tolerance attitudes will we ever see the much-needed breakthrough needed to tackle child abuse. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I know that you gave your good speech with goodwill, but don't you think that we should really give up such a language, such concepts as so-called sex tourism, and oppose it?After all, an abused, corrupted child, often given by relatives to a pervert who goes on a so-called sex trip, is not a tourist attraction.Really listen, what we always control is our language, so let's not use language that trivializes evil.Hope we agree.

name: Margot PARKER
text: blue-card answer. – There was no intention to trivialise this at all. We know it is jolly serious, of course we do, and more must be done. But do forgive the use of the language, because we have to make sure that people understand exactly what we are talking about. It is serious. Something has to be done. Children’s lives are ruined all over the world, and we must all pull together very much to make sure that we reduce the nastiness that goes on, so that we can actually protect our children in a better, much more sensitive way.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children are, first and foremost, moral crimes, because they offend and damage the tender souls of victims, who are sensitive and vulnerable. In addition, they cause them psychological problems, which often leave unhealed wounds for life. At the same time, in combination with child pornography, criminal offenses are committed which the state must prosecute immediately, harshly and exemplary. Children are the future of every state, they are the institutions that guarantee the survival and continuity of the nation. That is why we must protect them both at the family level and at the state level. Unfortunately, the possibilities of the internet enable those who want to exploit and sexually abuse children to do so. That is why the state must act proactively, investigate, identify perpetrators and victims in a timely manner, protect children and, as I said before, impose severe sanctions on those who sexually abuse them. For these very reasons and despite any weaknesses, I believe that we should vote in favor of the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, I congratulate the rapporteur, Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, for her excellent report on the implementation of the directive on combating sexual crime against children, including child pornography and crime on the Internet. Report one year late due to Member States' delays in implementing the Directive. I wonder what could be slowing down the implementation of the legislation on the most heinous forms of child sexual violence. The age of aggrieved children - as we know from research - is constantly decreasing: 70% of victims have not even entered puberty, and there are also victims who are not even two years old. At this point I would like to point out that, in addition to websites with child pornography, also those hosted on servers outside the European Union and which, according to the directive, are to be blocked or removed by the Member States, there is a huge and growing plague of sexual crimes against children in the darknet or if we want in the deep web, in the TOR network. We are talking about an illegal, hidden area of ​​the Internet that ensures complete anonymity. Tens of thousands of transactions are carried out there involving child pornography, including the rape and sexual torture of children. This unexplored crime scene requires immediate intervention, and I appeal from here to the European Commission services and the Member States.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank Mrs Anna Maria Corazza Bildt for her excellent report. The Directive against the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children online deals with an issue on which the European Union can and must give a strong impetus to ensure that all Member States adopt suitable systems and measures to effectively combat these very serious abuses. It is particularly appreciable that the report calls on Member States to adopt rules aimed at preventing and combating new criminal offenses, such as cyberbullying and "revenge porn", which have sometimes led young and very young people even to suicide. And again, it calls on the Member States to deploy adequate human and financial resources, to invest in innovative technological solutions useful for identifying the perpetrators, and to increase cooperation through greater use of joint investigation teams. But it is also necessary to develop educational and awareness programs for minors and their parents, to prevent the risks of the network, and also to promote initiatives aimed at avoiding the so-called secondary victimization, that is, attitudes of reproach or blame that cause so much suffering in victims.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - I would like to thank the rapporteur for this strong and clear report. Absolute zero tolerance must apply when it comes to the sexual abuse and exploitation of children. Unfortunately, today we still have too many problems in the detection and prosecution of such criminal offenses. Here, Europe can and must prove its added value. Good cross-border cooperation between Member States is of the utmost importance. There are still many challenges here, especially in the field of online crime. We are constantly confronted with new forms of online abuse that require continuous investment in new digital detection techniques, an adapted legislative framework and further prevention and awareness-raising. Finally, I would like to point out that children with disabilities are particularly vulnerable. Much more often they are confronted with physical and sexual violence. There were also other forms of abuse than in children without disabilities, such as during the daily hygiene routine or during their treatment. This really requires special attention and vigilance.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the father that I have been and that I remain and the grandfather that I have become cannot hide the uneasiness and concern he feels at thinking that we did not do everything - at least what we could - to prevent sexual predators from taking action. Of course - and I welcome it - in 2011 the European Union adopted a directive, of which Ms Corazza Bildt, in her excellent report, makes an objective and critical assessment, distinguishing between what has been done and what can be to be improved and what remains to be done. For my part, I want to focus on a few measures that I feel are both necessary and urgent. We must ensure that Member States exchange the information they have on pedophiles, in order to prevent those of them who move to another Member State from being able to carry out an activity which brings them into contact with children. We must, in cooperation with internet service providers, provide ourselves with the technological means to detect and block child pornography content, as well as payments intended for such services. We must ensure that the identification of the people behind every internet connection is possible and, to do so, encourage internet service providers and network operators to take the necessary measures to limit the number of users per IP address. Finally, we must ensure that the Member States which have not yet done so criminalize, as is already the case in Belgium, cyberpredation, that is to say the act, for an adult , camouflage themselves and communicate online with a minor or a person they believe to be a minor, with the aim of subsequently committing a criminal act against them. In conclusion, I know that all of this will not prevent all passage into the act of sexual predators, but, at least, we will have done all we can to prevent it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Anne Marie, for her very conscientious and thorough work on this report. So do all the shadow rapporteurs. They were able to comprehensively assess the experience gained so far with the implementation of the directive on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children, and to point out possible improvements, in particular in the field of cooperation between Member States and in prevention. However, I am most pleased with the rapporteur's emphasis on using the term "child sexual abuse material" instead of child pornography. It is not just about the words, but about the very essence of the crimes we are talking about. Already when the directive was adopted in 2011, I also requested a change in the title of the document, and I pointed out that the term pornography can only refer to material that is created with the voluntary consent of an adult. In the case of minors, such materials are by definition a record of their abuse and their creator and disseminators automatically become criminals. When we realize this, we accept at the same time the seriousness of such action, and thus the urgency of combating it.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we must unequivocally condemn any form of child abuse or sexual exploitation. Child sexual abuse is, unfortunately, a crime that is difficult to disclose and report. And here, the Commissioner said very well: we must not point fingers at each other. Here we simply have to make a team, to be in solidarity - the European institutions with the national ones. The rapporteur, Anna Maria, and her colleagues have shown precisely new ways in which we can identify these abuses. There needs to be better police, judicial and judicial cooperation between Member States, using the tools provided by Europol and Eurojust. There is a need for assistance, for the protection of victims. Not all states have an adequate and sufficient infrastructure. But, Commissioner, Mr President, dear Anna Maria, I believe that education is needed to prevent possible victims, especially children. Sex education, in order to prevent children from falling into the trap, is extremely important, I think, and the online sexual exploitation of children, we must admit, is growing, therefore, I agree with the blocking of those sites that contain information. of this kind. And, in the end, the punishments must be toughened, because any such offense is a crime.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, I would like to thank Anna Maria for the work she has done. This is a very important direction. Any pornographic crime, and even more so against children, is always of a cross-border nature, so this is an area that international institutions such as our Parliament should deal with in a special way. Therefore, it is good that we are moving in this direction. But we will not effectively solve this problem if we do not eliminate its subsoil, that is, the deeply diseased, pornographic nature of our culture. After all, we all know Josef Fritzl was a pathological pornophile. He was also passionate about pornography and tormented his entire family, daughters, granddaughters. We are now watching the Weinstein scandal and on this occasion we are listening to the confessions of big stars, people we often admire and know, wives whose husbands took prostitutes home to stage something - will these people be safe parents for their children? We really need to remove the foundations of this disease, restore health to our culture, respect for the sexes, respect for love so profoundly profaned in our time. I will support all the work that you do, all the activities, but I would like to count on the same solidarity. I very much regret that in this report, which has valuable content anyway, many of my conclusions have been omitted. It's good that there were any.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr. president. Commissar. Thank you Anna Maria, rapporteur for this magnificent report. Thank you for your tireless work on behalf of children's rights. In these days of Christmas, of lights, of gifts, of images of happy children, there is another face that is not bright but very dark and very cruel for millions of children who are sexually exploited in Europe and in the world. For this reason, this Directive, which fights against sexual abuse and child pornography, is the necessary response so that children and adolescents who should live in safety are not duped by adults who subject them to humiliation, rape and abuse and then use those images, leading, in many cases, these minors to suicide, because they are victims again and again. It is necessary to criminalize sexual extortion, which affects more adolescent girls every day. When will the protection and greater protection for the most vulnerable victims? We need Member States to have a clear definition of child pornography; that the penalties for possession of child abuse material be toughened; that websites that broadcast content are blocked; greater police and judicial cooperation; and that the internet industry assume once and for all its responsibility to guarantee the safety of minors. The difficulty of prosecuting these cross-border crimes makes the fight against them more difficult, but from this Parliament we demand zero tolerance for those who violate the rights of children. Therefore, prevent, prosecute, protect and respond to the victims.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, according to the data provided by the Council of Europe, one in five children in Europe are victims of some form of sexual violence – one in five, colleagues – and, more than that, children with disabilities are twice as likely to be abused as non-disabled children. These children have mainly faced sexual abuse within the family circle, become victims of child pornography, prostitution and exploitation via the internet. I particularly support the rapporteur with regard to combating the new forms of sexual crimes against children spread on the internet and developing innovative solutions.  The EU needs to intensify its efforts in prevention and prosecution of such abuses, particularly by promoting cross-border cooperation with the help of Europol and Eurojust. Prevention is the most challenging task, but also the most essential. Therefore, colleagues, I ask you to support it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! The report places particular emphasis on prevention as the most effective tool against abuse and exploitation. The most vulnerable are children who are forced to grow up without parents, preferably under the supervision of other adults, otherwise completely without supervision. In the Member State where I come from, Romania, the disordered situation of unaccompanied minors is a serious problem. This is because millions of Romanian citizens work in the richer western Member States of the EU and many are leaving their children behind, leaving their upbringing to grandparents, friends or their own. This is now a mass phenomenon in Romania and is causing serious problems. According to one statistic, tens of thousands of such children live in the country and apparently many do not appear in official figures. This phenomenon is also known in other Central and Eastern European states. If we are talking about prevention, we need to do something about such harmful practices, as parental supervision cannot be replaced, children who are not next to their parents will always be vulnerable. We must not allow the right to free employment within the Union to contribute to situations in which children become vulnerable.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a really great report. I remember discussing the draft directive in the Council of Ministers of Justice in 2010 and 2011. At that time, I had the opportunity to represent the Czech Republic, the debate was very general and many countries were more or less reluctant to adopt this legislation. We have made enormous progress since then, and this debate today shows that. I very much welcome the report that the rapporteur has prepared, which contains a number of valuable suggestions on how to tighten up existing legislation and a specific directive in the future. I would be very much in favor, Commissioner, of really addressing the specific initiatives and proposals contained in the rapporteur's report. The issue of sharing information on offenders between Member States, the issue of blocking websites, the issue of better opportunities for victims of crime to report abuse, these are things that would be worth considering whether the directive should not be amended and re-amended in the future.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, with whom I share, together with other colleagues, the experience of the "Minors" intergroup, for this beautiful and very comprehensive report. This was a much anticipated report, that of the commission, six years after the directive, but actually the results are still rather inadequate and in any case patchy, while the picture of this transnational crime has worsened, given that, as the data of last April of the Internet Watch Foundation, Internet domains now host 60 percent of web pages with images of child sexual abuse, an increase of 19 percent over the previous year. Commissioner Avramopoulos is right when he says that a strong initiative from the Commission will have to be taken for Member States to comply with the rules and measures of the directive, because it is a criminal crime, and therefore we must face it with zero tolerance, multidisciplinarity, strengthen cooperation and information between Member States, but also between police and law enforcement authorities, in particular for investigations, for prosecution, for the protection of victims, for blocking, which has only been accepted by half of the Member States, and for immediate removal of online material. In fact, I hope that the AVMS directive will soon be approved, which thanks to our amendments - but the trialogue is still ongoing - provides for an obligation for video sharing platforms to have effective mechanisms for reporting and immediate and permanent removal of these. contents. But this does not happen today, and many minors are led, even in my country, to suicide for this. Member States must also make the grooming and cyber-tracking of minors a crime. I end up saying just this: today we have some positive experiences. I can name only one: the Italian Postal Police, for twenty years, has a specific body dedicated only to these crimes.Here, I hope that these experiences can become a common heritage.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the fight against child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation must be on the agenda. We must be just as resolute about the exemplary punishment of child pornography. Directive 2011/93 sets out regulations that need to be further strengthened, in particular with regard to the punishment of online child pornography. Taking severe punishment for the heinous crime of child sexual abuse must be our priority. The context and scope of Directive 2011/93 are clear. In addition, the need for increased prevention measures, as well as for the identification of victims, must be emphasized. Furthermore, assistance to victims and their protection is particularly important. So no tolerance for those who promote child pornography! Their place is not in society but in prison.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, children are the future of every society and we have a great responsibility to enable them to grow up as safely and carefree as possible.We live in a time when this is not so easy because technology has advanced greatly and become available to everyone, even the youngest children, and predators have easier access to victims today than ever before.That is why quality policies and awareness campaigns are extremely important.The rapporteur recognizes this well and recommends a number of good measures to protect children and adolescents.But in addition to raising awareness by educating both children and parents on how to use the internet without overexposing themselves to potential predators, I think prevention must also go in the direction of publicly recording convicted pedophiles so parents can see at any time who is threatening their children.As families live in the dark not knowing if there are convicted child sex abusers around them, it will be much harder to protect them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you all for this very interesting and, believe me, necessary discussion tonight. The fight against child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation is the duty of our entire society, and all actors must contribute to it. We, as Commissioners, are ready to play our own part, but we all must work together to fight this terrible crime in order to protect and defend our children. As I said at the beginning, it is not only about legislation, it is also about effective and immediate action. I therefore welcome your contributions to keep this very important issue high on all our agendas. Such a crime against children who – as very correctly was said tonight – are the most vulnerable in our societies is the most atrocious crime, and we must fight together until we can manage to eradicate it entirely. Thank you for your contributions tonight; together, we have made a step forward. Once again, my thanks to the rapporteur.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I wish to thank all colleagues, especially my shadows, for their great support for my report. Together, let us really make sure that the Member States prioritise child protection. I would also tonight like to pay tribute to the police, the judges, the lawyers, the NGOs, the INHOPE network, Eurojust, Europol, the EU Anti-trafficking Coordinator, the Fundamental Rights Agency, for their relentless efforts to protect children. They are the heroes of our time and deserve our support. According to UNICEF, 53% of children abused are as young as 10 years old, and sexual abuse causes longstanding trauma for children. Often kids denounce their aggressors only when they are adults. Therefore we call on the Member States to extend the statute of limitation for these crimes. I welcome the fact that France has just passed a law to this effect. We also asked for the adoption of aggravating sanctions for offenders who are in a position of trust and authority – teachers, guardians, coaches, a relative – and mandatory background checks. You said it, Commissioner, and I am glad you are going to follow up on our new proposals for persons working with children. Tougher sanctions also for offences against children with disabilities. As regards orphans: yes, institutions that cover up crimes should be held liable, because silence is complicity. On sex tourism, I would like to say that it is criminalised by the Anti-Trafficking Directive. It is a crime under European law, and Member States must do more on prevention: setting up prevention programmes, identifying men at risk of recidivism, training officials, and education for children and parents on the risk of the net. It is important to empower our kids to defend themselves on the net. Updating registers of child sexual offenders and sharing information on criminal convictions and disqualifications.  Child sexual abuse is a cross-border crime and it requires a European response. We have to make full use of the tools that are available at European level – the European Investigation Order, the Arrest Warrant and the Joint Investigation Teams – and we have to share best practices on investigation tools; covert infiltration is not used enough by all the Member States. We also need to improve information-sharing and interoperability.  I shall finish by responding to the issue of data. Yes, we need more data from the Member States so that the Commission can really make a thorough assessment. Let me assure you that, together with the Intergroup on children’s rights, whom I would like to thank especially here tonight, we are going to continue to be committed and follow up on the Commission, with the Member States. We are not going to give up as long as everything that is in the Directive and the additional issues are going to be implemented. With our vote tomorrow, let’s send a strong and united message to the Member States that it is time to go from words to action to stop child sexual abuse.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 14 December 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - The figures for pedophilia are alarming, since more than 13% of young girls and 5.7% of young boys are believed to be victims. And the situation is bound to worsen, as Europe faces a record influx of unaccompanied minors to its coasts, the latter of course being the prime targets of traffickers. The greatest firmness is required with regard to the perpetrators of such acts. However, not only has the European Union failed to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the effectiveness of the 2011 directive, but many additional measures are needed to effectively combat these abuses. Thus, while Australia has recently instituted exit bans for those convicted of pedophile acts, it is inconceivable that European states do not also crack down on sex tourism, which, in addition to the human tragedies it provokes and permanently tarnishes the image of Western states in the regions affected by these practices. At a time when France is questioning the age of consent, it is also urgent to address the evil at the root by opposing the hypersexualization of children and, in particular, young girls, which is a worrying deviance from protest feminism.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - I am very pleased, as a mother of four, to take action at EU level against this lowest form of crime, which is constantly taking its toll, endangering the children of all of us - which is penetrating even the most vulnerable children's rooms through the world of the internet. We cannot waste time, as child pornography takes its victims much more widely than the public perception would be aware of. Exemplary international cooperation is needed to curb this phenomenon, as the Internet knows no borders, so it is not enough to fight one by one at Member State level. In particular, I would like to welcome the fact that the report calls on the Member States to set up hotlines across borders to search for missing children quickly and efficiently. A very good example in this area is AMBER Alert Europe, the European Child Rescue Alert and Police Network for Missing Children. According to the organization, 250,000 children are reported missing in the EU each year. In 76% of cases, the child's life is most at risk within three hours of abduction. As law enforcement often stops at national borders, a rapid international response is essential, especially in border areas. Effective cooperation and joint action between law enforcement, border guards and local authorities will make it possible to find abducted children and save children's lives. Child safety must remain a central issue in all EU Member States. Let's take care of our children!

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - Child abuse is a horrible crime, contrary to human dignity, and it must be prosecuted more effectively at European level especially in this era of digital opportunities and transnational crime. I am happy to note that this report includes a balanced gender perspective: it recognizes that sexual abuse impacts girls the most, but also underlines that there is a significant percentage of boys involved. Furthermore, one of the recitals recognizes that "men are less likely to report abuse." I believe that we should deepen this path that makes male victimization visible, imagining solutions to reduce social stigma and forms of intervention better adapted to the needs of children and boys who suffer abuse, from prevention to treatment. I also want to draw attention to an important aspect of child sexual exploitation not included in the report and that has nothing to do with production but with consumption: the massive availability of pornography in this digital age and its negative impact on moral development and neuropsychological of children, adolescents and adults. Consumption is also a form of abuse. I encourage from here that this issue enters more strongly on the future agenda of Parliament.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - Children are a particularly vulnerable section of society who must ensure the highest standards of protection, create all necessary conditions for their healthy and sustainable development, ensure proper and effective implementation of children's rights standards, establish verification mechanisms to verify compliance with child protection standards. Child sexual abuse is possible both in real life and on the Internet, and I would like to emphasize in particular the need for wide-ranging legal regulation, not only at national but also at EU level, covering all possible cases of child abuse, child pornography and strict liability for relevant offenses. criminal offenses, as well as ways and means of technologically preventing child pornography and sexual exploitation in the digital space. I believe that it is particularly important to ensure the proper functioning of EU legislation on combating the sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, in order to ensure the harmonious development of European societies.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - Children represent the future of humanity, and the violation of their fundamental rights is a direct attack on humanity. Protecting the future of humanity is all the more difficult in the age of digitalization, as the online dimension has led to an increase in threats and risks to the safety of children in the online environment. In order to combat this scourge, it is imperative that all Member States step up their efforts to fully and correctly transpose Directive 2011/93 / EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on combating child sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and of child pornography. At the same time, Member States must ensure the exchange of good practice on educational materials and training programs for all actors involved (teachers, parents, educators, law enforcement authorities). Of course, we regret that the Member States have faced considerable difficulties in applying that solid and comprehensive legal framework for combating child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation, especially with regard to the provisions on prevention, research and criminal prosecution, as well as protection and assistance to victims.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - In my recent report on the fight against cybercrime, I devoted a special section to the dangers facing children in the modern digital world. Today, UNICEF reveals that young people, especially children, remain virtually unprotected on the Internet from a wide range of risks, including cyberbullying, privacy breaches, abuse and sexual exploitation. Child sexual abuse online and offline is a growing tragedy that has affected even infants. It is a cross-border crime that requires transnational police and judicial cooperation in order to tackle and coordinate properly between European crime authorities. The criminal networks of child sexual abuse on the internet have evolved and law enforcement authorities are faced with laws that do not always anticipate future developments. It is our duty to institutionally launch the necessary changes that will contribute to the prevention and fight against this criminal phenomenon. Proper implementation and updating of existing legislation will help us criminalize or prevent new forms of crime. At the same time, with transnational information and awareness campaigns, we must protect children and educate adults against the ignorance and fear that exacerbate the problem.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. It's time to stop dodging and pretending the problem doesn't exist. The scale of crimes related to the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography continues to grow, especially on the Internet. Therefore, we must take all measures to prosecute such crimes effectively and to punish those responsible properly. The internet cannot be a safe haven for crimes against children. Online crime prosecution must not be held back by ill-conceived freedom of speech and internet freedom. Using childish naivety and trust to persuade and solicit for sexual purposes condemns children to life trauma. Therefore, cooperation is needed not only from law enforcement agencies, but also from owners of portals, platforms and online environments to prevent and effectively prosecute such crimes. It is also important to raise awareness about the dangers that exist on the Internet, both among children themselves, as well as parents, teachers and all those who work with children on a daily basis. The report by Ms Corraza Bildt carefully examines the implementation of EU law in the Member States in the area of ​​combating the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography and, unfortunately, shows how much more remains to be done to ensure effective protection of our youngest citizens.
